COAUTHORS: ["Gail Davenport\u00a0*","Sonya Halpern\u00a0*","Ed Harbison\u00a0*","Sally Harrell\u00a0*","Kim Jackson\u00a0*","Lester Jackson\u00a0*","Emanuel Jones\u00a0*","Harold Jones\u00a0*","Jennifer Jordan\u00a0*","David Lucas\u00a0*","Nikki Merritt\u00a0*","Nan Orrock\u00a0*","Sheikh Rahman\u00a0*","Michael Rhett\u00a0*","Valencia Seay\u00a0*","Freddie Sims\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["01/27/2021 - Senate Hopper","01/28/2021 - Senate Read and Referred"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill defines "rural county." This bill requires the Secretary of State to develop and implement a pilot program to provide grants to rural counties to establish an advance voting location. The bill's specified goal is to increase rural county voting. This bill requires the Secretary of State to submit a report to the General Assembly by January 31 of odd numbered years regarding the effectiveness of the program. This bill becomes effective when funds are appropriated for its implementation.

COAUTHORS: ["Gloria Butler\u00a0*","Gail Davenport\u00a0*","Ed Harbison\u00a0*","Sally Harrell\u00a0*","Kim Jackson\u00a0*","Emanuel Jones\u00a0*","Harold Jones\u00a0*","Jennifer Jordan\u00a0*","David Lucas\u00a0*","Nikki Merritt\u00a0*","Nan Orrock\u00a0*","Elena Parent\u00a0*","Sheikh Rahman\u00a0*","Valencia Seay\u00a0*","Freddie Sims\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["01/27/2021 - Senate Hopper","01/28/2021 - Senate Read and Referred"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill is an Agreement Among the States to Elect the President by National Popular Vote. This bill establishes the right for states to use the popular vote method in presidential elections. This bill requires each state to determine the national popular vote winner and to appoint all electors based upon who won the national popular vote. This bill lays out nomination procedures and procedures in case of a tie. This bill goes into effect collectively when states with a majority of popular votes have signed on to the agreement. This bill clarifies withdrawal guidelines. This bill defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["01/27/2021 - Senate Hopper","01/28/2021 - Senate Read and Referred"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill specifies voter identification requirements for absentee ballot submissions. This bill specifies verification requirements for the registrar or absentee ballot clerk.

COAUTHORS: ["Gloria Butler\u00a0*","Gail Davenport\u00a0*","Sonya Halpern\u00a0*","Ed Harbison\u00a0*","Sally Harrell\u00a0*","Kim Jackson\u00a0*","Lester Jackson\u00a0*","Emanuel Jones\u00a0*","Harold Jones\u00a0*","Jennifer Jordan\u00a0*","David Lucas\u00a0*","Nikki Merritt\u00a0*","Nan Orrock\u00a0*","Elena Parent\u00a0*","Sheikh Rahman\u00a0*","Michael Rhett\u00a0*","Valencia Seay\u00a0*","Freddie Sims\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["01/27/2021 - Senate Hopper","01/28/2021 - Senate Read and Referred"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows voters to opt to be placed on the permanent absentee voter list. This bill outlines when a voter may be removed from the permanent absentee voter list. This bill specifies that permanent absentee voters must be included in data collected and maintained for the Secretary of State.

HISTORY: ["01/26/2021 - House Hopper","01/27/2021 - House First Readers","01/28/2021 - House Second Readers"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows voters to register to vote at their polling place, at the office of the registrar, or with the absentee ballot clerk on Election Day or during the specified period of early voting. The voter is required to fill out a voter registration form and show one of the accepted forms of ID. This bill states that those successfully registering in this manner may vote a provisional ballot. This bill requires the registration application to be verified within three business days. This bill lays out specific actions for if the voter registration verification is successful or if it fails. It also requires poll officers to allow those standing in line at closing time to be allowed to register. This bill enumerates the same process for those registering during the early voting period. This bill specifies certain processes for counting a provisional ballot.

COAUTHORS: ["Gloria Butler\u00a0*","Gail Davenport\u00a0*","Ed Harbison\u00a0*","Sally Harrell\u00a0*","Kim Jackson\u00a0*","Emanuel Jones\u00a0*","Harold Jones\u00a0*","David Lucas\u00a0*","Nikki Merritt\u00a0*","Nan Orrock\u00a0*","Elena Parent\u00a0*","Sheikh Rahman\u00a0*","Michael Rhett\u00a0*","Valencia Seay\u00a0*","Freddie Sims\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["01/27/2021 - Senate Hopper","01/28/2021 - Senate Read and Referred"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill removes the requirement that poll officers be residents or employees of the county in which they serve. This bill requires poll officers to be Georgia residents.

COAUTHORS: ["Gloria Butler\u00a0*","Sonya Halpern\u00a0*","Sally Harrell\u00a0*","Kim Jackson\u00a0*","Harold Jones\u00a0*","Nikki Merritt\u00a0*","Nan Orrock\u00a0*","Sheikh Rahman\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["01/26/2021 - Senate Hopper","01/27/2021 - Senate Read and Referred"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill provides for absentee ballot drop boxes at every advance voting location. This bill outlines when the drop boxes should be available, security requirements for drop boxes, construction, labeling, and design requirements for drop boxes. This bill outlines ballot pick up, security, and transportation requirements from drop boxes.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2021 - House Hopper","01/14/2021 - House First Readers","01/26/2021 - House Second Readers"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows county electors to vote in any precinct in the county as long as certain conditions are met by the election superintendent. This bill allows the election superintendent to make the decision of whether to allow electors to vote in any precinct at least 30 days before the election, and requires the superintendent to notify the Secretary of State in writing. This bill requires the election superintendent to notify voters by posting notices and advertising the decision in the legal organ or the county once per week for two weeks immediately before the election. The superintendent's decision will also apply to related run-off elections.

HISTORY: ["01/12/2021 - House Hopper","01/13/2021 - House First Readers","01/14/2021 - House Second Readers","02/11/2021 - House Special Committee On Election Integrity Rich Subcommittee (11:30 2/11/2021 406 CLOB HYBRID)","02/17/2021 - House Special Committee On Election Integrity Rich Subcommittee (15:30 2/17/2021 406 CLOB)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires a candidate on a ballot in a nonpartisan election who dies to remain on the ballot. This bill requires all votes cast for the candidate be counted. This bill directs that if the deceased candidate wins the election, the contest should be handled as a failure to fill the office. This bill outlines provisions for if the deceased candidate qualifies for a run-off election. This bill prohibits a candidate being sworn into office if the candidate did not receive the majority of votes cast in the election.

HISTORY: ["01/12/2021 - House Hopper","01/13/2021 - House First Readers","01/14/2021 - House Second Readers"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill prohibits a board of elections, board of elections and registration, superintendent, and county board of registrars from accepting grants, gifts, or other outside funding.

HISTORY: ["01/12/2021 - House Hopper","01/13/2021 - House First Readers","01/14/2021 - House Second Readers"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill changes deadlines and administrative requirements for filing as a candidate for nonpartisan local elections, with provisions for counties with consolidated governments. This bill specifies ballot content requirements for local nonpartisan elections during the general primary, including if a simultaneous partisan election if occuring.

HISTORY: ["01/05/2021 - House Prefiled","01/11/2021 - House Hopper","01/12/2021 - House First Readers","01/13/2021 - House Second Readers","02/11/2021 - House Special Committee On Election Integrity Rich Subcommittee (11:30 2/11/2021 406 CLOB HYBRID)","02/17/2021 - House Special Committee On Election Integrity Rich Subcommittee (15:30 2/17/2021 406 CLOB)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill outlines requirements for the content and format of absentee primary runoff ballots and instructions for voters on ranking candidates. This bill provides requirements for the instructions and return of these ballots. This bill outlines requirements for these absentee ballot envelopes. This bill lays out the administrative requirements for processing and counting these absentee primary runoff ballots when they are returned. This bill requires the Secretary of State to create instructions fro opening, counting, and canvassing these ballots.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires any federal election not held on the date of the regularly scheduled primary and general election, and special elections, be conducted with ranked choice voting. This bill outlines the procedure to be used for counting ballots with ranked choice voting. This bill defines relevant terms. This bill requires all election proclamations where ranked choice voting is being used to include a statement that "votes shall be cast and tabulated using ranked-choice voting," with an explanation of ranked-choice voting. This bill requires a ballot include necessary information to use ranked-choice voting. This bill makes changes to existing law to comply with ranked choice voting requirements.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires anyone petitioning to run for office through a political party to include their month and date portion of their date of birth on their petition. This bill requires parties to file with the chief election officer at least 170 days before the primary, including a names of party officers.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires anyone applying to be a political party candidate on a ballot to include the month and date portion of their date of birth in the petition. This bill requires parties to file with the chief election officer by the 170th day before the primary.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill defines an official observer. This bill requires rules adopted for elections to be approved by the legislature. This bill changes timeline requirements for voter service centers. This bill outlines requirements for removing ballots from ballot drop boxes, allows the county clerk to determine ballot drop off locations, with certain considerations related to locale and security, and requires drop boxes by locked and sealed, with certain specifications. This bill requires two election observers from different parties for ballot counting and handling, with two observers at each counting station within the counting center. This bill outlines security specifications for voting systems and tabulators.

HISTORY: ["02/23/2022 - Introduced, placed on calendar. H.J. 354.","03/17/2022 - Placed on calendar under unfinished business. H.J. 591.","03/21/2022 - Amendment H-8208 filed. H.J. 602.","04/07/2022 - Fiscal note."]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires nomination papers be signed by eligible electors.
  • Allows one person who is a precinct election official, selected by the chief judge, to attend a primary election recount.
  • Changes deadlines for withdrawal of a candidate.
  • Establishes notification guidelines for a caucus and elections.
  • Establishes legal funding sources for elections. 
  • Requires the commissioner to make public notifications related to the election 30 days in advance, and including information about the post-election audit.
  • Allows the commissioner to use an electronic election register under certain conditions.
  • Requires public announcement of canvass results at a precinct when the canvass is done and someone at the precinct requests it.
  • Applies rules and timelines governing unofficial canvas of election results to all levels of election, and requires the commissioner to provide explanation in writing to the state commissioner if all precincts are not reported. 
  • Changes days appropriate officials meet to canvass the vote and conduct a second canvas.
  • Specifies requirements for ordering a recount and requirements for conducting it and reporting it.
  • Outlines requirements for appointment to observe an audit.
  • Provides relevant definitions.
  • Specifies requirements for processing absentee ballot applications, and what should be included, including tracking by the commissioner.
  • Specifies voter duties in filling out absentee ballots and envelopes and affidavits.
  • Outlines absentee ballot, envelope, and affidavit handling requirements and deadlines, including what to do when requirements are not met or a voter is deceased.
  • Specifies which elections require the commissioner to prepare a separate absentee ballot style for each precinct.
  • Outlines procedures for contested gubernatorial and lieutenant governor elections.
  • Specifies roles in the case of the clerk's absence.
  • Changes the timeline for an impeachment.
  • Outlines timelines for special elections to fill vacancies based on whether Congress is in session.

• Requires nomination papers be signed by eligible electors.
  • Allows one person who is a precinct election official, selected by the chief judge, to attend a primary election recount.

  • Establishes notification guidelines for a caucus and elections.
  • Establishes legal funding sources for elections. 
  • Sets a timeline for notification of elections and the audit.

  • Requires public announcement of canvas results at a precinct when the canvas is done and someone at the precinct requests it.
  • Applies rules and timelines governing unofficial canvas of election results to all levels of election, and requires the commissioner to provide explanation in writing to the state commissioner if all precincts are not reported.

HISTORY: "02/10/2022 - Introduced, referred to State Government. H.J. 236."
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes the statement that a ballot will be rejected if the voter uses a mark to identify a voter's ballot.
  • Requires the board to certify an election canvas summary report no later than one week after convening. 
  • Requires the secretary of state to present to the board of state canvassers abstracts of votes cast at the election no later than 34 days after the election date.
  • Allows the county board of canvassers to order a recount of votes cast in each election precinct where a vote was cast for an office.
  • Requires the commissioner to send a copy of a request for recount to each commissioner of a county where elections were held immediately upon receipt of the request, requiring the commissioners in the county to conduct a recount.
  • Establishes a candidates for statewide office only be required to pay one bond for a recount.
  • Outlines the number of designees to attend a recount, based upon the number of ballots cast.
  • Requires recounts be conducted by hand. 
  • Clarifies that any mark in a "voting target" is a vote for a candidate, unless the board finds the voter made the mark by accident or attempted to erase the mark.
  • Establishes that at least two-thirds of members of the recount board must sign the written report of findings.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines absentee ballot submission guidelines for Address Confidentiality Program participants.
  • Lays out appointment limitations for conference board appointees. 
  • Adds actions to the list of behaviors leading to election misconduct in the first, second, third degree.
  • Adds actions to the list of behaviors leading to technical infractions.
  • Requires the state commissioner to immediately notify the attorney general and county attorney of election law violations or misconduct.
  • Requires the attorney general or county attorney to investigate reported election misconduct and implementation of certain actions based on the outcome of the investigation.
  • Precludes nomination papers being filed on behalf of a candidate if papers were already filed on behalf of the candidate for the same office and the same year.
  • Outlines signature requirements for nomination papers.
  • Outlines requirements for nonparty political organizations to nominate a candidate through convention or caucus, including minimum numbers of eligible electors required.
  • Outlines nominating petition signature requirements for statewide and federal office holders.
  • Allows the state commissioner of elections to issue guidance clarifying election law.
  • Stipulates that the county commissioner of elections does not possess home rule powers related to conduct of elections.
  • Requires the state registrar to quarterly conduct voter verification in the statewide voter registration file, with specific guidelines and timelines
  • Requires the state registrar to use information from the Electronic Registration Information Center and the department of transportation to update voter registrations.
  • Requires the voter identification card to include the times during which polling places are open on election days.
  • Provides timelines for verifying or rejecting a change of address notification.
  • Requires the commissioner to participate in the US Postal Service national change of address program and verify voter registration through a specific related process.
  • Changes deadlines related to voter change of address verification.
  • Requires a cancellation of voter registration if a voter's registration record has been inactive for two successive general elections.
  • Outlines reporting and publication requirements for the commissioner of registration.
  • Requires the state registrar of voters to conduct audits of voter registration maintenance in certain timelines and outlines related actions.
  • Outlines oversight guidelines by the state commissioner of the county commissioner and defines "oversee."
  • Requires a person on the precinct election board who changes political party within 30 days of the election be immediately removed from the board.
  • Outlines notification requirements for change of precinct polling place.
  • Requires public notification of polling place hours on a website by November 7, 2024.
  • Prohibits someone running for office from assisting a voter in the voting booth.
  • Prohibits precinct election officials or county commissioners from interfering with someone who is voting and outlines penalties.
  • Entitles voters two consecutive hours of time off from work to vote.
  • Allows members of local law enforcement and state patrol to take "reasonable actions" to prevent election violations.
  • Sets a timeline for a commissioner to send an absentee ballot application and requires certain actions in a public health disaster.
  • Prohibits prefilling absentee ballot applications, except for ballot type and date of the election, and prohibits sending absentee ballot applications without a submitted request.
  • Outlines timeline requirements for sending absentee ballots based on receipt date of the application.
  • Outlines reporting requirements for absentee ballots.
  • Requires the commissioner to enclose information with an absentee ballot about return by a person not prohibited to collect and deliver the ballot, including outlining who may drop off an absentee ballot.
  • Requires absentee voting in-person and satellite absentee voting 20 days before the election.
  • Outlines ballot drop box drop off requirements, along with general dropbox requirements.
  • Removes official postmark and postal service barcode requirements for return envelopes for absentee ballots.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Outlines affidavit signature requirements and actions if the signature is missing or if the envelope is otherwise incomplete.
  • Outlines record keeping and reporting requirements for absentee ballots.
  • Outlines actions to be taken when receiving an absentee ballot application from a hospital, assisted living facility, or health facility, including deadline requirements.
  • Requires the absentee and special voter precinct board to reconcile affidavits and ballots at the conclusion of each meeting, along with related requirements, reporting requirements, and actions.
  • Outlines requirements for an absentee ballot to be counted.
  • Adds a reason that an elected or appointed official may be removed by a court.
  • Requires appointments to fill a vacancy be for the period until the next general election, with certain petition guidelines.
  • Removes the requirement that a special election not be held on the same day as a school election.
  • Requires the county attorney to bring actions for failure to pay fines and not dismissed.
  • Requires the treasurer to provide polling place hours and election days when sending tax statements.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows special elections to be additionally held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November.
  • Requires the proposed Constitutional amendment be considered a public measure.
  • Allows election officials to hold a second elected office if 30 days or less remain in the term of the first office.
  • Authorizes a political party or nonparty political organization to intervene in certain proceedings or court actions to challenge an election provision, including petitioning the court and the authority to appeal.
  • Allows nomination papers on behalf of a candidate to be filed 92-74 days before the election, with the withdrawal deadline no later than 69 days before the election.
  • Requires new deadlines in case of candidate withdrawal or death before an election.
  • Sustains objections when incorrect or incomplete information is submitted for nominating petitions or certificates.
  • Sets new deadlines related to filing objections for nomination petitions or certificates, and withdrawal of candidacy.
  • Requires a likeness of the county seal to appear on ballots, and requires counties to have only one official seal.
  • Amends quantities of required signatures for nomination of candidates to county offices.
  • Forbids a commissioner from sending change of address and return cards to voters who will be under 18 years of age on the date of the general election.
  • Requires the commissioner to accept notification of death from the federal social security administration.
  • Allows the state registrar of voters to set the audit schedule within certain parameters.
  • Sets deadlines for the commissioner drawing lots for ballot position. 
  • Requires certain notifications be placed on ballots for presidential elections.
  • Requires the commissioner to summarize constitutional amendments and other public measures. 
  • Sets specific election notification requirements and publication of ballot requirements.
  • Specifies the oath for board members before opening the polls.
  • Requires proof of identity by voters before signing an oath or casting a provisional ballot.
  • Sets a new timeline for certification of sample ballots.
  • Allows election officials to deliver election results in person at the request of the commissioner conducting the election, and specifies certain required procedures. 
  • Requires write-in candidates receiving fewer than ten votes and not winning the election to be reporting collectively under the heading "scattering."
  • Requires the state commissioner to order an audit before every election.
  • Requires voters to date their absentee ballot request form.
  • Outlines circumstances in which a satellite absentee voting station may be rejected, and exceptions.
  • Requires the state commissioner to create an application where a voter can track his or her absentee ballot and absentee ballot request form by February 26, 2024, and requires specific information be included.
  • Specifies rules related to the lawful and unlawful return of an absentee ballot. 
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Specifies compensation for presidential electors.
  • Requires new deadlines for hospital trustees.

S.J. 555.","03/09/2021 - Point of order raised on S-3057, ruled in order. S.J. 560.","03/09/2021 - Amendment S-3057 adopted. S.J. 561.","03/09/2021 - Passed Senate, yeas 30, nays 17. H.J. 920.","05/20/2021 - Rereferred to State Government. H.J. 1203."]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows the state commissioner of elections to exercise emergency powers within 15 days of the election.
  • Removes the requirement that emergency powers be approved by the legislative council and other related requirements.
  • Removes requirements related to the number of polling places in an emergency.
  • Authorizes the general assembly or legislative council to rescind the emergency order, providing for effective dates.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Provides emergency election procedures, including notification requirements, election method modification procedures, approval requirements, polling place location requirements, date change guidelines, voting process modifications, absentee ballot requirements, tabulation process requirements, procedures for closing polling locations on election day, ballot transportation and storage requirements, record keeping procedures, procedures for federal elections versus state elections, errors in the conduct of elections in emergency procedures, and conducting repeat elections.

HISTORY: ["03/01/2021 - By COMMITTEE ON STATE GOVERNMENT","03/01/2021 - Introduced, referred to State Government.","03/01/2021 - Subcommittee: Smith, R., Cournoyer, and Jochum.","03/02/2021 - Subcommittee Meeting: 03/03/2021 10:30AM RM 111.","03/03/2021 - Senate  (10:30 3/3/2021 )","03/03/2021 - Subcommittee recommends passage.","03/04/2021 - Senate State Government (13:00 3/4/2021 Senate Chamber)","03/04/2021 - Committee report approving bill, renumbered as SF 568."]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows special elections to be additionally held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November.
  • Requires the proposed Constitutional amendment be considered a public measure.
  • Allows election officials to hold a second elected office if 30 days or less remain in the term of the first office.
  • Allows nomination papers on behalf of a candidate to be filed 92-74 days before the election, with the withdrawal deadline no later than 69 days before the election.
  • Requires new deadlines in case of candidate withdrawal or death before an election, and new deadlines for candidates designated to fill a vacancy on a ballot.
  • Sustains objections when incorrect or incomplete information is submitted for nominating petitions or certificates.
  • Sets new deadlines related to filing objections for nomination petitions or certificates, and withdrawal of candidacy.
  • Sets new deadlines for filling a candidate vacancy.
  • Requires the commissioner to accept notification of death from the federal social security administration.
  • Sets deadlines for the commissioner drawing lots for ballot position. 
  • Requires certain notifications be placed on ballots for presidential elections.
  • Requires the commissioner to summarize constitutional amendments and other public measures. 
  • Sets notification and other requirements for public measures related to the issuance of bonds.
  • Sets specific election notification requirements and publication of ballot requirements.
  • Specifies the oath for board members before opening the polls.
  • Requires proof of identity by voters before signing an oath or casting a provisional ballot.
  • Sets a new timeline for certification of sample ballots.
  • Allows election officials to deliver election results in person at the request of the commissioner conducting the election, and specifies certain required procedures. 
  • Requires return of the election register by a precinct official who did not deliver the election results in person.
  • Requires the commissioner to send messengers for missing tally lists on the night of the election.
  • Requires write-in candidates receiving fewer than ten votes and not winning the election to be reporting collectively under the heading "scattering."
  • Requires the state commissioner to order an audit before every election.
  • Requires the state commissioner to create an application where a voter can track his or her absentee ballot and absentee ballot request form by February 26, 2024, and requires specific information be included.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Specifies compensation for presidential electors.
  • Requires new deadlines for hospital trustees.

  • Requires a likeness of the county seal to appear on ballots, and requires counties to have only one official seal.

HISTORY: ["02/16/2021 - By COMMITTEE ON STATE GOVERNMENT","02/16/2021 - Introduced, referred to State Government.","02/16/2021 - Subcommittee: Smith, R., Celsi, and Cournoyer.","02/23/2021 - Subcommittee Meeting: 02/25/2021 11:15AM RM 111.","02/25/2021 - Senate  (11:15 2/25/2021 )","02/25/2021 - Subcommittee recommends passage.","03/02/2021 - Senate State Government (14:30 3/2/2021 Senate Chamber)","03/02/2021 - Committee report approving bill, renumbered as SF 531."]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows the state commissioner of elections to exercise emergency powers within 15 days of the election.
  • Removes the requirement that emergency powers be approved by the legislative council and other related requirements.
  • Removes requirements related to the number of polling places in an emergency.
  • Authorizes the general assembly or legislative council to rescind the emergency order, providing for effective dates.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Provides emergency election procedures, including notification requirements, election method modification procedures, approval requirements, polling place location requirements, date change guidelines, voting process modifications, absentee ballot requirements, tabulation process requirements, procedures for closing polling locations on election day, ballot transportation and storage requirements, record keeping procedures, procedures for federal elections versus state elections, errors in the conduct of elections in emergency procedures, and conducting repeat elections.

H.J. 541.","02/24/2021 - Amendment H-1117 to amendment H-1107 filed, adopted. H.J. 541.","02/24/2021 - Amendment H-1107 adopted, as amended. H.J. 541.","02/24/2021 - Amendment H-1109 lost. H.J. 542.","02/24/2021 - Amendment H-1111 withdrawn. H.J. 542.","02/24/2021 - SF 413 substituted. H.J. 542.","02/24/2021 - Withdrawn. H.J. 545."]
BILLSUMMARY:
This bill adds ways election officials can fail in their duties including disregarding or hindering the law and inadequate voter list maintenance. This bill prohibits election officials serving as a member of the challenging committee while also serving as a precinct official at the polls, making it a third degree misconduct charge. This bill also makes interfering with a person permitted at a polling place a third degree misconduct charge. This bill classifies the following as election misconduct: return of an absentee ballot to a drop box by a person prohibited from collecting and delivering completed absentee ballots, and making a false statement reporting that an absentee ballot was returned to a drop box by a person prohibited from delivering ballots. This bill required that a state commissioner impose a fine of $10,000 or less upon a technical infraction by a county commissioner and outlines the process of paying the fine and possible suspension. This bill requires the state commissioner to immediately inform the attorney general and relevant county attorney if a technical infraction may constitute election misconduct. This bill requires the attorney general to investigate allegations of election misconduct reported to him or her, or to the county attorney and requires certain related actions. This bill requires nomination papers in partisan nominations be signed by eligible electors. 

This bill requires nonparty political organizations to have a minimum of 500 eligible electors at its convention or caucus to nominate candidates for statewide office, 200 eligible electors for US representative, 20 eligible electors for county or city office, 25 eligible electors for representative in the general assembly, and 50 eligible electors for a state senatorial district. This bill also states a candidate who has been nominated under a political party is not eligible for a nonparty nomination for the same office in the same election year. This bill requires nomination petitions for candidates for US Senator, President, Vice President, Governor, and Lieutenant Governor be signed by at least 3,500 eligible voters with at least 100 of the voters coming from at least 19 counties. This bill also states that nomination petitions for other statewide offices must be signed by at least 2,500 eligible voters including at least 77 from at least 18 counties. This bill requires nomination petitions for US House of Representatives be signed by at least 1,726 eligible voters with at least 47 voters from at least one-half of the counties in the district. This bill further makes changes to the number of signatories on nomination petitions for county-wide office, county supervisor, city offices, and special charter city offices. 

This bill allows the state commissioner of elections to issue guidance to clarify election laws. This bill clarifies that the county commissioner of elections doe not have home rule powers related to the conduct of elections. This bill outlines quarterly voter verification, reporting, and report publication requirements for the state registrar and allows the registrar to pursue related third party vendor contracts. This bill also requires the state registrar to use information from the Electronic Registration Information Center to update voter information. This bill requires each commissioner to update registration information using specific guidelines, and follow specific reporting requirements. This bill allows for a voter registration to be canceled if the voters registration record has been inactive for two successive general elections. This bill outlines certain procedures and rules for the state registrar to conduct an audit. This bill allows the state commissioner or their designee to oversee activities of county election commissioners under certain circumstances, defining "oversee." This bill specifies a person serving on a precinct election board who changes political party within 30 days of an election will be immediately removed from the board. This bill specifies that a voter may choose anyone to assist them in voting, except someone whose name is on the ballot. This bill prohibits an election official or county commissioner from obstructing or interfering with a person's role or duty and specifies penalties. This bill allows members of law enforcement to take "all reasonable actions" to prevent election violations. This bill allows voters to apply for absentee ballots no more than 70 days before the election and specifies when a commissioner may not sent an absentee ballot. This bill specifies that absentee ballot applications may not have prefilled fields, except type and date of election. This bill specifies requirements for commissioners in handling absentee ballot applications arriving at certain times, and specifies reporting requirements for absentee ballots. This bill specifies that absentee ballots must include a statement that they may be returned to certain drop boxes under certain conditions. This bill prohibits election officials from mailing an absentee ballot to anyone not submitting an application. This bill requires a commissioner to provide absentee in-person voting no more than 18 days before an election, and to create satellite absentee voting stations when receiving a petition meeting certain requirements. This bill removes the postmark requirement for return absentee envelopes and relies on a postal service barcode. This bill outlines requirements for handling return absentee envelopes including drop box requirements, deadlines, security, accessibility, retrieval of ballots, and processing. This bill defines relevant terms. This bill specifies processes for voter affidavits lacking specific requirements and outlines requirements. This bill specifies information required for record keeping of absentee ballots by the commissioner. This bill specifies requirements for if a voter is hospitalized after the deadline for a written application for an absentee ballot and how to return the ballot. This bill specifies requirements for handling, recording, and reporting on signed affidavits and reconciling them with the number of ballots counted. This bill specifies who may return a completed absentee ballot. This bill specifies that an appointed or elective officer may be removed by impeachment for failure to pay a fine. This bill requires vacancy appointments by the board of supervisors be until the next general elections and requires if a petition is circulated and filed within 14 days of the publication only to be valid of the signature is dated prior to the date the appointment was made. This bill removes the provision that a special election not be held on the same day as a school election. This bill provides for the county attorney bringing actions for failure to pay fines.

HISTORY: ["02/16/2021 - Introduced, referred to State Government. S.J. 356.","02/23/2021 - Subcommittee: R. Smith, Cournoyer, and Jochum. S.J. 445."]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes the makeup of a recount board, based upon county population size.
  • Authorizes the recount board to oversee the recount.
  • Allows the recount board to conduct the recount, or allows them to direct the county commissioner and staff to conduct the recount, and amends related legislation.
  • Allows the recount board to re-tabulate ballots using the automatic tabulating equipment on a per precinct basis, and requires the board to examine each ballot the equipment identifies as containing an undervote, overvote, or write-in.
  • Requires two-thirds of the recount board to sign the written report.
  • Requires the commissioner to mail absentee ballots up to 45 days before an election, or the next day that is not a holiday.
  • Requires the commissioner to facilitate absentee in-person voting and satellite absentee voting up to 45 days before an election.

HISTORY: ["02/16/2021 - By COMMITTEE ON STATE GOVERNMENT","02/16/2021 - Introduced, referred to State Government. H.J. 437.","02/16/2021 - Subcommittee: Kaufmann, Boden, Mascher, Nordman and Wolfe. H.J. 439.","02/16/2021 - Subcommittee Meeting: Upon adjournment of House Chamber Law Library.","02/17/2021 - House  (17:30 2/17/2021 )","02/18/2021 - Committee report, recommending passage. H.J. 491.","02/18/2021 - Committee report approving bill, renumbered as HF 590."]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Adds ways election officials can fail in their duties including disregarding or hindering the law and inadequate voter list maintenance. 
  • Prohibits election officials serving as a member of the challenging committee while also serving as a precinct official at the polls, making it a third degree misconduct charge. 
  • Makes interfering with a person permitted at a polling place a third degree misconduct charge. 
  • Classifies the following as election misconduct: return of an absentee ballot to a drop box by a person prohibited from collecting and delivering completed absentee ballots, and making a false statement reporting that an absentee ballot was returned to a drop box by a person prohibited from delivering ballots. 
  • Requires a state commissioner impose a fine of $10,000 or less upon a technical infraction by a county commissioner and outlines the process of paying the fine and possible suspension. 
  • Requires the state commissioner to immediately inform the attorney general and relevant county attorney if a technical infraction may constitute election misconduct. 
  • Requires the attorney general to investigate allegations of election misconduct reported to him or her, or to the county attorney and requires certain related actions. 
  • Requires nomination papers in partisan nominations be signed by eligible electors. 
  • Requires nonparty political organizations to have a minimum of 500 eligible electors at its convention or caucus to nominate candidates for statewide office, 200 eligible electors for US representative, 20 eligible electors for county or city office, 25 eligible electors for representative in the general assembly, and 50 eligible electors for a state senatorial district. 
  • Makes a candidate who has been nominated under a political party ineligible for a nonparty nomination for the same office in the same election year. 
  • Requires nomination petitions for candidates for US Senator, President, Vice President, Governor, and Lieutenant Governor be signed by at least 3,500 eligible voters with at least 100 of the voters coming from at least 19 counties. Nomination petitions for other statewide offices must be signed by at least 2,500 eligible voters including at least 77 from at least 18 counties. Nomination petitions for US House of Representatives be signed by at least 1,726 eligible voters with at least 47 voters from at least one-half of the counties in the district. 
  • Changes to the number of signatories on nomination petitions for county-wide office, county supervisor, city offices, and special charter city offices. 
  • Allows the state commissioner of elections to issue guidance to clarify election laws. 
  • Clarifies that the county commissioner of elections does not have home rule powers related to the conduct of elections. 
  • Outlines quarterly voter verification, reporting, and report publication requirements for the state registrar and allows the registrar to pursue related third party vendor contracts. 
  • Requires the state registrar to use information from the Electronic Registration Information Center to update voter information. 
  • Requires each commissioner to update registration information using specific guidelines, and follow specific reporting requirements. 
  • Provides for electronic records to include a status code designating whether records are active and specifies actions to be taken for inactive records.
  • Allows for a voter registration to be canceled if the voters registration record has been inactive for two successive general elections, and establishes certain reporting requirements.  
  • Outlines certain procedures and rules for the state registrar to conduct an audit. 
  • Allows the state commissioner or their designee to oversee activities of county election commissioners under certain circumstances, defining "oversee." 
  • Specifies a person serving on a precinct election board who changes political party within 30 days of an election will be immediately removed from the board. 
  • Allows a voter to choose anyone to assist them in voting, except someone whose name is on the ballot. 
  • Prohibits an election official or county commissioner from obstructing or interfering with a person's role or duty and specifies penalties. 
  • Allows members of law enforcement to take "all reasonable actions" to prevent election violations. 
  • Allows voters to apply for absentee ballots no more than 70 days before the election and specifies when a commissioner may not send an absentee ballot, and in the event of a public health disaster allows the general assembly to require the state commissioner to send an absentee ballot application to each registered voter. 
  • Specifies that absentee ballot applications may not have prefilled fields, except type and date of election. 
  • Specifies requirements for commissioners in handling absentee ballot applications arriving at certain times, and specifies reporting requirements for absentee ballots. 
  • Specifies timelines for mailing out absentee ballots.
  • Requires information to the voter that an absentee ballot may be returned to certain drop boxes under certain conditions. 
  • Prohibits election officials from mailing an absentee ballot to anyone not submitting an application. 
  • Requires a commissioner to provide absentee in-person voting no more than 18 days before an election, and to create satellite absentee voting stations when receiving a petition meeting certain requirements. 
  • Removes the postmark requirement for return absentee envelopes and relies on a postal service barcode instead. 
  • Outlines requirements for handling return absentee envelopes including drop box requirements, deadlines, security, accessibility, retrieval of ballots, and processing. 
  • Defines relevant terms. 
  • Specifies processes for voter affidavits lacking specific requirements and outlines requirements. 
  • Specifies information required for record keeping of absentee ballots by the commissioner. 
  • Outlines requirements for if a voter is hospitalized after the deadline for a written application for an absentee ballot and how to return the ballot. 
  • Specifies requirements for handling, recording, and reporting on signed affidavits and reconciling them with the number of ballots counted. 
  • Outlines who may return a completed absentee ballot. 
  • Clarifies that an appointed or elective officer may be removed by impeachment for failure to pay a fine. 
  • Requires vacancy appointments by the board of supervisors be until the next general elections and requires if a petition is circulated and filed within 14 days of the publication only to be valid of the signature is dated prior to the date the appointment was made. 
  • Removes the provision that a special election not be held on the same day as a school election. 
  • Provides for the county attorney bringing action for failure to pay fines.

HISTORY: ["02/07/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","02/08/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs","02/14/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 2/14/2022 Room EW40)","02/15/2022 - Reported out of Committee with Do Pass Recommendation, Filed for Second Reading","02/16/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","02/17/2022 - U.C. to hold place on third reading calendar one legislative day","02/18/2022 - U.C. to hold place on third reading calendar until Monday, February 21, 2022","02/21/2022 - U.C. to hold place on third reading calendar one legislative day","02/22/2022 - Read Third Time in Full -- PASSED 51-15-4","02/22/2022 - Title apvd","02/22/2022 - to Senate","02/23/2022 - Received from the House passed; filed for first reading","02/23/2022 - Introduced, read first time; referred to: State Affairs","03/02/2022 - Senate State Affairs Committee (08:00 3/2/2022 Room WW55)","03/03/2022 - Reported out of Committee with Do Pass Recommendation; Filed for second reading","03/04/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","03/11/2022 - Read third time in full -- PASSED 29-3-3","03/11/2022 - Title apvd","03/11/2022 - to House","03/14/2022 - Returned from Senate Passed; to JRA for Enrolling","03/15/2022 - Reported Enrolled; Signed by Speaker; Transmitted to Senate","03/15/2022 - Received from the House enrolled/signed by Speaker","03/15/2022 - Signed by President; returned to House","03/16/2022 - Returned Signed by the President; Ordered Transmitted to Governor","03/17/2022 - Delivered to Governor at 10:35 a.m. on March 16, 2022","03/22/2022 - Reported Signed by Governor on March 21, 2022 Session Law Chapter 81 Effective: 03/21/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Specifies procedures for if a voter claims a homestead exemption.
  • Provides provisions for investigating a candidates qualification for office.
  • Requires a declaration of candidacy include a sworn verification that the candidate satisfies legal qualifications for office, including disclosure of the homestead exemption.
  • Requires the state tax commission to disclose information about an improper claim for homestead exemption to the county clerk and secretary of state, who are to use it to determine a person's voting residence. 
  • Requires the state tax commission to establish a searchable database of active homestead exemptions accessible to relevant officials.

HISTORY: ["02/04/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","02/07/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs","02/10/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 2/10/2022 Room EW40)","02/17/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 2/17/2022 Room EW40)","02/17/2022 - Reported out of Committee with Do Pass Recommendation, Filed for Second Reading","02/18/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","02/21/2022 - U.C. to hold place on third reading calendar one legislative day","02/22/2022 - U.C. to hold place on third reading calendar one legislative day","02/23/2022 - Read Third Time in Full -- PASSED 69-0-1","02/23/2022 - Title apvd","02/23/2022 - to Senate","02/24/2022 - Received from the House passed; filed for first reading","02/24/2022 - Introduced, read first time; referred to: State Affairs","03/02/2022 - Senate State Affairs Committee (08:00 3/2/2022 Room WW55)","03/03/2022 - Reported out of Committee with Do Pass Recommendation; Filed for second reading","03/04/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","03/11/2022 - Read third time in full -- PASSED 33-0-2","03/11/2022 - Title apvd","03/11/2022 - to House","03/14/2022 - Returned from Senate Passed; to JRA for Enrolling","03/15/2022 - Reported Enrolled; Signed by Speaker; Transmitted to Senate","03/15/2022 - Received from the House enrolled/signed by Speaker","03/15/2022 - Signed by President; returned to House","03/16/2022 - Returned Signed by the President; Ordered Transmitted to Governor","03/17/2022 - Delivered to Governor at 10:35 a.m. on March 16, 2022","03/21/2022 - Reported Signed by Governor on March 18, 2022 Session Law Chapter 73 Effective: 07/01/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines a procedure for judicial review of election results, including timetable and notifications.
  • Outlines district court roles and powers in the case of juridical review of an election.

HISTORY: ["03/10/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","03/10/2022 - Reported Printed; Filed for Second Reading","03/11/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","03/14/2022 - Read Third Time in Full -- PASSED 47-21-2","03/14/2022 - Title apvd","03/14/2022 - to Senate","03/15/2022 - Received from the House passed; filed for first reading","03/15/2022 - Introduced, read first time; referred to: State Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines acceptable forms of identification for registering to vote, including for proof of identity and proof of citizenship.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain a voter registration website.
  • Specifies requirements for verification of online and mailed registration in certain circumstances.
  • Specifies individuals using the federal voter registration form, not providing identification required by Idaho law, will only be eligible to vote for federal office.
  • Specifies required information for a voter registration oath or affirmation.
  • Creates and funds an election integrity fund.
  • Specifies that certain code must be followed regarding acceptable personal identification at the polls.
  • Specifies all records to be retained for five years after an election.
  • Requires voter registration through the department of motor vehicles include proof of citizenship.
  • Requires drivers licenses or identification cards of US citizens have a notation "USA" included on the license.
  • Requires the motor vehicle department to keep records of the proof relied upon to determine citizenship status of an applicant.
  • Requires the motor vehicles department to issue a free identification card under certain circumstances and requires the applicant to submit proof of citizenship, identity, and date of birth.

HISTORY: ["03/04/2022 - Introduced; read first time; referred to JR for Printing","03/07/2022 - Reported Printed; referred to State Affairs","03/11/2022 - Senate State Affairs Committee (08:00 3/11/2022 Room WW55)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires proof of US citizenship when registering to vote.
  • Outlines provisions for individuals who cannot provide proof of identity, residence, or citizenship.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain an electronic system for voter registration and includes proof of US citizenship in required documents.
  • Requires those registering electronically, or by mail, to vote in-person at least once before being able to vote absentee, with certain exceptions.
  • Outlines required identification for mail-in registration and registration applications.
  • Removes provisions related to unaffiliated party affiliation.
  • Outlines certain requirements for absentee ballot applications.
  • Removes the possibility of electronic transmission of completed absentee ballots.
  • Outlines content requirements for the absentee ballot return envelope.
  • Requires the absentee ballot be returned by mail or delivered personally by hand.
  • Aligns rules regarding voter identification at the polls.
  • Requires a voter without proper identification to complete an affidavit on a secure envelope, place his or her ballot in the envelope, and return to the polling place within two business days with proper identification. 
  • Provides instructions to the clerk in the case of a provisional ballot.



  • Removes provisions related to voter registration including where a registration may be delivered and provisions related to unaffiliated voter registration and voting.
  •  and includes a list of acceptable forms of identification when registering.
  • Provides that a first time voter registrant using the federal application form who did not provide voter identification required by Idaho law will only be eligible to vote in federal races.
  • Includes all information required under oath for voter registration.
  • Provides for a provisional ballot when a voter lacks proper identification and outlines administrative actions to be taken with the provisional ballot.
  • Removes student identification cards as acceptable identification at the polls. 
  • Requires certain county records be maintain for five years, adding provisional ballot envelopes to the list.
  • Removes election day registration from early absentee voting rules.

HISTORY: ["02/04/2022 - Introduced; read first time; referred to JR for Printing","02/07/2022 - Reported Printed; referred to State Affairs","02/09/2022 - Senate State Affairs Committee (08:00 2/9/2022 Room WW55)","02/09/2022 - Reported out of Committee with Do Pass Recommendation; Filed for second reading","02/10/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","02/17/2022 - Read third time in full -- PASSED 35-0-0","02/17/2022 - Title apvd","02/17/2022 - to House","02/18/2022 - Received from the Senate, Filed for First Reading","02/18/2022 - Read First Time, Referred to State Affairs","02/24/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 2/24/2022 Room EW40)","02/25/2022 - Reported out of Committee with Do Pass Recommendation, Filed for Second Reading","02/28/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","03/01/2022 - U.C. to hold place on third reading calendar one legislative day","03/02/2022 - Read Third Time in Full -- PASSED 69-0-1","03/02/2022 - Title apvd","03/02/2022 - to Senate","03/03/2022 - Returned From House Passed; referred to enrolling","03/03/2022 - Reported enrolled; signed by President; to House for signature of Speaker","03/04/2022 - Received from Senate; Signed by Speaker; Returned to Senate","03/07/2022 - Reported signed by the Speaker & ordered delivered to Governor","03/11/2022 - Session Law Chapter 32 Effective: 03/11/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Specifies that stored ballots may be unsealed and resealed as part of a post election audit.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to identify and order a post election audit of certain paper ballots cast in any election, with notification requirements.
  • Specifies procedures related to the post election audit.
  • Specifies which elections may be audited and how precincts may be chosen for audit. 
  • Allows the Secretary of State to select certain ballots from early and absentee ballot voting for an audit.
  • Allows the Secretary of State to conduct the audit and requires the county clerk to facilitate it.
  • Specifies procedures for the audit, including who may attend it, the timetable, notifications, observers, reporting, costs and payment, and follow up.

HISTORY: ["01/17/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","01/18/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs","03/07/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:30 3/7/2022 Room EW40)","03/10/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 3/10/2022 Room EW40)","03/11/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 3/11/2022 Room EW40)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines procedures for providing assistance to voters in certain facilities when assistance is requested for absentee voting, including training, personnel, and who may assist a voter.
  • Specifies that attempting to influence a voter when providing absentee ballot assistance is a misdemeanor crime.

HISTORY: ["02/28/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","03/01/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs","03/02/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 3/2/2022 Room EW40)","03/03/2022 - Reported out of Committee with Do Pass Recommendation, Filed for Second Reading","03/04/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","03/07/2022 - Read Third Time in Full","03/07/2022 - U.C. to be returned to State Affairs Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Amends which records need to be kept for five years after an election.
  • Lists approved identification for election day registration, including providing proof of US citizenship.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain a voter registration website.
  • Stipulates rules for verification for uniformed and overseas citizens voting absentee.
  • Stipulates requirements for mail in registration identification.
  • Specifies individuals using the federal voter registration form, not providing identification required by Idaho law, will only be eligible to vote for federal office.
  • Specifies required information for a voter registration oath or affirmation.
  • Establishes and funds an election integrity fund.
  • Stipulates required forms of identification at the polls.
  • Requires voter registration through the department of motor vehicles include proof of citizenship.
  • Requires drivers licenses or identification cards of US citizens have a notation "USA" included on the license.
  • Requires the motor vehicle department to keep records of the proof relied upon to determine citizenship status of an applicant.
  • Requires the motor vehicles department to issue a free identification card under certain circumstances and requires the applicant to submit proof of citizenship, identity, and date of birth.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","01/14/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs","02/10/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 2/10/2022 Room EW40)","02/14/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 2/14/2022 Room EW40)","02/15/2022 - Reported out of Committee with Do Pass Recommendation, Filed for Second Reading","02/16/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","02/17/2022 - U.C. to hold place on third reading calendar one legislative day","02/18/2022 - U.C. to hold place on third reading calendar until Monday, February 21, 2022","02/21/2022 - Read Third Time in Full -- PASSED 36-32-2","02/21/2022 - Title apvd","02/21/2022 - to Senate","02/22/2022 - Received from the House passed; filed for first reading","02/22/2022 - Introduced, read first time; referred to: State Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Removes provisions for affiliating with a party as an unaffiliated elector.

HISTORY: ["02/21/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","02/22/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs","02/24/2022 - House State Affairs Committee (09:00 2/24/2022 Room EW40)","02/25/2022 - Reported out of Committee with Do Pass Recommendation, Filed for Second Reading","02/28/2022 - Read second time; Filed for Third Reading","03/01/2022 - U.C. to hold place on third reading calendar one legislative day","03/02/2022 - Read Third Time in Full -- PASSED 54-15-1","03/02/2022 - Title apvd","03/02/2022 - to Senate","03/03/2022 - Received from the House passed; filed for first reading","03/03/2022 - Introduced, read first time; referred to: State Affairs","03/21/2022 - Senate State Affairs Committee (08:00 3/21/2022 Room WW55)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Directs that the term of incumbent trustees elected as of July 1, 2018 will expire January 1 following the November election.
  • Requires the election date for the recall of a school district trustee follow Idaho Code.
  • Outlines procedures, including timelines, for filling a vacancy or vacancies on the school board of trustees, including possibly appointing temporary trustees.

HISTORY: ["02/07/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","02/08/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes provisions related to voter registration including where a registration may be delivered and provisions related to unaffiliated voter registration and voting.
  • Requires proof of US citizenship when registering to vote and includes a list of acceptable forms of identification when registering.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain an electronic system for voter registration and provides instructions for verifying a current address for electronic submissions.
  • Provides that a first time voter registrant using the federal application form who did not provide voter identification required by Idaho law will only be eligible to vote in federal races.
  • Includes all information required under oath for voter registration.
  • Provides for a provisional ballot when a voter lacks proper identification and outlines administrative actions to be taken with the provisional ballot.
  • Removes student identification cards as acceptable identification at the polls. 
  • Requires certain county records be maintain for five years, adding provisional ballot envelopes to the list.
  • Removes election day registration from early absentee voting rules.

HISTORY: ["01/28/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","01/31/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to Ways & Means"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Allows stored ballots to be unsealed by order of Secretary of State or the county clerk when there is a challenge by a candidate or organization affiliated with a ballot measure, or for a recount.

HISTORY: ["01/24/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","01/25/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to Ways & Means"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows electronic voter registration applications from the transportation department.
  • Requires the transportation department to register each eligible voter who applies for a drivers license or identity card.
  • Requires the drivers license office to forward completed registration applications weekly and on the business day prior to registration closing.
  • Requires the division of motor vehicles to provide for an elector to drop out of registration.

HISTORY: ["01/20/2022 - Introduced; read first time; referred to JR for Printing","01/21/2022 - Reported Printed; referred to State Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines terms including "nonpartisan primary election," "precinct captain election," "presidential primary," "ranked choice voting."
  • Outlines the method to be used for ranked choice voting and rules for counting ballots using the method.
  • Removes provisions for unaffiliated voters in primary elections by mail.
  • Requires unaffiliated voters to declare which precinct captain or presidential primary election ballot they wish to vote and aligns relevant rules.
  • Establishes that for nonpartisan primaries, every voter will receive the same ballot.
  • Specifies an elector may change political party affiliation for precinct caption and presidential primary elections within certain guidelines. 
  • Removes certain requirements for write in candidates in nonpartisan primaries.
  • Clarifies that nonpartisan primary elections determine four candidates to appear on the general election ballot, not based upon party.
  • Clarifies that candidates for judicial office will be nominated at the judicial nominating election.
  • Specifies declaration of candidacy rules for nonpartisan primary elections.
  • Specifies with which office each level of candidate needs to file candidacy.
  • Specifies the procedure for notifying parties of declared candidates affiliated with the party.
  • Amends certification of candidate procedures by the Secretary of State. 
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide a sample form for presidential primaries, nonpartisan primary elections, and precinct captain races to each county clerk.
  • Requires the county clerk to prepare a sample primary and precinct captain ballot for upcoming elections, including names of all candidates.
  • Specifies procedures and timelines for filling vacancies in nonpartisan primary races and precinct captain elections.
  • Specifies procedures for filling vacancies for nonpartisan judicial races.
  • Amends administrative procedures for withdrawal of candidacy.
  • Requires presidential primary elections to be conducted by laws governing elections for federal office in a general election.
  • Allows candidates for precinct captain to seek one additional office in a nonpartisan primary election.
  • Outlines requirements for primary nonpartisan election ballots and precinct captain election ballots.
  • Adds precinct captain elections to rules for eligibility to vote in presidential primary elections, and rules for absentee ballot applications and issuance of absentee ballots.
  • Outlines rules for what must be printed on ballots for the general election.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and disseminate widely voter education materials for nonpartisan primary elections, and general elections at least 60 days before the election.
  • Removes certain requirements on absentee ballot applications related to unaffiliated voters.   
  • Outlines rules and procedures for certificate of nomination for nonpartisan primary elections and precinct captain elections.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2022 - Introduced, read first time, referred to JRA for Printing","01/14/2022 - Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires incumbent trustees elected after July 1, 2018 terms to expire January 1 after the November election.
  • Requires the election date of a recall election for school board trustee to be determined by Idaho Code.
  • Outlines provisions for filling a vacancy in the case of a recall or resignation of a board of trustees member(s), including the timeline and temporary appointments.

HISTORY: ["10/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Darren Bailey","10/26/2021 - First Reading","10/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","05/09/2022 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Win Stoller"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a free Voter Identification Card to each registered voter without an acceptable form of photo ID, to be used only for voting.
  • Lists required information items for the ID card.
  • Adds the Voter Identification Card as an acceptable form of photo ID for voting.
  • Allows a provisional voter ten days to provide the required photo ID.

John Connor","01/18/2022 - First Reading","01/18/2022 - Referred to Assignments","01/26/2022 - Assigned to Executive","02/07/2022 - To Executive- Elections","02/10/2022 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments","04/30/2022 - Chief Sponsor Changed to Sen. Don Harmon"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Board to create a downloadable program allowing petition signatures to be collected on electronic devices.
  • Requires the program to be free and made available to all political committees.
  • Sets minimum standards and requirements for the program.
  • Allows the Board to use a third party developer.

HISTORY: ["02/25/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. John Connor","02/25/2021 - First Reading","02/25/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/16/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/16/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Sally J. Turner","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments","04/30/2022 - Chief Sponsor Changed to Sen. Don Harmon"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to design an alternative signature verification method for petition signatures from state advisory referendums.
  • Removes the requirement that a proponent in a statewide advisory referendum file a copy of the petition with each proper election authority.
  • Allows registered proponents and opponents of proposed amendments to certain articles of the state Constitution to observe the sample signature verification process, and to participate in proceedings related to sample signature verification.
  • Allows political parties and civic organizations to participate in the proceedings related to sample signature verification for proposed amendments to certain articles of the state Constitution.

Don Harmon"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines penalties for anyone altering or falsifying information on a report.
  • Defines "public funds."
  • Prohibits the use of public funds to influence a voter regarding a candidate or proposition.
  • Allows the use of public funds for voter information purposes.
  • Outlines penalties for misuse of public funds.
  • Prohibits candidates accepting certain types of contributions and outlines penalties.
  • Prohibits willful failure to file information or falsifying information and outlines penalties.

Brad Halbrook","02/19/2021 - First Reading","02/19/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","03/27/2021 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee","04/08/2022 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Chris Miller"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires a grace period registrant to provide identification with their date of birth.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines deep fake videos.
  • Provides that a person is committing a Class A misdemeanor if the person creates, publishes, and distributes a deep fake video with the intent to injure a candidate or influence the results of an election.

HISTORY: ["01/18/2022 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Ram Villivalam","01/18/2022 - First Reading","01/18/2022 - Referred to Assignments","01/26/2022 - Senate Amendment 001","01/26/2022 - Assigned to Executive","01/26/2022 - Senate Committee Amendment No. 1 Filed with Secretary by Sen. Ram Villivalam","01/26/2022 - Senate Committee Amendment No. 1 Referred to Assignments","02/01/2022 - Senate Committee Amendment No. 1 Assignments Refers to Executive","02/07/2022 - To Executive- Elections","02/07/2022 - Senate Committee Amendment No. 1 To Executive- Elections","02/07/2022 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Emil Jones, III","03/30/2022 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Omar Aquino"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows certain forms from the department of motor vehicles to also be used as voter registration applications, provided the applicant presents identification confirming US citizenship and age, unless the applicant denies the option.
  • Provides that if an applicant to the department of motor vehicles does not submit identification confirming US citizenship and does not indicate the applicant is currently registered to vote in the state, then the application will not be a dual-purpose application.
  • Allows the State Board of Elections to enter into an agreement with certain agencies for the purpose of updating an applicant's existing voter registration record.
  • Allows the agencies to transmit information about clients who may be registered to vote for the sole purpose of updating their registration.
  • Requires the Department of Healthcare and Family Services to implement automatic voter registration for Medicaid applicants by July 1, 2023.
  • Establishes rules for automatic voter registration applications sent without signature.
  • Establishes procedures for automatic voter registration applications received for individuals protected by certain programs designed for confidentiality of victims.
  • Outlines certain notification requirements for individuals who are automatically registered to vote, including declining to register.
  • Makes other conforming changes to election code.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. David A. Welter","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","03/22/2022 - Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Patrick Windhorst","03/22/2022 - Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Paul Jacobs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the posting of uncounted ballot information on a website to also include election judge affidavits.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to establish training materials and guidelines for judges of elections.
  • Requires the county clerk and the Board of Election Commissioners to incorporate guidelines and training materials from the State Board of Elections, including outlining minimum guidelines.
  • Requires election authorities to automatically register a voter whose information is received through the National Change of Address database within 90 days.
  • Requires the county clerk to conduct a verification of voter registrations after elections in odd-numbered years, but before the first day of candidate filing for the following primary election in an even-numbered year.
  • Allows the county clerk to conduct investigations and conduct canvasses of registered voters after elections in odd-numbered years, but before the first day of candidate filing for the following primary election in an even-numbered year.
  • Provides for the county clerk and the Board of Election Commissioners to certify the verification of information to the State Board of Elections.
  • Allows the Board of Election Commissioners to conduct investigations and make canvasses of registered voters after elections in odd-numbered years, but before the first day of candidate filing for the following primary election in an even-numbered year.
  • Requires that if there is a delay of more than five hours in getting tally sheets to the county clerk, that the two designated judges, one from each major political party, create a written affidavit explaining the delay.
  • Requires the affidavit be delivered to the county clerk and be made available to the general public on a website.
  • Requires vote by mail processing procedures be published on a website at least 120 days before an election.
  • Subjects vote by mail ballots arriving after election day to an audit and outlines the procedures, timeline, and scope of the audit.

HISTORY: ["04/21/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Kambium Buckner","04/23/2021 - First Reading","04/23/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee","03/21/2022 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Michael Kelly"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that the rights of any citizen to vote may not be abridged due to race, color, or membership in a language minority group.
  • Establishes what constitutes a violation of the right to vote.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to designate a certain locality a language minority area of certain criteria are met.
  • Requires a locality to provide election materials and notices in the applicable language of the language minority group for designated areas, empowering the attorney general or any qualified minority language group member institute a cause of action in the circuit court to compel provision of materials and notices in the minority language. 
  • Outlines related provisions for the action.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Defines "certification of no objection" and defines "covered practices" included in the enfranchisement of minority voters, which include voting and other changes to voting rules.
  • Requires election authorities to publicize proposed changes to covered practices, giving two options, following certain guidelines and outlining the process of challenging proposed changes.
  • Prohibits an at-large method of election be used if it impairs the ability of a protected class to elect candidates of their choice and outlines violations, actions, and court remedies. 
  • Creates and funds a Voter Outreach and Education Fund whose goal is to educate voters on their voting rights.
  • Outlines an Attorney General's actions when there is reasonable cause to believe there has been a violation of the Election Code affecting rights of voters.
  • Establishes rules for voter assistance in the case of a non-English speaking voter who arrives at the polls without an interpreter.
  • Outlines actions for voters who are intimidated, threatened, or coerced by another person for all elections, selection of nominees, and all voting methods.
  • Outlines penalties and actions for intimidating an election officer.
  • Outlines penalties and actions for communicating false information to a registered voter to impede the voter in exercising his or her right to vote.
  • Outlines penalties and actions for officials committing illegal actions related to voting and carrying out official voting duties.   
  • Outlines penalties and actions for anyone furnishing a ballot to a non-English speaker and misinforming him or her about the content, or making changes to a ballot.

HISTORY: ["01/26/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Kelly M. Cassidy","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee","03/10/2022 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. La Shawn K. Ford"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Excludes nominating, candidate, and referendum petitions from digital signature options.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to adopt rules for collecting digital voter signatures for nominating, candidate, and referendum petitions by January 1, 2024.
  • Specifies rules for electronic devices being used for signature collection.

Dan Ugaste"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a reporting system for election authorities to record returned mail in ballots.
  • Requires election authorities to record the number of mail in ballots received before and after election day, and on election day, and ballots received postmarked after election day.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires five members of the State Board of Education be elected in a nonpartisan election at the general election in 2024 and every four years after.
  • Allows the State Board of Elections to hear and pass upon objections to nominations of candidates for State Board of Education.
  • Requires election authorities to open the returns and make abstracts of the votes for State Board of Education.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to proceed with a canvass after the election for elected members of the State Board of Election.
  • Provides that the State Board of Education should consist of five elected and eight appointed members.
  • Requires one election member from the State Board of Education come from each judicial district for a four year term.  
  • Outlines the petition for nomination process for State Board of Education candidates.
  • Provides vacancy procedures for appointed and elected members.
  • Outlines qualification requirements for candidates for State Board of Education.
  • Defines what constitutes quorum for the Board and what is needed for a vote to pass.

BILLSUMMARY: • Makes non substantive change to the election code.
