BILLSUMMARY: • Requires the election authority to include methods of voting used in unit-by-unit vote totals to the State Board of Elections.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines requirements for the appointment panels of judges to compare signatures on vote by mail ballots.
  • Outlines requirements for comparing signatures.
  • Outlines reasons for rejecting a ballot and procedures in the case of a rejection, including in some cases permitting a voter to cast a new ballot.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a form to be used by election authorities to remove a voter from the roll.
  • Requires the county clerk to issue certifications of death records and use them to cancel registrations.

BILLSUMMARY: • Requires the county clerk to cross check each voter registration roll with the national Change of Address System and update voter information, including removing from the roll information from those who have self removed.

HISTORY: ["01/27/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Edgar Gonzalez, Jr.","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee","02/24/2022 - Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Eva-Dina Delgado"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows certain forms at the department of motor vehicles to also be used as voter registration applications, provided the applicant presents identification confirming US citizenship and age, unless the applicant denies the option.
  • Provides that if an applicant to the department of motor vehicles does not submit identification confirming US citizenship and does not indicate the applicant is currently registered to vote in the state, then the application will not be a dual-purpose application.
  • Allows the State Board of Elections to enter into an agreement with certain agencies for the purpose of updating an applicant's existing voter registration record.
  • Allows the agencies to transmit information about clients who may be registered to vote for the sole purpose of updating their registration.
  • Requires the Department of Healthcare and Family Services to implement automatic voter registration for Medicaid applicants by July 1, 2023.
  • Establishes rules for automatic voter registration applications sent without signature.
  • Establishes procedures for automatic voter registration applications received for individuals protected by certain programs designed for confidentiality of victims.
  • Outlines certain notification requirements for individuals who are automatically registered to vote.
  • Makes other conforming changes to election code.

COAUTHORS: ["Tim Butler","Andrew Chesney","Amy Grant","Mark Luft","Tony McCombie","Chris Miller"]
HISTORY: ["02/17/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Ryan Spain","02/19/2021 - First Reading","02/19/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","03/18/2021 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to use a Voter Identification Card to each registered voter who does not have an acceptable form of photo ID, and includes information required on the card, valid dates, and uses.
  • Clarifies that the General Assembly intends to advise the Secretary of State on how to issue the identification card.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for Voter Identification Cards and provide Cards to any registered voter who qualifies.
  • Lists documents requires for a Voter Identification Card.
  • Provides for exemptions for certain voters.
  • Lists acceptable forms of identification to be able to vote, including the Voter Identification Card.
  • Includes the Voter Identification Card in other related election ID rules.
  • Allows a provisional voter 10 days to provide the proper authority with required photo ID.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Replaces the "State Board of Elections website" with "electronic voter registration portal" in existing legislation.
  • Allows qualified residents to preregister to vote on or after their 16th birthday using the online voter registration system.
  • Outlines related requirements for election authorities in processing the applications.
  • Allows qualified 17-year-olds, who will be 18 by the date of the next election, to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public question.
  • Deems qualified 16-year-olds competent to execute and attest any voter registration forms.

HISTORY: ["01/24/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Terra Costa Howard","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/01/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Removes the requirement that judges initial ballots of those who ordered a vote by mail ballot, but came to the polls in person.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to use a Voter Identification Card to each registered voter who does not have an acceptable form of photo ID, and includes information required on the card, valid dates, and uses.
  • The General Assembly intends to advise the Secretary of State on how to issue the identification card.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for Voter Identification Cards and provide Cards to any registered voter who qualifies.
  • Lists documents requires for a Voter Identification Card.
  • Provides for exemptions for certain voters.
  • Lists acceptable forms of identification to be able to vote, including the Voter Identification Card.
  • Includes the Voter Identification Card in other related election ID rules.
  • Allows a provisional voter 10 days to provide the proper authority with required photo ID.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Katie Stuart","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections within 24 hours of receiving a certificate of nomination, nominations papers, or proposed question, and the objector's petition, to send a call by registered or certified mail to the election authority to whom the ballot is certified, along with others who were previously listed.
  • Establishes that the chair of the election board other than the State Board of Elections will be responsible for having the sheriff serve a copy of the call to each of the designated officers or other individuals.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Katie Stuart","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Allows election authorities to reduce the number of judges in each precinct from five to three.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Katie Stuart","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/09/2022 - Chief Sponsor Changed to Rep. Carol Ammons","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Excludes permanent vote by mail voters from the requirement that a notice of a vote by mail option be sent before an election.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Katie Stuart","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Adds "proposed statewide advisory public questions" to the list of types of hearings the State Electoral Board may conduct in the case of objections to a petition.  
  • Removes provisions specifying requirements for statewide advisory public questions, including petitions and referenda.
  • Removes certain responsibilities from election authorities, including petition signature verification. 
  • Removes certain filing requirements for those submitting a statewide advisory public question.
  • Modifies procedures for valid signature calculation and petition verification watchers.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["02/16/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Deanne M. Mazzochi","02/17/2021 - First Reading","02/17/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","03/27/2021 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee","12/29/2021 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Amy Grant","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires that if judges find a signature on a certificate does not match a signature on a registration card, the voter must provide a valid, approved state identification.
  • Allows that judges may find that signatures do not match if one is in cursive and the other is printed.

HISTORY: ["01/07/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Chris Miller","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Changes the oath for candidates filing for election to include swearing that they are not affiliated with "any socialist organization."

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Katie Stuart","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows County Board with a population over 3 million to divide, adjust, or consolidate election precincts.
  • If it is not practicable for the County Board to change the boundaries of the precincts after the decennial census, they may do so at their next regular June or July meeting.
  • Adds consolidating to the list of options for a County Board in adjusting precincts.
  • If a County Board fails to adjust precincts in the year following the decennial census, then existing districts will continue until the next regular June meeting.

HISTORY: ["12/28/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Charles Meier","12/28/2021 - Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. David Friess","01/05/2022 - First Reading","01/05/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires election authorities to automatically register any voter within 90 days of receipt of information from the National Change of Address database.
  • Requires the county clerk to send notice to appear for a hearing to a juror who the clerk believes is not a qualified voter, and outlines relevant provisions.
  • Requires the county clerk to conduct a verification of voter registrations on a specified timetable.
  • Requires the clerk of the circuit court to notify jury officials of each jury summons returned due to a change of address, and the jury administrator to send local election authorities a list of all such address changes every three months.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Katie Stuart","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/08/2022 - Chief Sponsor Changed to Rep. Carol Ammons","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Expands the requirement that an election authority identify health and safety requirements for a voting location to all elections.

HISTORY: ["02/16/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Chris Miller","02/17/2021 - First Reading","02/17/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","03/27/2021 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee","12/29/2021 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Amy Grant","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a free Voter Identification Card to each registered voter without an acceptable form of photo ID, to be used only for voting.
  • Lists required information items for the ID card.
  • Provides that the General Assembly intends to provide the Secretary of State guidance on how to issue the Voter Identification Card to those without acceptable form of photo ID.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for the Voter Identification Card and establish procedures for identity verification.
  • Lists acceptable forms of ID for voting.
  • Provides religious exemptions and exemptions for indigent individuals.
  • Outlines ID requirements for voters registered by mail.
  • Allows a provisional voter ten days to provide the required photo ID.
  • Aligns other provisions with the new Voter Identification Card rules.

HISTORY: ["01/28/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Tom Weber","01/31/2022 - First Reading","01/31/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires all ballots used in elections to contain an "Illinois State Board of Elections" watermark and to be numbered, prohibiting linkage of the ballot number to a specific voter.

HISTORY: ["08/31/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Mark Batinick","09/03/2021 - First Reading","09/03/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee","10/28/2021 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Thomas M. Bennett","10/28/2021 - Removed Co-Sponsor Rep. Thomas M. Bennett","11/24/2021 - Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Thomas M. Bennett","01/06/2022 - Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Avery Bourne","01/11/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","01/19/2022 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Charles Meier","01/20/2022 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Blaine Wilhour","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Illinois State Police and the State Board of Elections to create an automatic voter registration program for those completing applications related to a Firearm Owners Identification card or a Concealed Carry Permit.
  • Allows the above applications to also serve as a residential address update for voter registration purposes.
  • Requires that the applicant be given an opportunity to decline to register.
  • Requires an attestation by signature that the applicant meets the qualifications to register.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the Illinois State Police related to applications, notifications, information transmission, and qualifications.
  • Provides that a Firearm Owners Identification Card application or concealed carry license application constitute an application to register to vote in Illinois.
  • Defines "dual purpose application."
  • Makes other complying changes.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Katie Stuart","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Allows eligible incapacitated voters to vote by mail or onsite, rather than onsite only.

HISTORY: ["02/17/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Deanne M. Mazzochi","02/18/2021 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Thomas M. Bennett","02/18/2021 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Chris Miller","02/18/2021 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Avery Bourne","02/19/2021 - First Reading","02/19/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","03/27/2021 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires appropriate officials to transmit a death certificate to the county clerk within seven days of the death.
  • Requires the county clerk and coroner to report quarterly to certify full compliance.
  • Allows for any person to request a copy of the report and outlines penalties for not providing the report, including the role of a circuit court judge in compliance and penalties.

HISTORY: ["01/24/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Amy Grant","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires that no voter registration be canceled without following the procedures of the National Voter Registration Act of 1993.
  • Provides for cancelation of a voter registration if a voter becomes inactive by not voting in two consecutive general federal elections, provided National Voter Registration Act procedures are followed, unless the voter acts to restore their name to active voter status.
  • Provides for the cancelation of a voter registration if the voter requests this in writing.
  • Provides for a voter registration to be canceled if the election authority receives notice that the voter is incarcerated in a US, state, or county correctional facility, if the incarceration is the result of a criminal conviction or judgment of conviction.
  • Provides for a voter registration to be canceled if a person has a judgment of conviction for a crime and it is found at the time that the voter lacks the required qualifications to be a registered voter.
  • Provides for a voter registration to be canceled if a certified copy of a final judgment order or a final determination of an administrative tribunal finds that the voter lacks the required qualifications to be a voter. 
  • Provides for a voter registration to be canceled if election authorities receive a voter's death certificate or equivalent.
  • Requires the county clerk to issue a death certificate and requires the clerk to cancel the deceased person's voter registration.

HISTORY: ["01/27/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Ryan Spain","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/10/2022 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Mark Luft","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that recordings of collection sites for vote by mail ballots are public records subject to related laws.
  • Requires collection sites to be established only on public grounds where normal local government business is conducted and where there is no residential component.
  • Requires all collection sites be recorded by security cameras.
  • Requires authorities to retain recordings for 90 days after each election and make recordings available for inspection and copying under FOIA.

HISTORY: ["01/11/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Mark Batinick","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires names of candidates on a ballot to appear in random order, requiring each election district or precinct to choose a different order, as much as mathematically possible.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to follow the randomization requirements for certifying the election.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to choose a software vendor who can conduct the described randomization of names.
  • Requires any software purchased to be used solely for this purpose.

HISTORY: ["01/24/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Dan Caulkins","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Amends the early voting period to end on the Friday immediately before the election, and requires the early voting polling place to stay open until then.

HISTORY: ["01/27/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Keith R. Wheeler","01/31/2022 - First Reading","01/31/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to establish a system for publishing and certifying election results.
  • Requires the county clerk to quarterly confirm that deceased voters and those who moved away are no longer registered to vote in the county.
  • Requires the board of election commissioners to confirm that deceased voters and those who moved away are no longer registered to vote in the municipality.
  • Requires the county clerk to update vote totals at least every 24 hours after Election Day and includes required information.

HISTORY: ["01/24/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Carol Ammons","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Counties & Townships Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the chief elected county board member, when learning of a vacancy in an elective county office, to declare a vacancy exists and notify appropriate officials within three days of the vacancy.
  • Requires the vacancy be filled within 60 days by appointment by the chief elected county board member, with advice and consent of the county board.
  • Defines "county executive form of government" to allow elected members to choose a chief administrative official, speaker, or board chair.

HISTORY: ["01/28/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. David Friess","01/31/2022 - First Reading","01/31/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/09/2022 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","02/18/2022 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Allows the county board or county commissioners in a county with a population less than 100,000 to dissolve a municipal board of election commissioners, by ordinance or resolution, and transfer its functions to the county clerk.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes the date of the general election is the first Tuesday after the first Monday of November in even years.
  • Makes conforming changes to election code.
  • Establishes that colleges, universities, agencies, and community college offices will be closed on general election day.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Creates the Citizen Empowerment Act.
  • Provides for the dissolution of a unit of local government by voters.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Outlines the steps for a petition for a referendum to dissolve a local government unit, including ballot placement.
  • Outlines voting requirements for the referendum.
  • Provides for the transfer of rights and duties with the dissolution of a unit of local government.
  • Includes the Citizen Empowerment Act in other electoral code.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows an election authority to reduce the number of judges of an election in each precinct from five to three for any election.
  • Makes conforming changes to the election code.

BILLSUMMARY: • Requires a candidate to swear they are unaffiliated with hate groups and white supremacist organizations in the candidate oath.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Changes "State Board of Elections website" to "electronic voter registration portal."
  • Allows qualified voters to preregister to vote after their 16th birthday with certain procedures.
  • Requires preregistration to take place using the electronic voter registration portal.
  • Allows 17-year-olds who will be 18 at the time of the next election to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public questions.
  • Establishes that 16-year-olds are deemed competent to execute and attest to any voter registration forms.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "electronic transmission" and "voter with a disability."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to establish a procedure to sent vote by mail ballots electronically to persons with disability so that they can privately mark their ballot using assistive technology.
  • Requires the election authority to transmit a vote by mail ballot for a voter with disability within three business days if the application arrives after the election authority begins transmitting ballots.
  • Requires ballots received and marked to be printed by the voter and returned to the election authority.
  • Allows election authorities to deliver an official ballot electronically in certain instances.
  • Requires an election authority to provide printed slips, or electronic versions for vote by mail, with full instructions for marking the ballot.
  • Requires election authorities to provide voters with electronically transmitted ballots to provide the same instructions, certifications, and balloting materials as for other voters, to the extent possible.

BILLSUMMARY: • Requires election authorities to notify voters of the option for permanent vote by mail status, unless a voter has already applied for permanent vote by mail status, or a voter has submitted a written request to be excluded from permanent vote by mail status.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the County Board in counties with a population over three million to divide, adjust, or consolidate precincts in June each year.
  • Allows the County Board to divide, adjust, or consolidate boundaries of precincts after the decennial census within certain timetables.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "hand-marked paper ballot."
  • Requires election authorities to allow voters to use hand-marked paper ballots, including allowing voters to inspect and verify their vote before casting the ballot.
  • Requires hand marked paper ballots to be counted by hand or read by optical scan technology or another counting method.
  • Requires election judges to advise voters of the opportunity to correct any error on the ballot.
  • Requires ballots be preserved in a way that keeps them anonymous.
  • Establishes hand marked paper ballots as the official ballot, to be preserved and suitable to be used for recount or audit.
  • Requires hand marked paper ballots be the true and correct record of the cast vote if there are inconsistencies with electronic tallies.
  • Provides that if hand marked paper ballots are compromised in sufficient number to change the result of the election, the appropriate remedy should be made in accordance with Electoral Code, and the electronic tally should not be used as the only basis for determining the result.
  • Establishes security measures for voter registration rolls, ballots, ballot boxes, poll lists, poll books, and voting tabulators.
  • Prohibits remote access to electronic devices used in certain voting procedures.

HISTORY: ["01/21/2022 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Julie A. Morrison","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Assignments","02/01/2022 - Assigned to Executive","02/07/2022 - To Executive- Elections","02/10/2022 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Provides that election authorities establish a voting center where all voters in the jurisdiction can vote for all elections.

HISTORY: ["01/21/2022 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Julie A. Morrison","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Assignments","02/01/2022 - Assigned to Executive","02/07/2022 - To Executive- Elections","02/10/2022 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to adopt rules to provide a certified remote accessible vote by mail for voters with disabilities where voters may mark their ballot using assistive technology.
  • Requires election authorities to transmit a vote by mail ballot to a disabled voter within two business days after vote by mail ballots begin being transmitted.
  • Requires voters to print and return ballots received in vote by mail for voters with disabilities.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to adopt rules, including certification standards, for remote accessible vote by mail and a method for voters with disability to request a vote by mail ballot.
  • Defines related terms.
  • Codifies the affirmation for the application for vote by mail ballot for people with disabilities.
  • Requires election authorities to provide applicants for electronic transmission of ballots with the same instructions, certifications, and balloting materials as others sending ballots by mail, to the greatest extent possible.
  • Requires that a duplicate ballot not include the invalid votes appearing on the original ballot.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes non-substantive changes to the election code.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes general election day as a state holiday. 
  • Makes conforming changes to the election code.
  • Requires college, university, agency, and community college offices to be closed on general election day.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the chair of the electoral board, within 24 hours of receipt of an objector's petition, to notify the election authority to whom the ballot is certified, in addition to previously listed offices.
  • Requires the chair of the electoral board (other than the State Board of Elections) to cause the sheriff to serve a copy of the call to each designated officer or person.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that ranked choice voting be used for candidates for General Assembly, Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Attorney General, Secretary of State, Comptroller, and Treasurer during regular and special elections.
  • Outlines ballot content rules for ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines rules for voting a ranked choice ballot.
  • Outlines tallying procedures and rules for ranked choice voting.

HISTORY: ["01/21/2022 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Steve Stadelman","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Assignments","02/01/2022 - Assigned to Executive","02/07/2022 - To Executive- Elections","02/10/2022 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines deep fake videos.
  • Provides that a person is committing a Class A misdemeanor if the person creates, publishes, and distributes a deep fake video with the intent to injure a candidate or influence the results of an election within 30 days of the election.

HISTORY: ["01/12/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Blaine Wilhour","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/01/2022 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Tom Weber"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a free Voter Identification Card to each registered voter without an acceptable form of photo ID, to be used only for voting.
  • Lists required information items for the ID card.
  • Adds the Voter Identification Card as an acceptable form of photo ID for voting.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for the Voter Identification Card and the Secretary of State to adopt procedures for identity verification of registered voters.
  • Provides certain exemptions.
  • Lists acceptable forms of ID for voting.
  • Makes changes to align the election code.
  • Allows a provisional voter ten days to provide the required photo ID.

HISTORY: ["01/28/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Kambium Buckner","01/31/2022 - First Reading","01/31/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Non-substantive change to the Election Code.

HISTORY: ["01/24/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Barbara Hernandez","01/27/2022 - First Reading","01/27/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires each early voting polling place to have sufficient paper ballots for voters who request them.
  • Requires a 10% election day audit of all votes cast for each statewide, countywide, federal, municipal, or other race or proposition on election day, where there is more than 50,000 registered eligible voters.
  • Requires audits to take place as soon as possible after the close of polls at the location where votes are counted, but not interfere with the reporting of election results.
  • Requires the audit be conducted by election judges with staffing requirements laid out in the legislation.
  • Provides for a method for the random selection of ballots and for recording the results of the random selection.
  • Provides a system for examining and recording ballots for the audit.
  • Requires election authorities to create and print an audit summary form before election day listing the races and propositions to be audited, with spaces for recording the results of the audit, and certain other requirements.
  • Outlines requirements for completion of the audit summary form and distribution and publicity of copies of the form. 
  • Requires election authorities to collect all precinct audit reports and create a consolidated report to be published within 24 hours of the polls closing, and requires authorities to certify the election day audit results.
  • Outlines storage and public availability requirements for the audit.
  • Provides that the reports are admissible as evidence as required.
  • Requires a parallel, independent audit be conducted for each race or proposition in each election.
  • Outlines staffing, timeline, and committee composition rules for the audit.
  • Outlines rules for the parallel election tabulation and audit, including request for proposals, timeline, awarding the contracting, funding, contractor qualifications, licensing and bonding requirements, and requires the contractor have access to all records of the election.
  • Outlines requirements for the report submitted by the contractor in the parallel audit including timeline, procedures, certification or non-certification criteria, what should be examined, questions to be answered, and information required. 
  • Clarifies that the parallel election tabulation and audit reports are public property, in the public domain, available under FOIA, and may be posted on a website.
  • Requires the parallel election tabulation and audit reports be admissible as evidence as required.
  • Creates the Illinois Election Integrity Fund as a special fund in the State treasury and clarifies funding mechanisms.
  • Defines "approved independent testing authority."
  • Requires precinct tabulation optical scan technology voting systems to fulfill voluntary provisions and mandatory requirements from proper authorities and to fulfill testing requirements by approved testing authorities.

HISTORY: ["01/12/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Blaine Wilhour","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to develop procedures for conducting audits of affidavit signatures from regular elections, beginning in the general election of 2022.
  • Requires each election authority to randomly select 1% of ballots cast to be audited in accordance with the procedure developed by the State Board of Elections.

HISTORY: ["01/21/2022 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Robert Peters","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Revises information requirements for voter registration record cards.
  • Establishes reasonable costs for voter registration records and data.
  • Prohibits placing voter registration records on the internet with unrestricted access.
  • Lists confidential information from voter registration records.
  • Provides that a government entity or employee or officer will not be held civilly liable for disclosure of information unless it is due to "gross negligence or willfulness."
  • Outlines guidelines for providing voter registration records for election, scholarly, or journalistic purposes.

HISTORY: ["01/12/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Blaine Wilhour","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "change in status," "voter registration database," and "trackable ballot."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to develop and maintain a system to track ballots, including updates of changes.
  • Requires the ballot tracking system to update a voter electronically about any changes.
  • Provides language for consenting to receive notifications.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to update a voter's information in the statewide voter registration database.

HISTORY: ["01/12/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Blaine Wilhour","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a county clerk to use death records to cancel a voter registration.
  • Requires certified death records be sent to the county clerk within seven days of death.
  • Requires the county clerk or coroner to report quarterly to the county board and certify its full compliance.
  • Requires the county clerk to monthly request records of permanent address changes from the Postal Service and update voter records.
  • Establishes that any person can request a copy of the required reports and establishes penalties for failing to provide them, including circuit court jurisdiction, actions, and penalties.

HISTORY: ["01/07/2022 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Chris Bos","01/21/2022 - First Reading","01/21/2022 - Referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a policy concerning chain of custody and secure storage of vote by mail ballots.
  • Requires the policy include: procedures to destroy certain ballots, reporting requirements, and creation of a public database.

HISTORY: ["01/05/2022 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Darren Bailey","01/05/2022 - First Reading","01/05/2022 - Referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to issue a free Voter Identification Card to each registered voter without an acceptable form of photo ID, to be used only for voting.
  • Lists required information items for the ID card.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide application forms for the Voter Identification Card and establish procedures for identity verification.
  • Offers practices for those seeking a religious exemption for the photo ID.
  • Lists acceptable forms of ID for voting.
  • Allows a provisional voter ten days to provide the required photo ID.
  • Aligns other provisions with the new Voter Identification Card rules.

HISTORY: ["01/05/2022 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Darren Bailey","01/05/2022 - First Reading","01/05/2022 - Referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the county clerk to cancel the voter registration of anyone who died in the preceding month.
  • Requires certain qualified individuals to transfer notification of death within seven days to the county clerk.
  • Requires the county clerk to monthly request change of address records from the US Postal Service and update affected voter registrations.
  • Outlines reporting requirements for the county clerk.
  • Outlines penalties for not fulfilling reporting requirements.
  • Outlines powers of a circuit court judge in reporting, including ordering certain information to be produced, assessing penalties, and coverage of costs.

HISTORY: ["01/05/2022 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Darren Bailey","01/05/2022 - First Reading","01/05/2022 - Referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to develop procedures for conducting audits of signatures on ballot applications in regular elections starting with the general election in 2022.
  • Requires each election authroity to randomly select 1% of applications and audit in accordance with the developed procedure.

HISTORY: ["01/05/2022 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Darren Bailey","01/05/2022 - First Reading","01/05/2022 - Referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "change of status."
  • Defines "trackable ballot."
  • Defines "voter registration database."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to develop and maintain a state or locally based system to track the status of a trackable ballot by July 1, 2022.
  • Requires the ballot tracking system to send a voter who has elected to track his or her ballot electronic notifications.
  • Requires notification be given in the ballot tracking application that the voter will receive electronic notifications, and requires that the voter specifically consent to this.
  • Requires the election authoruty to transmit voter information to the State Board of Elections.

• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a policy concerning the chain of custody and secure storage of vote by mail ballots, including procedures to destroy a ballot when a voter votes in person after voting by mail, reporting requirements, database creation and publication of data.
  • Requires the policy to be implemented by each election authority.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a resident from a voter's residential address to endorse a voters vote by mail envelope to verify a voter's identity and residency. 
  • If this is not possible, a resident of the voter's precinct may endorse the envelope, or the voter may include a utility bill or lease with the ballot to verify their identity.

BILLSUMMARY: • Requires that after four hours of counting ballots, local election authorities determine how many ballots are left to be counted for each precinct, and what type of ballots are left to count.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a voter to apply for a vote by mail ballot 60-90 days before an election, rather than 5-90 days.
  • Make conforming changes.

BILLSUMMARY: • Prohibits any voting machine from being connected to the internet while being used to cast votes.

HISTORY: ["02/17/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Deanne M. Mazzochi","02/19/2021 - First Reading","02/19/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","03/27/2021 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee","12/29/2021 - Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Amy Grant"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a vote by mail ballot to be postmarked no later than three days before election day to be counted, rather than election day.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["10/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Darren Bailey","10/26/2021 - First Reading","10/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to develop procedures for conducting audits of affidavit signatures on ballots cast in regular elections by the general election in 2022.
  • Requires each election authority to select a random 1% of ballots cast to be audited.

HISTORY: ["10/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Darren Bailey","10/26/2021 - First Reading","10/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the county clerk to cancel the voter registration of anyone who died in the preceding month.
  • Requires certain qualified individuals to transfer notification of death within seven days to the county clerk.
  • Requires the county clerk to monthly request change of address records from the US Postal Service and update affected voter registrations.
  • Outlines reporting requirements for the county clerk.
  • Outlines penalties for the clerk not fulfilling reporting requirements.
  • Outlines powers of a circuit court judge in reporting, including ordering certain information to be produced, assessing penalties, and coverage of costs.

HISTORY: ["10/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Darren Bailey","10/26/2021 - First Reading","10/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "change of status."
  • Defines "trackable ballot."
  • Defines "voter registration database."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to develop and maintain a state or locally based system to track the status of a trackable ballot by July 1, 2022.
  • Requires the ballot tracking system to send a voter who has elected to track his or her ballot electronic notifications.
  • Requires notification be given in the ballot tracking application that the voter will receive electronic notifications, and that the voter's provided information will be included in the statewide voter registration database.

HISTORY: ["07/30/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Maurice A. West, II","09/03/2021 - First Reading","09/03/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines meeting requirements for dividing election precincts for County Boards in counties with under three million inhabitants, where the number of votes cast in a precinct on election day in the most recent general election was more than 1,200.
  • Changes "district" to "precinct" throughout the text.
  • Allows precincts to be consolidated when dividing them.
  • Make conforming changes to election code.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Changes the name of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Chicago to the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago.
  • Requires Chicago Board of Education members be elected to five year terms in 2022, with successors being elected to four-year terms.
  • Requires 2022 Chicago Board of Education elections to be nonpartisan.
  • Establishes that each Chicago Board of Education member will be elected at each consolidated election beginning in April 2027 to succeed the incumbent member whose term ends.
  • Requires the city of Chicago to be subdivided by the General Assembly into 20 electoral districts for school board.
  • Requires one representative from each district, plus one at-large representative.
  • Outlines requirements for meetings, organization, and vacancy on the school board.
  • Outlines prohibitions for school board members and conflicts of interest, including penalties.
  • Outlines candidacy and nomination requirements for school board elections.
  • Removes certain health insurance, benefit, and compensation provisions.
  • Specifies language for nomination petitions for school board.
  • Provides that the Inspector General be appointed by the board instead of the mayor starting March 22, 2022 and the board appoint vacancies starting March 24, 2026.
  • Requires the General Assembly to redistrict school board districts after each decennial census with certain requirements.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Implements the National Voter Registration Act and order of the Circuit Court regarding canceling voter registrations.
  • Requires procedures to cancel voter registrations from the National Voter Registration Act be followed, including providing notice.
  • Provides that a voter who has not voted in two consecutive federal general elections is inactive and will be canceled, if the voter has taken no actions specified in the Act to restore his or her name.
  • Requires an election authority to cancel the voter registration of a voter who requests it in writing.
  • Lists reasons a voter's registration may be canceled.
  • Requires the county clerk to cancel the registration of a deceased voter, following certain guidelines.

HISTORY: ["02/24/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Ann Gillespie","02/24/2021 - First Reading","02/24/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/09/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Melinda Bush","03/23/2021 - Assigned to Ethics","03/25/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Jacqueline Y. Collins","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments","05/04/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Laura M. Murphy"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "asset," "creditor," "debt," "diversified funds," "economic relationship," "family," "filer," "income," "investment real estate," "lobbying," "lobbyist," "personal residence," "sector funds," "spouse," "affected office," and "candidate political committee." 
  • Prohibits legislators from engaging in promoting or opposing the passage of any legislative matter affecting the interests of any individual, association, or corporation, in distinction from the interests of the people of the state as a whole.
  • Prohibits legislators from engaging in compensated lobbying of any government body on behalf of any lobbying entity registered in the state of Illinois or any Illinois county, municipality, or township.
  • Prohibits any appointed person from serving as an officer or becoming a candidate of a candidate political committee.
  • Requires that an appointed person within 30 days of their appointment implement certain measures related to their affiliation with a candidate political committee.
  • Requires the General Assembly to be in compliance with this legislation within 30 days of its effective date.
  • Requires that the interest of a spouse or any other party is considered the same as the interest of the person making the statement of economic interest.
  • Provides that campaign receipts are not to be included in the statement of economic interests.
  • Lists the interests that are required to file, including certain assets, income, debt, employers within the government, lobbying.
  • Provides that every five years the Secretary of State will adjust disclosure amounts based on inflation.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to develop guidance for filing the statement of economic interests and make it available on their website.
  • Removes conflicting guidance.
  • Provides the instructions for the statement of economic interests and provides that it may be filed with a county clerk, in addition to the Secretary of State.
  • Allows that a filers statement should be made with reasonable, good faith guidance from the Secretary of State and should not constitute a willful false or incomplete statement for classification of misdemeanor offenses.
  • Adds Supreme Court Justices, appellate court judges, circuit court judges, and judicial retention to the list of those who should not use the internet to file their statement.
  • Clarifies that candidates, officials, and officers may not hold a virtual fundraising event in Sangamon County on certain days related to when the legislature is in session if the person is not in Sangamon County.
  • Prohibits a former officer of the executive or legislative branch from engaging in activities that require registration under the Lobbyist Registration Act for a period of six months after leaving office.
  • Adds fiscal administration of state contracts as a reason to work with certain state agencies or entities on issues dealing with procurement and the prohibition of a revolving door.
  • Requires the Legislative Inspector General to be a full time employee of the state, outlines compensation requirements, and requires him or her to post office hours in Springfield.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Prohibits a limited activity committee from accepting contributions, except in specific circumstances and under certain guidelines.
  • Provides that a limited activity committee may only make certain expenditures.
  • Requires that starting January 1, 2022 compensation paid to members of the General Assembly be paid bi-monthly and prorates payment to members who resign and those completing a vacancy term.
  • Provides that state regulations regarding lobbying supercede local rules.

• Requires that an appointing committee to fill a vacancy in the General assembly convene within three days and establishes guidelines for their work.
  • Prohibits the a State Senator or Representative, who is also a committee member, from appointing his or her successor and establishes related voting rules.

• Requires a permanent polling place for early voting to remain open starting 22 days before the during regular hours.
  • Requires a permanent polling place for early voting to remain open starting 11 days before the election 8:30am-7pm or 9am-7:30pm every day.
  • Requires early voting locations to remain open at least 16 hours in the final weekend before the election.

["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Steven M. Landek","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/17/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments","04/22/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Jason Plummer"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines meeting requirements for dividing election precincts for County Boards in counties with under three million inhabitants, where the number of votes cast in a precinct on election day in the most recent general election was more than 1,200.
  • Changes "district" to "precinct" throughout the text.
  • Allows precincts to be consolidated when dividing them.
  • Make conforming changes to election code.

HISTORY: ["02/19/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Sally J. Turner","02/19/2021 - First Reading","02/19/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/03/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/10/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments","04/20/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Michael E. Hastings","04/20/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Neil Anderson"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Includes election related security measures as exempt from FOIA requests in all relevant agencies.
  • Removes a paragraph about public hearings related to cyber-security efforts.
  • Changes "Help America Vote Act" to "2018 Help America Vote Act Election Security Grant" in related legislation.

HISTORY: ["02/19/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Sue Rezin","02/19/2021 - First Reading","02/19/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/17/2021 - To Executive- Elections","03/23/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Brian W. Stewart","04/13/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Terri Bryant","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments","04/19/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Dale Fowler"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Allows a US citizen who has never lived in the US, but whose parent or legal guardian is a qualified voter, eligibility to register and vote in federal elections where his or her parent or guardian lives.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2021 - Filed with the Clerk by Rep. Jonathan Carroll","01/14/2021 - First Reading","01/14/2021 - Referred to Rules Committee","02/18/2021 - Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Carol Ammons","02/23/2021 - Assigned to Ethics & Elections Committee","03/02/2021 - Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Rita Mayfield","03/27/2021 - Rule 19(a) / Re-referred to Rules Committee","04/19/2021 - Fiscal Note Filed"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires schools to be closed on election day regardless of whether the school is used as a polling site.
  • Requires school districts to close all schools on the day of a general election.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Sara Feigenholtz","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","04/07/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/15/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Changes the definition of "person with disability" to include intellectual or developmental disabilities.
  • Requires election authorities to give 75 days notice, rather than 60, before each election about the availability of voting and registration aids through the Federal Voting and Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act.
  • Requires aids be for voting in person, early in person, or by mail. 
  • Outlines responsibilities of the county clerk for mailing and receiving vote by mail ballots 14-20 days before an election for a person with a disability.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections and Department of Human Services to create a system where vote by mail voters may return their ballots through other means.
  • Adapts code to conform to the new standard.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Steven M. Landek","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/17/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows voters to apply to be added to a list of permanent vote by mail voters.
  • Requires permanent vote by mail voters to stay on the vote by mail list until they change their registration, request to be removed, or if the election authority receives notice that they are registered in another county.
  • Requires election authorities to notify qualified voters about the option of being placed on the permanent vote by mail list 45-90 days before an election, with certain requirements.
  • Provides language for the application for a permanent vote by mail application.
  • Requires election authorities to allow permanent vote by mail voters to change their party affiliation for a primary election.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Doris Turner","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/16/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Adriane Johnson","03/17/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Mattie Hunter","03/23/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Changes "State Board of Elections website" to "electronic voter registration portal."
  • Allows qualified 16 year olds to preregister to vote using the electronic voter registration portal.
  • Allows a 17 year old, who will be 18 at the next election, to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public question.
  • Deems a 16 year old competent to execute and attest to any voter registration forms.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Mike Simmons","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","04/07/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/15/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires that when a vacancy occurs for State Senator or Representative, the appropriate legislative committee to fill the vacancy must notify the public of the vacancy and the replacement process, including providing information of where interested members of the public may apply for an appointment. 
  • Requires the legislative committee to provide the public notice of an impending vote to fill the vacancy at least six days before the vote.
  • Requires a meeting to fill a vacancy in the General Assembly be open to the public, subject to the Open Meetings Act, be recorded, and be broadcast for the public. 
  • Requires the Governor comply with the above requirements, to the extent possible, if he or she fills a vacancy for State Senate or House.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Melinda Bush","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","04/07/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/15/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "audit unit."
  • Lists conditions to be satisfied for a precinct, set of ballots, or single ballot to be an audit unit.
  • Requires each election authority to conduct an audit following an election, notifying the State Board of Elections before election day about the type of audit to be conducted.
  • Requires election authorities to also conduct a random audit of 5% of ballots cast by mail.
  • Outlines steps and requirements for a random audit.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to consult certain experts to adopt rules and criteria for the conduct of a risk-limiting audit, and outlines steps and requirements.
  • Requires written notice to state central committee chairs when either audit is conducted.
  • Removes certain test requirements for vote counting equipment and outlines steps for if an error is detected following an audit.

HISTORY: ["01/29/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Terri Bryant","01/29/2021 - First Reading","01/29/2021 - Referred to Assignments","02/09/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/10/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires that one elector for US President and Vice President come from each congressional district.
  • Allows the State Convention or State central committee of a party to choose two electors at-large.
  • Makes complying changes to Election Code.
  • Requires each congressional district elector to cast his or her ballot for the candidate who received the highest number of votes in the congressional district.
  • Requires each at-large elector to cast his or her ballot for the candidate who received the highest number of votes in the state.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Cristina Castro","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/04/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Bill Cunningham","03/04/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Jacqueline Y. Collins","03/08/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Laura Fine","03/09/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Laura M. Murphy","03/18/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Rachelle Crowe","03/23/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires online voter registration applicants to use the "electronic voter registration portal" instead of the State Board of Elections website.
  • Allows individuals to preregister to vote starting on their 16th birthday, requiring the registration to be held by election authorities until the individual reaches voting age.
  • Requires those preregistering to vote to use the electronic voter registration portal.
  • Allows 17 year olds who will be 18 by the time of the next election, and are otherwise eligible to vote, to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public question.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Neil Anderson","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/16/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires one presidential elector be designated from each congressional district in the state.
  • Makes related changes to ballot requirements.
  • Establishes that the presidential elector with the highest number of votes in a district, or at-large, must cast the electoral vote for the presidential and Vice President candidates of his or her political party.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Cristina Castro","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/15/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Jacqueline Y. Collins","03/16/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "actual malice" and "campaign material."
  • Prohibits anyone or any organization from distributing campaign materials containing superimposed images of candidates with actual malice, unless the picture is labeled "this picture is not an accurate representation of fact."
  • Outlines options for restraining orders, civil actions, fines, and other court actions related to campaign materials alleged to be inaccurate or published with actual malice.
  • Provides for certain exemptions.
  • Defines "materially deceptive audio or visual media" and lists conditions in which it may be used.
  • Prohibits anyone from distributing with actual malice, materially deceptive audio and visual media of a candidate with the intent to injure the person's reputation or deceive, within 60 days of the election. 
  • Provides exceptions.
  • Outlines requirements for disclosures for visual and audio media.
  • Provides pathways for relief for candidates whose voices or likeness is used in visual and audio media.
  • Provides exceptions.
  • Provides that the provisions in this section are severable.
  • Provides that proceedings related to registration of voters, certification of candidates, and certification of ballot measures will be heard in order of their date of filing and will be given precedence.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Jil Tracy","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","04/07/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/15/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board of Elections, in conjunction with election authorities, by January 1, 2023 to implement a free, secure system to track vote-by-mail ballots, and to notify a voter if his or her vote by mail ballot was accepted in the counting, with reasons if it was rejected. 
  • Requires the election authority to make the system available for each election, with timelines.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Omar Aquino","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/16/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Changes the name of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Chicago to the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago.
  • Requires in the 2022 primary that members of the Board of Trustees of the City Colleges of Chicago and the Illinois Community College District 508 be elected in a non partisan election for a term of four years.
  • Requires that members of the Board of Trustees of the City Colleges of Chicago and Illinois Community College District 508 be elected at each consolidated election starting in April 2023 to succeed incumbent members whose term ends after the consolidated election.
  • Outlines board appointments, elections, membership, and vacancy procedures for community college districts.
  • Establishes language for nomination petitions, as well as instructions for content, processing, and timelines, in the City of Chicago.
  • Outlines rules for ballots and petitions related to community college district elections.
  • Requires the City of Chicago to create 20 trustee districts by January 1, 2022 and requires they be reapportioned the year after the decennial census.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Steven M. Landek","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/09/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/17/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows an election authority to reduce the number of judges of an election in each precinct from five to three for any election.
  • Makes conforming changes to the election code.

COAUTHORS: ["Terri Bryant","Dale Fowler","Dan McConchie","Jason Plummer","Brian Stewart","Win Stoller","Jil Tracy","Sally Turner"]
HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. John F. Curran","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/23/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/23/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Brian W. Stewart","03/24/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Dale Fowler","03/24/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Dan McConchie","03/24/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Win Stoller","03/24/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Jil Tracy","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/13/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Terri Bryant","04/13/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Jason Plummer","04/15/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Sally J. Turner","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the treasurer of a political committee to preserve all records and accounts before January 1, 2022 for two years, and for seven years after that date.
  • Allows the board to require a political committee to conduct an audit of its financial records if: a candidate admits a violation of the law in testimony, a candidate is convicted of misuse of funds, the committee fails to comply with a board order regarding reporting, or if a statement or organization by a political committee included officers or candidates of a political committee that was administratively terminated in the last 24 months.
  • Establishes that the audit period is within the board's discretion, but may not exceed seven years.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Melinda Bush","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","04/07/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/15/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "electronic ballot marking tool."
  • Provides that the General Assembly intends that vote by mail be fully accessible to all voters. 
  • Provides that the State Board of Elections will work with election authorities and the disability community to develop procedures and technology to provide vote by mail ballots in alternative formats that meet the requirements of other vote by mail ballots and do not require assistance.
  • Requires adaptation of the electronic ballot marking tool, enabling voters to mark their ballot privately and independently.
  • Requires implementation of alternative methods for voters to return the ballot, including secure email portals, conforming with Illinois accessibility legislation and technology and security standards.
  • Requires each election authority to provide the option of a fully electronic ballot allowing voters with disability to vote a secret ballot without assistance starting January 1, 2023.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Ram Villivalam","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","04/07/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/15/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "trackable."
  • Requires mailed ballots to be trackable.
  • Requires election authorities to mail, or deliver in person, return envelopes that are postage prepaid and trackable with vote by mail ballots.
  • Requires election authorities to maintain a list of applicants who have requested, received, or returned vote by mail ballots.
  • Requires election authorities to provide online access to the vote by mail ballot list, with certain additional information and updating on their website.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Julie A. Morrison","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/23/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","03/25/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Jacqueline Y. Collins","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows the Board to distribute Help America Vote Act funds to election authorities for maintenance of secure collection sites for return of vote mail ballots.
  • Allows election authorities to establish curbside voting for early voting and election day.
  • Requires curbside voting programs to designate at least two election judges from opposite parties per vehicle with certain ballot security provisions.
  • Requires election officials to accept vote by mail ballots returned with insufficient postage.
  • Allows election authorities to maintain collection sites for postage free return of vote by mail ballots and outlines a process for collection, timelines, security, and authority.
  • Establishes the State Board of Elections will establish additional guidelines for security of collection sites.
  • Establishes the State Board of Elections will create standard vote by mail envelopes and provides guidelines for the creation of envelopes.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Linda Holmes","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","04/07/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/15/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines electioneering.
  • Creates an Elections Special Projects Fund where all fees and penalties paid to the State Board of Elections will be deposited and used for ordinary and contingent expenses of the State Board of Elections.
  • Requires the appropriate election authority to notify candidates of the requirement to submit quarterly campaign contribution reports.
  • Prohibits anyone from circulating a nominating petition during an election within 100 feet of a polling place.
  • Removes guidelines related to contributions for political party committees.
  • Removes the requirement that the Task Force on Campaign Finance Reform make recommendations on improving access to information related to complaints.
  • Removes certain provisions related to the registration of business entities, including filing, timelines, reporting, and penalties. 
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to publish precinct-by-precinct vote totals for offices, candidates, and public questions with certified election results within 52 days of the election.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Replaces the term "measure" with "public question" or "question" in relevant legislation.
  • Replaces the term "Direct Recording Electronic Voting System" with "direct recording electronic tabulators and electronic marking devices" in relevant legislation.
  • Requires that direct recording electronic tabulators be capable of instantly marking votes, producing a permanent paper record, and enabling votes to be counted at the polling station, and further defines terms and capabilities of the equipment.
  • Prohibits use of public funds to sway a voter for or against anything or anyone on the ballot, or for political or campaign purposes.
  • Allows public funds to be used for "dissemination of factual information" related to voter education.
  • Outlines penalties for misuse of public funds or receipt of illegal contributions.
  • Outlines penalties for filing a false complaint.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to give political committees a blank form of the Code of Fair Campaign Practices and a copy of the related provisions.
  • Removes certain restrictions on political committees conducting raffles.
  • Outlines penalties for violating provisions related to political committees conducting raffles.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Bill Cunningham","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/10/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Elgie R. Sims, Jr.","03/11/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Antonio Mu\u00f1oz","03/11/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Emil Jones, III","04/07/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/15/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows certain forms at the department of motor vehicles to also be used as voter registration applications, provided the applicant presents identification confirming US citizenship and age, unless the applicant declines the option.
  • Provides that if an applicant to the department of motor vehicles does not submit identification confirming US citizenship and does not indicate the applicant is currently registered to vote in the state, then the application will not be a dual-purpose application.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to electronically transmit information to the State Board of Elections for each completed application, including the applicant's choice of language.
  • Allows the State Board of Elections to enter into an agreement with certain agencies for the purpose of updating an applicant's existing voter registration record.
  • Allows the agencies to transmit information about clients who may be registered to vote for the sole purpose of updating their registration.
  • Requires the Department of Healthcare and Family Services to implement automatic voter registration for Medicaid applicants by July 1, 2023.
  • Establishes rules for automatic voter registration applications sent without signature.
  • Establishes procedures for automatic voter registration applications received for individuals protected by certain programs designed for confidentiality of victims.
  • Outlines certain notification requirements for individuals who are automatically registered to vote.
  • Makes other conforming changes to election code.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Jason A. Barickman","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/16/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/23/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Brian W. Stewart","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/13/2021 - Added as Co-Sponsor Sen. Terri Bryant","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Establishes that the highest ranking State Senator of the political party not affiliated with the Governor will be the nominating officer for the State Board of Elections if all the state executive officers are in the same political party as the Governor.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Melinda Bush","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","04/06/2021 - Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Jacqueline Y. Collins","04/07/2021 - Assigned to Executive","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Gives voters the option to be placed on the permanent vote by mail list.
  • Outlines processing requirements for being placed on the permanent vote by mail list and for processing ballots for elections.
  • Requires authorities to send a list of vote by mail voters to election officials within a certain timeline.
  • Clarifies that vote by mail ballots from permanent vote by mail voters are subject to the same deadlines and should be processed the same way as other ballots.
  • Outline procedures and notifications for voters who are on the permanent vote by mail list, but who do not return a ballot for four general elections.
  • Provides language for the vote by mail application, including a check box to indicate whether a voter wishes to be added to the permanent vote by mail list.
  • Outlines procedures for vote by mail partisan primaries in which a voter must choose a political party preference.
  • Outlines procedures for a voter to cancel their permanent vote by mail status, including listing what should be on the form.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Julie A. Morrison","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/23/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires any campaign, party, or others engaging in vote by mail operations in which voters are sent applications by mail to also provide the voter with an addressed return envelope to the proper election authority.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["02/26/2021 - Filed with Secretary by Sen. Ram Villivalam","02/26/2021 - First Reading","02/26/2021 - Referred to Assignments","03/23/2021 - Assigned to Executive","03/24/2021 - To Executive- Elections","04/16/2021 - Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Establishes that anyone who performs notarial acts related to election nominating papers, petitions of objection to nominating papers, or certificates of withdrawal of candidacy, and who is not authorized to provide notary services, will be in violation of the Election Code, in addition to other penalties.
