Roll Call 131: yeas 83, nays 10","01/31/2022 - Third reading: passed; Roll Call 162: yeas 66, nays 28","01/31/2022 - Senate sponsor: Senator Ford Jon","02/01/2022 - Referred to the Senate","02/07/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections","02/14/2022 - Committee report: amend do pass adopted; reassigned to committee on Appropriations","02/24/2022 - Committee report: amend do pass, adopted","02/28/2022 - Senate Amendment #2 (Filed)","02/28/2022 - Senate Amendment #1 (Filed)","02/28/2022 - Second reading: ordered engrossed","03/01/2022 - Third reading: passed; Roll Call 288: yeas 35, nays 10","03/01/2022 - Senator Rogers added as second sponsor","03/02/2022 - Returned to the House with amendments","03/03/2022 - Motion to concur filed","03/03/2022 - Motion to dissent filed","03/04/2022 - House conferees appointed: Wesco and Errington","03/04/2022 - House advisors appointed: O'Brien, Manning, Pfaff and Pierce","03/07/2022 - Concurrence withdrawn; House dissented from Senate Amendments","03/07/2022 - Senate conferees appointed: Ford Jon and Ford J.D.","03/07/2022 - Senate advisors appointed: Crane and Qaddoura","03/07/2022 - Motion to concur filed","03/07/2022 - House reconsidered and concurred in Senate amendments; Roll Call 351: yeas 95, nays 0","03/09/2022 - Signed by the Speaker","03/09/2022 - Signed by the President Pro Tempore","03/14/2022 - Signed by the President of the Senate","03/14/2022 - Signed by the Governor","03/14/2022 - Public Law 115"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that this bill applies only if the costs can be paid from federal government funds or appropriated by the general assembly.
  • Requires certain information be used on the envelope for an absentee ballot application, including font size.
  • Requires the electronic poll book must have the capacity for each voter to transmit information if the voter cast a provisional ballot, through a private server to the statewide voter registration system.
  • Requires this function not be disabled.
  • Removes the provision that the circuit court clerk must provide notice to a voter who casts a provisional ballot.
  • Makes changes aligning current election code with new requirements.
  • Defines "early voting" to mean voting before an absentee voter board.
  • Enumerates circumstances in which a county election board will not use a direct record electronic voting system in an election after July 1, 2022.
  • Allows a county election board to use a module of the computerized list to comply with requirements for provisional voters.
  • Lists required elements in a county's list related to provisional ballots.
  • Defines "post election audit" and replaces the term "risk limiting audit" in related legislation.

HISTORY: ["01/10/2022 - Authored by Senator Walker G","01/10/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Education and Career Development","01/24/2022 - Senator Buchanan added as coauthor"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "school board" to mean the governing body of a school corporation and includes elected school advisory boards in the definition.
  • Provides that the following rules apply only for nonpartisan school board elections.
  • Provides that nominees may withdraw by noon on July 15 under if nominations followed certain codes.
  • Removes candidates for precinct committeeman, state convention delegate, and school board from the requirement that names on ballot be arranged in alphabetical order.
  • Aligns relevant election code.
  • Removes school board elections from the list of elections where a candidate may receive the greatest number of votes to win.
  • Puts school board candidates on the ballot behind the town council candidates with certain provisions.
  • Outlines the process for resolving tie votes in school board elections.
  • Clarifies to whom a circuit court clerk should provide written notification in the case of a tie in a local or school board election.
  • Removes conflicting code regarding vacancies and makes clarifying changes.
  • Clarifies rules governing nomination to be a candidate of a governing body.
  • Provides that these rules do not apply to school corporations with an elected school advisory board.
  • Amends the population size requirements of cities in adoption of certain membership increases of the governing body of the school corporation.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2022 - Authored by Representative Engleman","01/13/2022 - Coauthored by Representative Young J","01/13/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Judiciary","01/20/2022 - Committee report: do pass, adopted","01/24/2022 - Second reading: ordered engrossed"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Names political subdivisions described by certain population parameters and other identifying features.
  • Changes formulas used to determine distribution of funds.
  • Removes provisions regarding the timeline for certain political subdivisions to take effect, as they relate to the decennial census.

HISTORY: ["01/06/2022 - Authored by Representative Wesco","01/06/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment","01/18/2022 - Committee report: amend do pass, adopted","01/18/2022 - Referred to the Committee on Ways and Means pursuant to House Rule 127","01/20/2022 - Representative Slager added as coauthor"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that this bill applies only if the costs can be paid from federal government funds or appropriated funds from the general assembly.
  • Extends the term of the threat intelligence code to expire January 1, 2028, from January 1, 2023.
  • Requires certain information and format on the envelope for an absentee ballot application.
  • Allows that someone can register on election day if they meet certain requirements.
  • Removes the provision that the circuit court clerk must provide notice to a voter who casts a provisional ballot.
  • Lists reasons a voter would be permitted to vote by mail.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Clarifies that voting before an absentee voter board is "early voting."
  • Defines "post election audit" and replaces the term "risk limiting audit" with "post election audit" in related code.
  • Requires those accessing absentee ballot applications to provide certain identification.

HISTORY: ["01/11/2022 - Authored by Representative Morrison","01/11/2022 - Coauthored by Representative Payne","01/11/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Education"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits the election commission from instituting, increasing, or expanding vote by mail or absentee ballot voting.
  • Prohibits the election commission from changing the time, manner, or place of holding an election.
  • Allows additionally a ten digit Indiana drivers license number or last four digits of the Social Security number for absentee ballot application identification.
  • Requires the county election board to deny an absentee ballot application if it does not include either the driver's license number or last four digits of the social security number, or if the numbers given do not match the election board's file.
  • Repeals the abilities of the secretary of state to designate counties as risk limiting pilot counties.
  • Requires the county election board to conduct a risk limiting audit before results are certified.
  • Specifies that the governor does not have the power to create an executive order changing the time, manner, or place of elections.
  • Specifies that the governor does not have the authority to institute or increase absentee voting or voting by mail.

HISTORY: ["01/11/2022 - Authored by Representative Pfaff","01/11/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines relevant terms.
  • Allows an individual to register or transfer registration on election day.
  • Makes changes to align new rules to current election code.
  • Enumerates requirements for registering on election day, including the responsibilities of relevant officials.
  • Establishes that an individual can register to vote until the close of polls on election day.

HISTORY: ["01/11/2022 - Authored by Senator Houchin","01/11/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Forbids the Commission from instituting or increasing vote by mail or absentee voting, or from changing the time, manner, or place of elections. 
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Lists acceptable forms of identification for absentee ballot applications.
  • Provides that the county board of elections will deny an absentee ballot application if a voter does not include the required ID.
  • Outlines certain deadlines for submitting an absentee ballot application.
  • Lists pilot counties for an electronic voting system audit pilot program.
  • Provides that the secretary of state will enter into contracts to conduct the pilot audits of equipment used in the 2022 general election.
  • Sets expiration and other deadlines.
  • Provides that before the audit, the contractor will randomly select counties to be audited, with certain provisions.
  • Outlines certain contracting guidelines for the secretary of state.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the audit of computer equipment.
  • Clarifies that this code does not grant the governor the power to create an executive order changing the time, manner, or place of elections, nor does it grant the governor the authority to institute or increase vote by mail or absentee voting.

HISTORY: ["01/11/2022 - Authored by Representative Miller D","01/11/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "school board" to mean the governing body of a school corporation and includes elected school advisory boards in the definition.
  • Provides that someone running for school board who wishes to be in the party primary election must file a declaration of candidacy.
  • Provides dates and deadlines for declaring candidacy for school board in 2022 primary elections and offers guidelines for ballots in the primary election.
  • Makes conforming changes for partisan school board elections.
  • Clarifies to whom a circuit court clerk should provide written notification in the case of a tie in a local or school board election.
  • Outlines the process for resolving tie votes and filling vacancies in school board elections.
  • Outlines guidelines for candidate filing for school corporations and advisory boards, and clarifies that IC3 governs the nomination and election process.
  • Changes population requirements for dealing with ties and vacancies in school boards. 
  • Provides guidelines for candidate nominations in governing bodies.
  • Provides guidelines for vacancy of various governing board members.
  • Provides that a superintendent may hold a bachelor's degree in business administration.

HISTORY: ["01/10/2022 - Authored by Senator Buck","01/10/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Adds US Senators to the list of those requiring a state nominating convention to be a party candidate, as appropriate.
  • Clarifies that if no party candidate for US Senate gets a majority of votes, the election division must certify the candidate who received the greatest number of votes, with other associated actions.
  • Makes aligning changes to the election code.

HISTORY: ["01/10/2022 - Authored by Senator Ford Jon","01/10/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Lists pilot counties for the audit of computer equipment.
  • Requires the secretary of state to enter into contracts to conduct an audit of all computer equipment used in the 2022 general election in the pilot counties.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the contractee.
  • Outlines requirements for the audit, including reporting.
  • Establishes that the report must be submitted before December 31, 2022 to the secretary of state, attorney general, and chairs of the relevant senate and house committees.
  • Provides an expiration date.

HISTORY: ["01/06/2022 - Authored by Senator Mrvan","01/06/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Repeals the requirement that each inspector, judge, poll clerk, and election sheriff who is a voter of the county and not a resident of the precinct is entitled to an absentee ballot.
  • Repeals the code allowing nonresident challengers or pollbook holders to vote by absentee ballot.
  • Requires the computerized list to include absentee ballot management features, specifying certain requirements.
  • Requires the computerized list include documentation of the date each absentee ballot is issued and returned, and permits printing of absentee ballot applications with certain specifications.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the report of absentee ballot applications and voting.
  • Allows absentee ballot voters to vote by mail or before an absentee voter board.
  • Removes the requirement that an absentee ballot voter state the reason he or she is entitled to vote absentee.

HISTORY: ["01/06/2022 - Authored by Representative Wesco","01/06/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Details a statement to be printed on absentee ballot envelope applications, including the font.
  • Prohibits anyone sending an absentee ballot unless it is requested by the individual.
  • Specifies forms of ID to be included with an absentee ballot application and requires a statement on the form that the application will be denied if the ID numbers do not match at least one that is on record.
  • Entitles a voter to vote by mail if they expect to be absent from the county or precinct for the entire period of time where a voter may vote absentee in-person, and on election day; or for the following additional reasons: if the voter will be confined, or observing a religious discipline during the entire absentee in-person voting period and election day.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["01/06/2022 - Authored by Representative Dvorak","01/06/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "major political party."
  • Allows major political parties to nominate party candidates for US Senate, US House of Representatives, Governor, legislative office, local office.
  • Requires nomination petitions to have at least 250 registered voter signatures from the election district.
  • Defines other political parties as those who received at least 2,500 votes but less than 25% of votes cast for at the last election for that office.

HISTORY: ["01/06/2022 - Authored by Representative Johnson","01/06/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Clarifies that a person's signature on a department of motor vehicles application is considered the person's signature on their voter registration application.
  • Requires the bureau of motor vehicles commission to design, jointly with the election division, an application form to include the information required for a voter registration application for a driver's license.
  • Provides changes to align the new rules.
  • Outlines requirements of what should be included in the application for a driver's license, permit, or ID card/voter registration, and how it should be processed.
  • Requires officials to explain to driver's license applicants that if they do not decline to register to vote on their application, they will be considered to have selected the option to register, and that they meet eligibility requirements.

HISTORY: ["01/06/2022 - Authored by Representative Morrison","01/06/2022 - Coauthored by Representative Morris","01/06/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "school board" to mean the governing body of a school corporation and includes elected school advisory boards in the definition.
  • Requires school board candidates to follow the same procedures as other candidates for local office.
  • Provides that political parties may nominate candidates for school board in primary elections.
  • Aligns election code to include school board candidates in partisan elections.
  • Clarifies to whom a circuit court clerk should provide written notification in the case of a tie in a local or school board election.
  • Outlines the process for resolving tie votes in school board elections.
  • Clarifies that election code IC3 governs the nomination and election of candidates in school board and advisory board elections and outlines specific procedures.
  • Removes conflicting code regarding vacancies and makes clarifying changes.
  • Clarifies rules governing nomination to be a candidate of a governing body.

HISTORY: ["01/06/2022 - Authored by Representative Goodrich","01/06/2022 - Coauthored by Representatives Prescott, Behning, Wesco","01/06/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "school board" and includes elected school advisory board int he term.
  • Establishes that those who wish to run in a primary election of a political party for school board must file a declaration of candidacy.
  • Outlines signature requirements for school board nominations, based on population size.
  • Establishes that a candidate for school board who does not identify with a political party is an independent candidate.
  • Provides that a school board candidates political party affiliation should be listed on the ballot.
  • Outlines requirements for a candidate being affiliated with a political party.
  • Outlines the process of a challenge.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Establishes procedures for a tie vote and for filling vacancies on the school board and governing body.
  • Outlines provisions for election of members of the governing body.
  • States that IC3 governs the nomination and election of candidates.
  • Establishes nominating deadlines.
  • Clarifies that the state board will work with the assistance of the county election board to carry out the election.

HISTORY: ["01/04/2022 - Authored by Senator Randolph Lonnie M","01/04/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Corrections and Criminal Law"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits anyone from carrying a firearm within 50 feet of the chute, the polls, or wherever voters congregate to vote.
  • Prohibits anyone from carrying a firearm where ballots are being counted.
  • Provides that violation is a Class C misdemeanor, or other level misdemeanor or felony, under certain circumstances.
  • Lists reasons that are not a defense for bringing a firearm to the election site.
  • Requires election officials to conspicuously display a firearm prohibition in certain locations.
  • Outlines what should be included in the firearm prohibition notice.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["01/04/2022 - Authored by Senators Baldwin, Raatz, Buchanan","01/04/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Education and Career Development"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides certain requirements to qualify as a candidate for school board.
  • Allows school board candidates to declare party affiliation if they wish, and provides for it to be listed on the ballot.
  • Makes related changes to unify the election code.
  • Provides for challenges to a candidates petition based on party affiliation.
  • Clarifies to whom a circuit court clerk should provide written notification in the case of a tie in a local or school board election.
  • Outlines the process for resolving tie votes and filling vacancies on the school board.
  • Outlines certain guidelines for school board reorganization plans, including the provision that they will be elected, as required by law.
  • Requires community school corporations being created out of existing corporations be elected.
  • Provides conforming changes to election code.
  • Outlines guidelines for filing for election in a school corporation governing body.
  • Lists officials who may appoint a school corporation governing body member.
  • Clarifies that election code IC3 governs the nomination and election of candidates for governing board or school board.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Changes population requirements for governing board membership size.
  • Provides effective dates.
  • Provides that the county election board will assist the state board in administering school board elections.
  • Provides terms of office for school board members.

HISTORY: ["01/04/2022 - Authored by Senator Ford J.D.","01/04/2022 - First reading: referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that elderly voters and voters with disabilities may apply for permanent absentee voter status.
  • Provides that a voter with permanent absentee voter status has the same rights and is subject to the same standards and procedures as other absentee voters.
  • Outlines responsibilities of the circuit court clerk if a voter qualifies for permanent absentee voter status.
  • Outlines processing instructions and notifications for permanent absentee voter's ballot. 
  • Outlines procedures for if more than one ballot is received by the election authorities.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - Senate Introduced","02/11/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows anyone 16 and older to apply to register to vote. 
  • Requires the secretary of state to suspend an applicants registration until they are 18 years of age, at which time they can vote.

HISTORY: ["01/14/2021 - Senate Introduced","01/15/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Removes the option for the secretary of state to extend the time limit deadline for mailed ballots.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - House Introduced","01/25/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","02/21/2022 - House Committee on Elections Report","02/21/2022 - House Committee Report recommending bill be passed by Committee on Elections","02/23/2022 - House Withdrawn from Calendar; Referred to Committee on Appropriations","03/01/2022 - House Withdrawn from  Committee on Appropriations and re-referred to Committee of the Whole","05/23/2022 - House Died on Calendar"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires a county election officer to send a confirmation of voter registration notice if a voter has not had an election-related activity in four calendar years.

HISTORY: ["01/31/2022 - House Introduced","01/31/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/08/2022 - House Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","03/08/2022 - House Committee Report recommending bill be passed by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - House Died on Calendar"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires an audit of all federal or state elections in even-numbered years that are within 1% of the vote.
  • Requires the audit to be in 10% of county precincts, with a minimum of one precinct per county.

HISTORY: ["01/11/2021 - House Prefiled for Introduction on Tuesday, December 22, 2020","01/11/2021 - House Introduced","01/11/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Decreases the penalty for a series of crimes associated with advance voting ballots and applications from a level 9 felony to a class C misdemeanor.
  • Removes a provision in election bribery crimes excluding businesses or organizations.
  • Revises the definition of "voting without being qualified" to include voting or offering to vote more than once in the same election, and inducing another person to vote more than once, and revises penalties to make it a class A misdemeanor rather than a level 7 penalty.
  • Increases the penalty for election tampering from a level 7 felony to a level 8 felony.
  • Increases the penalty for false impersonation of a voter from a level 8 felony to a level 9 felony.
  • Makes clarifying changes to the language for the registration book declaration.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Senate Introduced","01/26/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/08/2022 - Senate Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","03/08/2022 - Senate Committee Report recommending bill be passed as amended by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/16/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Committee Report be adopted","03/16/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to rerefer to committee failed","03/16/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Be passed as amended","03/17/2022 - Senate Final Action - Passed as amended;  Yea: 27 Nay: 10","03/21/2022 - House Received and Introduced","03/21/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in House Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires each person handling ballots for the county election office to sign an affidavit with certain information.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to develop an affidavit system that applies to all ballots handled at county election offices.
  • Establishes that violation of the affidavit is a level 9 felony.

HISTORY: ["01/14/2022 - House Introduced","01/14/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","02/21/2022 - House Committee on Elections Report","02/21/2022 - House Committee Report recommending bill be passed as amended by Committee on Elections","02/23/2022 - House Withdrawn from Calendar; Referred to Committee on Appropriations","03/01/2022 - House Withdrawn from  Committee on Appropriations and re-referred to Committee of the Whole","05/23/2022 - House Died on Calendar"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "electronic poll book" and provides exceptions.
  • Adds electronic poll books as an option, along with electromechanical voting system, for county commissioners and election officers at voting places.
  • Forbids electronic poll books or electromechanical voting systems from having the capability to connect to the internet or to a computer network.
  • Forbids the county election officer from buying or renting poll books unless they are certified by the Secretary of State.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to certify electronic poll books for internet safety related issues and outlines the process.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["03/25/2021 - Senate Introduced","03/26/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires advance voting ballots to be received by 7:00pm on election day.
  • Forbids anyone from changing the deadline.

HISTORY: ["01/26/2022 - Senate Introduced","01/27/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires that advance voting ballots be received by 7:00pm on election day.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - Senate Introduced","02/11/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires those soliciting voters to file advance voting applications to conspicuously identify themselves in specified font on the envelope.
  • Requires any included envelopes be addressed to the office of the Secretary of State or county election office.

HISTORY: ["01/28/2021 - Senate Introduced","01/29/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires all voting systems in the state to use "individual, durable, voter-verified paper ballot" with certain required guidelines.
  • Provides for ballot counting and audits of the paper ballots.
  • Provides procedures for recounts.
  • Prohibits use of poll books without signatures.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to implement these rules.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Senate Introduced","01/26/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires the Secretary of State and county election officers to develop a ballot system that includes how many years an incumbent candidate has served in the office.

HISTORY: ["02/09/2021 - Senate Introduced","02/10/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Enacts an interstate compact to elect the president by national popular vote.
  • Requires each state to conduct a statewide popular vote for US president and vice president.
  • Requires the chief election official to determine the popular vote in each state and produce a national popular vote total.
  • Requires the chief state election official to designate the presidential slate with the largest national popular vote total as the national popular vote winner, and to appoint electors accordingly. 
  • Outlines further requirements for: administration of the vote, the event of a tie, other administrative situations.
  • Requires the agreement to take effect when states with a majority of the electoral votes enact the agreement.
  • Outlines actions in the case of a state withdrawal.
  • Includes conforming changes.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["02/08/2022 - House Introduced","02/08/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires county election officers to ensure electronic election data and images of ballots are protected from alteration, destruction, and unauthorized transfer, using protective measures at least as protective as those for paper ballots. 
  • Requires county election officials to make digital images of ballots, searchable by precinct, available to the public after polls close.
  • Establishes that digital images are considered public records and subject to appropriate disclosure laws.

HISTORY: ["04/08/2021 - Senate Introduced","04/09/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires most bond elections for municipalities to be held 45-60 days after compliance with the necessary requirements.
  • Eliminates the requirement that an election commissioner be a qualified voter and resident of a county at least two years prior to appointment.
  • Requires that in counties with a population of more than 130,000, powers and duties for the conduct of elections is conferred on the election commissioner.
  • Requires mail ballots with a postmark by the election day deadline to be delivered and canvassed like other ballots, while also creating a deadline to receive mail ballots three days after the election. 
  • Requires the county election officer to contact each person who submits a mail ballot with no signature, or where the signature does not match, and allow them to correct the deficiency before the start of the final county canvas.

HISTORY: ["02/01/2022 - House Introduced","02/01/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires any political party seeking official recognition to file petitions equaling 1% of votes cast for gubernatorial candidates in the last election with the secretary of state by certain deadlines.
  • Requires petitions be submitted within one year of the date of the first petition signature.

HISTORY: ["02/08/2022 - House Introduced","02/08/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Includes a list of requirements for any vendor providing secure ballot paper.
  • Requires the legislature to appropriate sufficient funds for county expenditure on ballot paper.
  • Requires this paper be used in all elections for state and federal offices.
  • Requires implementation of this rule by the general election of 2024 and each even numbered election after.

HISTORY: ["02/04/2022 - Senate Introduced","02/07/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/02/2022 - Senate Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","03/02/2022 - Senate Committee Report recommending bill be passed by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/09/2022 - Senate Floor Amendment (Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Hilderbrand)","03/09/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Hilderbrand","03/09/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Amendment by  Senator Hilderbrand was adopted","03/09/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Be passed as amended","03/09/2022 - Senate Emergency Final Action - Passed as amended;  Yea: 33 Nay: 6","03/11/2022 - House Received and Introduced","03/11/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in House Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Allows a registered voter to be removed from the registration list if the voter has not responded to a notification, the notification was returned as undeliverable, and there has been no election-related activity for four years.

HISTORY: ["02/09/2021 - Senate Introduced","02/10/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Transparency and Ethics","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the county election commissioner to be appointed by a board of county commissioners.
  • Allows the board of county commissioners to remove the election commissioner for official misconduct and appoint a successor in case of vacancy.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2021 - House Introduced","01/13/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","02/01/2021 - House Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","02/01/2021 - House Committee Report recommending bill be passed by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/06/2021 - House Motion to suspend Joint Rule 4 (k) to allow consideration adopted;","05/06/2021 - House Committee of the Whole - Be passed","05/06/2021 - House Emergency Final Action - Passed;  Yea: 97 Nay: 24","05/07/2021 - Senate Received and Introduced","05/26/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/07/2022 - Senate Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","03/07/2022 - Senate Committee Report recommending substitute bill be passed by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/23/2022 - Senate Floor Amendment (Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Hilderbrand)","03/23/2022 - Senate Floor Amendment (Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Holscher)","03/23/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Committee Report be adopted recommending substitute bill be passed","03/23/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Holscher","03/23/2022 - Senate  Senator Hilderbrand raised a question of germaneness. The amendment was ruled not germane.","03/23/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Hilderbrand","03/23/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to rerefer to committee failed","03/23/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Amendment by  Senator Hilderbrand was adopted","03/23/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Substitute bill be passed as amended","03/23/2022 - Senate Emergency Final Action - Substitute passed as amended;  Yea: 22 Nay: 17","03/28/2022 - House Nonconcurred with amendments; Conference Committee requested; appointed Representative Barker , Representative Arnberger and Representative Miller as conferees","03/29/2022 - Senate Motion to accede adopted;  Senator Olson,  Senator Hilderbrand and  Senator Faust-Goudeau appointed as conferees","03/31/2022 - House  Representative Bergquist is appointed to replace  Representative Arnberger on the Conference Committee","04/01/2022 - Conference committee report","04/01/2022 - Senate Conference committee report now available","04/01/2022 - Senate Conference Committee Report was adopted;  Yea: 21 Nay: 17","05/23/2022 - House Died in Conference"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires remote ballot boxes be located in a municipal building where employees are physically present or located in another building and continuously observed by two authorized poll agents not registered to the same political party.
  • Removes the requirement that remote ballot boxes be continuously monitored by video recording equipment.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Requires applications for advance voting ballots to be submitted between 10 days before an election and 12:00 noon on the day before the election.
  • Prohibits the county election officer to transmit advance voting ballots until 23 days before an election.
  • Allows an advance voter to submit a ballot by depositing the ballot in a designated remote box, as well as other means.
  • Allows an advance voter submitting a ballot by mail to us the US Postal Service or any other delivery service providing a receipt verifying the ballot was delivered.
  • Requires advance voting ballots be received by the county election officer by 7:00pm on election day.
  • Requires county election officials to stop registering voters 23 days before the election, and to stop processing applications recieved from the division of motor vehicles 24 days before the election.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - House Introduced","02/10/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires recounts in counties with optical scanning systems or electronic voting systems to allow the method of the recount to be at the discretion of the person requesting it.
  • Outlines the process, supervision, and deadlines for requesting a recount.
  • Make conforming changes.
  • Requires that all electronic voting systems be certified in writing by the vendor that they cannot be connected to the internet or any computer or wireless network.
  • Requires the secretary of state and county election officer to inspect the system to verify compliance and to certify that the system is compliant.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - House Introduced","02/10/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits a county officer processing an incomplete advance voting application.
  • Prohibits a candidate from assisting any voter with voting or signing an application for advance voting, making it a violation a misdemeanor.
  • Includes in the definition of electioneering, a candidate who: handles a voter's ballot, distributes or counts ballots, obstructs a voter entering or leaving a voting place, or hinders an election worker from performing their duties.

HISTORY: ["02/04/2021 - Senate Introduced","02/05/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Transparency and Ethics","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that beginning at the general election in 2022, a county election commissioner will be elected to a four year term in each applicable county. 
  • Requires election commissioner to execute and file a corporate surety bond in an amount of at least $10,000.
  • Requires the commissioner be a qualified voter in the county.
  • Outlines procedures for a vacancy in the position.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["01/26/2021 - House Introduced","01/26/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/01/2021 - House Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","03/01/2021 - House Committee Report recommending bill be passed by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/02/2021 - House Committee of the Whole - Be passed","03/03/2021 - House Final Action - Passed;  Yea: 120 Nay: 4","03/03/2021 - Senate Received and Introduced","03/05/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/18/2021 - Senate Committee Report recommending substitute bill be passed by","04/07/2021 - Senate Floor Amendment (Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Alley)","04/07/2021 - Senate Floor Amendment (Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Peck)","04/07/2021 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Committee Report be adopted recommending substitute bill be passed","04/07/2021 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Alley","04/07/2021 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Amendment by  Senator Alley was adopted","04/07/2021 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Peck","04/07/2021 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Amendment by  Senator Peck was adopted  Yea: 20 Nay: 15","04/07/2021 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Substitute bill be passed as amended","04/08/2021 - Senate Final Action - Substitute passed as amended;  Yea: 33 Nay: 6","04/09/2021 - House Nonconcurred with amendments; Conference Committee requested; appointed Representative Barker , Representative Arnberger and Representative Ruiz, L. as conferees","05/03/2021 - Senate Motion to accede adopted;  Senator Alley,  Senator Hilderbrand and  Senator Faust-Goudeau appointed as conferees","03/30/2022 - Senate  Senator Olson is appointed to replace  Senator Alley on the Conference Committee","03/31/2022 - House  Representative Bergquist and  Representative Miller are appointed to replace  Representative Arnberger and  Representative Ruiz, L. on the Conference Committee","04/01/2022 - Conference committee report","04/01/2022 - Senate Conference committee report now available","04/01/2022 - Senate Conference Committee Report was adopted;  Yea: 28 Nay: 8","04/26/2022 - House Conference Committee Report was adopted;  Yea: 82 Nay: 40","04/27/2022 - House Reengrossed on Wednesday, April 27, 2022","05/23/2022 - House Enrolled and presented to Governor on Friday, May 6, 2022","05/23/2022 - House Approved by Governor on Tuesday, May 10, 2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides for the creation of an affidavit system to be utilized for the transfer of ballots, including penalties for violations.
  • Requires an audit in the year following the general election, in four counties, of election administration and election record procedures and outlines procedures for the audit. 
  • Requires all voting systems for elections held after January 1, 2024 to use specific ballot paper, with information about ballot, voting system, counting, and audit requirements.
  • Prohibits a candidate employed by the county election office to assist a voter, with certain exceptions.
  • Defines "candidate for office."
  • Establishes that if a voter's notice of removal of registration is returned as undeliverable, or if the voter has had no election related activity for four years, the person will be removed from the registration list.
  • Provides certain exceptions for electioneering.
  • Requires an audit of ballots in even number years that are within 1% of votes cast in 10% of involved counties, with certain requirements.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the availability of the publication of notice of audit.
  • Requires county election officers to provide electronic precinct level election results to specific offices no later than 30 days after the final canvas.
  • Defines electronic poll books and adds the term to Code related to electronic voting systems.
  • Prohibits electronic voting systems from having the capability to connect to the internet or other computer network and requires the equipment to be certified by the secretary of state.
  • Requires election judges to make all electronic voting systems and tabulating equipment available to any candidate or authorized agent for review to ensure lack of connectivity before, during, or after the election.
  • Requires public notice of testing of equipment to be places on a county website if the county has one.
  • Requires the test of equipment to occur within five business days of the completion of the canvas.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

COAUTHORS: ["Molly Baumgardner","J.R. Claeys","Renee Erickson","Michael Fagg","Richard Kloos","Virgil Peck","Mark Steffen","Alicia Straub","Mike Thompson","Richard Wilborn"]
HISTORY: ["01/11/2021 - Senate Prefiled for Introduction on Wednesday, January 6, 2021","01/11/2021 - Senate Introduced","01/12/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Prohibits anyone from backdating or otherwise altering the date of the mailing of an advance voting ballot.

COAUTHORS: ["Sydney Carlin","Stephanie Clayton","Linda Featherston","Dan Osman","Jason Probst","Tom Sawyer","Chuck Schmidt","Valdenia Winn","Brandon Woodard"]
HISTORY: ["02/08/2022 - House Introduced","02/08/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Judiciary","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes actions included in elector fraud and makes it a level 10 felony.
  • Defines "presidential electoral college certificate of vote."

HISTORY: ["02/02/2021 - Senate Introduced","02/03/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Authorizes mail ballot elections for a proposition to amend the state constitution where there is a concurrent resolution directing the Secretary of State to conduct a special mail ballot election.
  • Requires the election board of each county to make the original canvas of ballots and prepare the abstracts in such special mail ballot elections.

HISTORY: ["01/19/2022 - Senate Introduced","01/20/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/21/2022 - Senate Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","03/21/2022 - Senate Committee Report recommending bill be passed as amended by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/22/2022 - Senate Floor Amendment (Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Francisco)","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Committee Report be adopted","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Francisco","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Amendment by  Senator Francisco was adopted","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Francisco","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Amendment by  Senator Francisco was rejected","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Be passed as further amended","03/23/2022 - Senate Final Action - Passed as amended;  Yea: 29 Nay: 10","03/28/2022 - House Received and Introduced","03/28/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - House Died in House Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that the affidavit system for transfer of ballots applies to all ballots.
  • Establishes that is a violation to alter information on an affidavit or provide false information and that it is a level 9 felony.
  • Defines electronic poll book and adds it to the list of electronic voting systems in relevant legislation.
  • Prohibits electronic voting systems from having the capability to connect to the internet or any other computer network and requires the secretary of state to certify all electronic voting equipment used in elections after July 1, 2022.
  • Adds the county website to the list of places county election officials must publish a notice of equipment testing.
  • Requires electronic equipment be tested within five business days of the completion of a canvas.
  • Requires the secretary of state to adopt rules for the use of electronic poll books to process voters at polling places.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - House Introduced","02/10/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires all precinct committeemen and committeewomen to report certain identifying information to the county election officer, which will not be public record but will be disclosed to appropriate individuals.

HISTORY: ["02/22/2022 - Senate Introduced","02/23/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires candidates for certain offices to elect to have their political party designation added to their name and establishes that this rule supersedes other conflicting local rules.

HISTORY: ["02/04/2022 - Senate Introduced","02/07/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/07/2022 - Senate Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","03/07/2022 - Senate Committee Report recommending bill be passed as amended by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/22/2022 - Senate Floor Amendment (Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Hilderbrand)","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Committee Report be adopted","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Senator Hilderbrand","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Amendment by  Senator Hilderbrand was adopted","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Be passed as further amended","03/23/2022 - Senate Final Action - Passed as amended;  Yea: 38 Nay: 1","03/28/2022 - House Received and Introduced","03/28/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - House Died in House Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes the provision that a county selected in the three most recent audit cycles will not be selected again.
  • Requires an audit in even-numbered year elections where a certain race is within 1% of the total votes.
  • Requires the audit to be conducted in 10% of relevant county precincts, with a minimum of one in each of the counties.
  • Requires the publication of notice of the audit be made available to any authorized poll agent and provides other requirements.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - House Introduced","02/10/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires that advance voting ballots be received by appropriate authorities by 5:00pm on Election Day and prohibits officials and courts from changing the deadline.

HISTORY: ["01/11/2021 - House Prefiled for Introduction on Tuesday, December 8, 2020","01/11/2021 - House Introduced","01/11/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Enacts an interstate compact to elect the president by national popular vote.
  • Requires each state to conduct a statewide popular vote for US president and vice president.
  • Requires the chief election official to determine the popular vote in each state and produce a national popular vote total.
  • Requires the chief state election official to designate the presidential slate with the largest national popular vote total as the national popular vote winner, and to appoint electors accordingly. 
  • Outlines further requirements for: administration of the vote, the event of a tie, other administrative situations.
  • Requires the agreement to take effect when states with a majority of the electoral votes enact the agreement.
  • Outlines actions in the case of a state withdrawal.
  • Includes conforming changes.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["01/27/2022 - Senate Introduced","01/28/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/07/2022 - Senate Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","03/07/2022 - Senate Committee Report recommending bill be passed as amended by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/09/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Committee Report be adopted","03/09/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Motion to rerefer to committee failed","03/09/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Be passed as amended","03/09/2022 - Senate Emergency Final Action - Passed as amended;  Yea: 28 Nay: 12","03/11/2022 - House Received and Introduced","03/11/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - House Died in House Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill establishes that neither the governor nor any other executive officer may enter into an agreement with a court, or any other party, regarding the enforcement of election law or alteration of election procedures, without approval of the appropriate legislative body.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - House Introduced","02/10/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","03/01/2021 - House Committee on Elections Report","03/01/2021 - House Committee Report recommending bill be passed as amended by Committee on Elections","03/05/2021 - House Withdrawn from Calendar; Referred to Committee on Appropriations","03/10/2021 - House Withdrawn from  Committee on Appropriations and re-referred to Committee of the Whole","03/16/2021 - House Floor Amendment (Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Representative Finch)","03/16/2021 - House Committee of the Whole - Committee Report be adopted","03/16/2021 - House Committee of the Whole - Motion to Amend - Offered by  Representative Finch","03/16/2021 - House Committee of the Whole - Amendment by  Representative Finch was adopted","03/16/2021 - House Committee of the Whole - Be passed as amended","03/17/2021 - House Engrossed on Tuesday, March 16, 2021","03/17/2021 - House Final Action - Passed as amended;  Yea: 122 Nay: 1","03/17/2021 - Senate Received and Introduced","03/18/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Senate Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Adds changing or attempting to tamper with or conceal a cast ballot to the list of election crimes that are level 7 felonies. 
  • Adds attempting to change a vote by manipulating computer hardware or software, or attempting to change voter tabulation methods to produce false vote totals to the list of election crimes that are level 7 felonies.

HISTORY: ["02/09/2021 - Senate Introduced","02/10/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows any voter to apply for permanent advance voting status.
  • Requires the application for permanent advance voting status to include the requirements for maintaining the status.

HISTORY: ["02/08/2021 - Senate Introduced","02/09/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Eliminates the requirement that election commissioners be a voter and resident of the county in which they work for at least two years prior to appointment.

HISTORY: ["02/09/2022 - House Introduced","02/09/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows a candidate to request in writing a digital copy of all counted ballot images within 48 hours of the close of polls.
  • Requires the secretary of state to provide this information in digital format, with certain requirements.
  • Allows the secretary of state to create rules to implement this provision.
  • Exempts counties not using electronic voting systems or optical scanning equipment.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["02/08/2022 - Senate Introduced","02/09/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires that only locked ballot boxes located at the county election office or satellite advance voting site may be used for collecting advance voting ballots.
  • Requires ballot boxes to be located inside the building and be continuously observed by an employee while accessible to the public.

HISTORY: ["03/11/2021 - Senate Introduced","03/12/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires anyone delivering an advance voting ballot for a voter to have a written statement giving express permission.
  • Requires the written statement to be on a form created by the Secretary of State and to contain specified information.
  • Forbids anyone from delivering more than five advance voting ballots on behalf of other voters.
  • Establishes that a violation is a level 9 felony.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["02/08/2022 - Senate Introduced","02/09/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Transparency and Ethics","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the county chairperson appointing precinct committeemen and committeewomen to provide certain information regarding the appointees to the county election officer.
  • Requires the same information be requested if a committeeman or committeewoman is elected as a write in candidate.
  • Requires committeemen and committeewomen to update any changes to their information within 10 days of such a change.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Senate Introduced","01/26/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires a voter or other authorized person to return an advance voting ballot  in person or by mailing the ballot through the US Postal Service.

HISTORY: ["02/08/2021 - Senate Introduced","02/09/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Extends the advance voting window to start 40 days before an election.

HISTORY: ["03/11/2021 - Senate Introduced","03/12/2021 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - Senate Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Forbids election officials from accepting money or other items for expenses related to elections, except as provided by other laws.
  • Establishes that violation of this rule is a level 9 felony.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["01/25/2022 - Senate Introduced","01/26/2022 - Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/08/2022 - Senate Committee on Federal and State Affairs Report","03/08/2022 - Senate Committee Report recommending bill be passed as amended by Committee on Federal and State Affairs","03/14/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Committee Report be adopted","03/14/2022 - Senate Committee of the Whole - Be passed as amended","03/15/2022 - Senate Final Action - Passed as amended;  Yea: 27 Nay: 11","03/16/2022 - House Received and Introduced","03/16/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in House Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Establishes that certain paper ballots will be used, and certain procedures related to those ballots will be followed after January 1, 2024.

["02/01/2022 - House Introduced","02/01/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires advance voting ballots to be returned to the county election office by 7:00pm on election day.

HISTORY: ["01/27/2022 - House Introduced","01/27/2022 - House Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs","05/23/2022 - House Died in Committee"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires each county election officer to provide precinct level election results for all offices within 30 days of the final canvas, in electronic format.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits election officials from accepting or spending private money and includes penalties for violations.
  • Prohibits anyone from delivering an advance voting ballot on behalf of a voter, unless they submit a specified, sworn written statement with outlined information, and limits to ten the number of advance voting ballots that may be delivered. Provides for penalties for violations.
  • Outlines conduct that is false representation of an election official and provides penalties for violations. 
  • Requires the secretary of state to publish certain information regarding the number of registered voters monthly on the official website.
  • Prohibits candidates from assisting advance voting voters and provides penalties for violations.
  • Prohibits election officers from accepting mailed advance voting ballots unless they have a verified signature and specifies signature verification administration.
  • Prohibits anyone from backdating or altering a postmark or other evidence of the date of the mailing of a ballot, and provides penalties.
  • Adds certain actions by candidates to the definition of electioneering and provides certain exceptions.
  • Defines relevant terms.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits the executive branch and the judicial branch from modifying state election law.
  • Restricts the secretary of state's ability to enter into agreements with a court regarding enforcement of election law or alteration of election procedure.
  • Requires the county election officer to maintain a database of voters' residential and mailing addresses.
  • Requires those who solicit voters to file an application for advance voting to include a conspicuous label on the exterior envelope of the mailing, and information on certain other pages, stating certain disclosures and providing identifying information.
  • Requires solicitors to be residents of the state.
  • Requires that the advance voting application included in the mailing be the official application issued by the secretary of state, and that no portion be prefilled.
  • Requires that a pre-addressed envelope to the appropriate county official be included in the mailing and prohibits anyone to direct the applicant to send the application back to themselves.
  • Provides exemptions.
  • Classifies violations as a class C misdemeanor.
  • Includes a process for filing related complaints and outlines penalties.
  • Adds examples of election tampering including changing or attempting to change a ballot, election machine, or vote counting equipment.
  • Provides for appointive authority in cases where none is designated.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Outlines provisions for a temporary vacancy created by an officer's military service, including temporary appointments and processes.

HISTORY: ["01/11/2021 - House Prefiled for Introduction on Tuesday, December 22, 2020","01/11/2021 - House Introduced","01/11/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","01/13/2021 - House Withdrawn from  Committee on Elections; Referred to Committee on Judiciary","02/26/2021 - House Committee on Judiciary Report","02/26/2021 - House Committee Report recommending bill be passed as amended by Committee on Judiciary","03/05/2021 - House Stricken from Calendar by Rule 1507"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes the Secretary of State from the list of agencies empowered to prosecute election crime, leaving the county or district attorney and the attorney general.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to promptly inform the county or district attorney if the Secretary of State discovers evidence of election crimes.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide assistance in the investigation and prosecution of election crimes.

HISTORY: ["02/11/2021 - House Introduced","02/11/2021 - House Referred to Committee on Elections","02/24/2021 - House Committee Report recommending bill be passed and placed on Consent Calendar by","03/02/2021 - House Withdrawn from Consent Calendar and placed on General Orders","03/05/2021 - House Stricken from Calendar by Rule 1507"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that elections for municipal bonds (with certain exceptions) must be held 45-60 days after compliance with required procedures.
  • Removes the requirement that an election commissioner be a resident of the county for at least two years prior to appointment.
  • Amends the minimum population required for the appointment of an election commissioner to 130,000 residents (from 100,000).
  • Requires mail ballots received within three days after an election, but postmarked by close of business on election day, to be canvassed.
  • Requires the county election officer to attempt to contact voters whose mail ballots lack a signature, or if the signature does not match, and allow them the opportunity to correct it before the start of the final county canvas.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires the Attorney General to conduct independent inquiries of potential election irregularities in 12 counties each election, an increase from five percent of counties. This bill removes the use of a credit or debit card as a voter's secondary form of proof of identification. This bill requires the State Board of Elections to approve all voting equipment by January 1, 2024, and prohibits the approval of any equipment capable of connecting to any network, including the Internet, or with any external device. This bill also sets out the county clerk's duties related to securing and protecting voting equipment by expanding the time in which voting equipment is to remain locked after an election and requiring that voting equipment and ballot boxes remain under video surveillance.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill adds the definition of an e-poll book to existing election law and excludes it from the definition of voting machine and voting systems. An e-poll book is defined as an electronic device capable of holding a file of voter data and related information for use in identifying registered voters prior to a voter's receiving or casting a ballot, and allowing a voter to electronically sign in on an electronic registered voter roster in lieu of signing a paper registered voter roster. This bill allows the State Board of Elections to choose to provide master lists of registered voters in electronic format to county clerks for use in e-poll books during an election and permits the State Board of Elections to examine any voter registration system maintained by a county clerk, including e-poll books, to establish the security of the system and its components, with a report to be provided to the county board of elections.
