BILLSUMMARY: This bill would require that early-voting locations be open at least eight hours per day on the Thursday, Friday, and Saturday immediately preceding an election. It would also establish a separate six-day period (preceding the early voting period) during which voters meeting certain eligibility criteria can vote by in-person absentee ballot. This bill would prohibit the use of voting equipment that connects to the internet and would bar any person from transmitting or publicizing any election results until 6 p.m. on the day of the election. This bill would also specify that voting eligibility is limited to U.S. citizens.

HISTORY: ["01/20/2022 - Introduced in House","01/20/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)","03/02/2022 - to Elections, Const. Amendments & Intergovernmental Affairs (H)","03/03/2022 - House Committee On Elections, Constitutional Amendments, And Intergovernmental Affairs (10:00 3/3/2022 Annex Room 169)","03/03/2022 - reported favorably, 1st reading, to Calendar","03/04/2022 - 2nd reading, to Rules","03/09/2022 - posted for passage in the Regular Orders of the Day for Thursday, March 10, 2022","03/29/2022 - taken from the Orders of the Day","03/29/2022 - recommitted to Appropriations & Revenue (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would make it a Class B misdemeanor for a candidate or committee, or any person acting on behalf of a candidate or committee, to pay to transport a voter to the polls.

HISTORY: ["01/12/2022 - Introduced in House","01/12/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)","01/19/2022 - to Elections, Const. Amendments & Intergovernmental Affairs (H)","01/20/2022 - House Committee On Elections, Constitutional Amendments, And Intergovernmental Affairs (10:00 1/20/2022 Annex Room 169)","01/20/2022 - reported favorably, 1st reading, to Calendar with Committee Substitute","01/21/2022 - 2nd reading, to Rules","01/21/2022 - posted for passage in the Regular Orders of the Day for Monday, January 24, 2022","01/21/2022 - House Committee Substitute 1","01/27/2022 - floor amendment (1) filed to Committee Substitute","01/28/2022 - House Floor Amendment 1","03/10/2022 - taken from the Orders of the Day","03/10/2022 - RETURNED TO RULES","03/29/2022 - recommitted to Appropriations & Revenue (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows a candidate whose district number is altered by redistricting or reapportionment the ability to use funds contained in his or her campaign account for an election in their new district.

COAUTHORS: ["Jennifer Decker","Jim Gooch","C. Edward Massey","Bobby McCool","Sal Santoro","Nancy Tate"]
HISTORY: ["01/13/2022 - Introduced in House","01/13/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)","02/01/2022 - to Elections, Const. Amendments & Intergovernmental Affairs (H)","02/10/2022 - House Committee On Elections, Constitutional Amendments, And Intergovernmental Affairs (10:00 2/10/2022 Annex Room 169)","02/10/2022 - House Committee On Elections, Constitutional Amendments, And Intergovernmental Affairs (00:00 2/10/2022 Annex Room 169)","02/11/2022 - reported favorably, 1st reading, to Calendar with Committee Substitute (1)","02/11/2022 - floor amendment (1) filed to Committee Substitute","02/12/2022 - Corrections Impact to House Committee Substitute 1","02/12/2022 - Local Mandate to House Committee Substitute 1","02/12/2022 - House Committee Substitute 1","02/12/2022 - House Floor Amendment 1","02/14/2022 - 2nd reading, to Rules","02/15/2022 - posted for passage in the Regular Orders of the Day for Wednesday, February 16, 2022","02/17/2022 - 3rd reading, passed 75-22 with Committee Substitute (1) and Floor Amendment (1)","02/18/2022 - Received in Senate","02/18/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","02/22/2022 - to State & Local Government (S)","03/02/2022 - Senate Committee On State And Local Government (00:00 3/2/2022 Annex Room 131)","03/02/2022 - reported favorably, 1st reading, to Calendar","03/03/2022 - 2nd reading, to Rules","03/03/2022 - floor amendment (1) filed","03/03/2022 - posted for passage in the Regular Orders of the Day for Monday, March 07, 2022","03/04/2022 - Senate Floor Amendment 1","03/07/2022 - 3rd reading, passed 27-4 with Floor Amendment (1)","03/08/2022 - received in House","03/08/2022 - to Rules (H)","03/09/2022 - taken from Rules (H)","03/09/2022 - posted for passage for concurrence in Senate floor amendment (1)","03/10/2022 - House concurred in Senate floor amendment (1)","03/10/2022 - passed 77-18","03/11/2022 - enrolled, signed by Speaker of the House","03/11/2022 - enrolled, signed by President of the Senate","03/11/2022 - delivered to governor","03/24/2022 - became law without Governor's Signature (Acts Ch. 23)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires all costs and expenses related to election administration be paid for with public funds. This bill prohibits a state or local government employee from accepting anything of value to assist with election administration unless procured through a lawful contract. This bill requires a state or local government employee to disclose, in writing and within five days, to the Governor and the General Assembly, any communication related to election laws and election administration from a federal executive branch agency. This bill also prohibits the State Board of Elections, county clerks, and local government employees from accepting any private funds to assist with voter registration activities unless accepted as part of a valid contract.

HISTORY: ["12/10/2021 - Prefiled by the sponsor(s).","01/04/2022 - Introduced in House","01/04/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)","01/26/2022 - to Elections, Const. Amendments & Intergovernmental Affairs (H)","02/10/2022 - House Committee On Elections, Constitutional Amendments, And Intergovernmental Affairs (10:00 2/10/2022 Annex Room 169)","02/10/2022 - House Committee On Elections, Constitutional Amendments, And Intergovernmental Affairs (00:00 2/10/2022 Annex Room 169)","03/14/2022 - taken from Elections, Const. Amendments & Intergovernmental Affairs (H)","03/14/2022 - 1st reading","03/14/2022 - returned to Elections, Const. Amendments & Intergovernmental Affairs (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would establish a non-partisan system for electing the offices of Commonwealth's attorney, circuit clerk, county attorney, county clerk, sheriff, jailer, and coroner.

HISTORY: ["03/03/2022 - Introduced in Senate","03/03/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","03/07/2022 - to State & Local Government (S)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would permit any qualified voter the ability to vote in-person absentee during normal business hours on at least any of the twelve working days and two Saturdays before an election. This bill would also require that each county board of elections petition for, and use, a vote center on election day.

HISTORY: ["03/03/2022 - Introduced in Senate","03/03/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","03/07/2022 - to State & Local Government (S)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would redefine the terms "absentee ballot," "ballot," "multilingual ballot," "election," "multilingual voter registration form," and "voter" under state law. Additionally, it would require the State Board of Elections to create and make available multilingual voter registration forms, and require them to be both posted online and provided to the county clerk. It would require the board to promulgate administrative regulations to create, furnish, and process multilingual voter registration forms and require the State Board of Elections to establish a multilingual ballot hotline. This bill would also require the State Board of elections to give notice to voters of the availability of the multilingual ballot hotline and other multilingual voter materials, including the availability of a multilingual mail-in absentee ballot. Furthermore, this bill would require voting equipment and systems to have the ability to accept multilingual ballots, require the readiness of multilingual ballots and absentee ballots for an election, require multilingual voter instruction cards for use during an election, require the county board of elections to provide special training to election officials regarding multilingual ballots and information relating to the multilingual ballot hotline, and require translation assistance with a voter's oath.

HISTORY: ["03/02/2022 - Introduced in Senate","03/02/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","03/03/2022 - to State & Local Government (S)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would make a technical change to an existing election law, substituting "county chair" for the existing language, which reads: "county chairman."

HISTORY: ["03/02/2022 - Introduced in Senate","03/02/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","03/03/2022 - to State & Local Government (S)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would make a technical change to an existing election law, substituting "state chair" for the existing language, which reads: "state chairman."

HISTORY: ["03/01/2022 - Introduced in House","03/01/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would include a new requirement for a county board of elections' petition for consolidating precincts before the State Board of Elections. Namely, it would require that the Board take into consideration the time it takes for a voter who is of the furthest distance geographically and the time it takes for a voter who is of the furthest distance as measured by an interval of time to travel by car, or public transportation, if available, to the voting location where his or her consolidated precinct is located.

HISTORY: ["02/28/2022 - Introduced in House","02/28/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would allow school districts to remain open if an individual school within the district is used as a polling location for an election. Additionally, this bill would permit a school district to include additional days within their nontraditional instruction plan for each school district that closes to allow schools in the district to be used as a polling place for an election.

HISTORY: ["02/25/2022 - Introduced in House","02/25/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would require elections for the offices of county commissioner, soil and water conservation officer, board of education, mayor, municipal legislative members, city ward, and all other city offices, have a partisan primary or proceed as partisan general elections. This bill would also allow for the use of a transcript from an accredited college to satisfy the requisite for school board candidacy eligibility, require school board candidates to have emblems of political party affiliation presented on the ballot.

HISTORY: ["02/24/2022 - Introduced in House","02/24/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would make a technical change to an existing election law, substituting "state chair" for the existing language, which reads: "state chairman."

HISTORY: ["02/22/2022 - Introduced in House","02/22/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would require the State Board of Education to include instruction on "how to cast a ballot" within their annual public education program to high school juniors and seniors.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2022 - Introduced in Senate","02/10/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","02/14/2022 - to State & Local Government (S)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would require that a voter be a resident of the state and precinct on or before the day of a primary or an election in order to register. Additionally, this bill would allow a person who is not a registered voter prior to the time that the registration books are closed, and who possesses all other qualifications for voter registration, to register at the person's precinct of residence on the day of a primary or an election if the person confirms his or her identity and completes the registration form and required oath. This bill also specifies that timely receipt for precinct voter registration is on the day of a primary or an election, requires the county clerk to provide the State Board of Elections with a report of the number of voters registering to vote at the precincts on the day of a primary or an election, and provides that each application for a motor vehicle driver's license shall be a simultaneous application for voter registration unless declined by the applicant. Further, this bill would provide "convenience of the voter" as a basis for absentee voting and permit any qualified voter the ability to vote in-person absentee during normal business hours on at least any of the twelve working days and/or the two Saturdays prior to election day. This bill would also extend the ending voting hours from 6 p.m. to 7 p.m., as well as require that if the person is not listed on a precinct roster, that the person, subject to some requirements, be given the opportunity to register and to vote at the precinct on the day of an election.

HISTORY: ["02/14/2022 - Introduced in House","02/14/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would define "election officer" as any person tasked with election administration within the state, including, but not limited to, the Secretary of State and his or her employees, members of the State Board of Elections and staff, members of county boards of elections and staff, county clerks and staff, precinct election officers, election officials, and poll workers.

HISTORY: ["01/19/2022 - Introduced in House","01/19/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)","02/08/2022 - Bill has been withdrawn from consideration"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Sets the filing deadline for the 2022 primary as May 31, 2022, 4:00pm.
  • Sets the 2022 primary as the first Tuesday in August.
  • Allows the Secretary of State to determine the time of drawing for ballot positions for the 2022 primary following related guidelines.
  • Allows the Secretary of State to determine other deadlines needed for the 2022 primary election.
  • Declares an emergency as a requirement to extend the deadline for redistricting legislation to be passed.

HISTORY: ["01/27/2022 - Introduced in Senate","01/27/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","02/07/2022 - to Banking & Insurance (S)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would remove a student or employee identification document as acceptable forms of voter ID. This bill would also prevent the use of a credit or debit card as a secondary form of identification to confirm a voter's identity.

HISTORY: ["02/01/2022 - Introduced in House","02/01/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
This bill would require that a voter be a resident of the state and precinct on or before the day of a primary or an election for voter registration purposes. It would, nevertheless, allow a person who is not a registered voter prior to the time that the registration books are closed, and who possesses all other qualifications for voter registration, to register at the person's precinct of residence on the day of a primary or an election if the person confirms his or her identity, completes the registration form, and affirms the required oath. This bill also specifies that timely receipt for precinct voter registration is on the day of a primary or an election. Additionally, this bill requires the county clerk to provide the State Board of Elections with a report of the number of voters registering to vote at the precincts on the day of a primary or an election and provides that each application for a motor vehicle driver's license shall be a simultaneous application for voter registration unless declined by the applicant. Further, this bill provide that each application filed through a designated voter registration agency shall be a simultaneous application for voter registration unless declined by the applicant. 

Moreover, this bill provides that "convenience of the voter" may be a basis for absentee voting and permits any qualified voter the ability to vote in-person absentee during normal business hours on at least any of the 12 working days and 2 Saturdays before an election. This bill also extends the ending voting hours from 6 p.m. to 7 p.m.. and requires that if the person is not listed on the precinct roster, that the person be given the opportunity to register and to vote at the precinct on the day of an election.

HISTORY: ["01/11/2022 - Introduced in Senate","01/11/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","01/13/2022 - to State & Local Government (S)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would require certain candidates for office to be elected by ranked-choice voting and establish the process relating thereto. Additionally, this bill would require voting machines be equipped to allow for ranked-choice voting and require the county board of elections to provide ranked-choice voting training to election officers.

HISTORY: ["01/07/2022 - Introduced in Senate","01/07/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","01/10/2022 - to State & Local Government (S)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would mandate new requirements for voting equipment. This bill would also provide additional instructions for voter instruction cards, as well as change requirements for ballot counting, tabulation, and certification of election results. Lastly, this bill would require the State Board of Elections to notify a voter of the effect of casting multiple ballots for a single office on a paper ballot.

HISTORY: ["01/04/2022 - Introduced in House","01/04/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)","01/04/2022 - to Elections, Const. Amendments & Intergovernmental Affairs (H)","01/05/2022 - House Committee On Elections, Constitutional Amendments, And Intergovernmental Affairs (12:00 1/5/2022 Annex Room 154)","01/05/2022 - reported favorably","01/05/2022 - 1st reading","01/05/2022 - 2nd and 3rd readings dispensed with","01/05/2022 - placed in the Orders of the Day","01/05/2022 - passed 84-12","01/05/2022 - Received in Senate","01/05/2022 - to Committee on Committees (S)","01/05/2022 - to State & Local Government (S)","01/06/2022 - Senate Committee On State And Local Government (00:00 1/6/2022 Annex Room 171)","01/06/2022 - reported favorably","01/06/2022 - 1st reading","01/06/2022 - to Rules (S)","01/06/2022 - posted for passage in the Regular Orders of the Day for Thursday, January 06, 2022","01/06/2022 - 2nd and 3rd readings dispensed with","01/06/2022 - passed 28-4","01/06/2022 - received in House","01/06/2022 - enrolled, signed by Speaker of the House","01/06/2022 - enrolled, signed by President of the Senate","01/06/2022 - delivered to governor","01/06/2022 - signed by Governor (Acts ch. 1)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This emergency bill extended the filing deadline for all candidates running in the 2022 Primary to January 25, 2022. This bill also permitted the Secretary of State, or the county clerk, depending on the office, to determine when the drawing for ballot positions and certifications would be held. This bill also permitted the Secretary of State or the county clerk to establish any other necessary elections deadlines for the 2022 primary, excluding the date of the primary.

HISTORY: ["12/08/2021 - Prefiled by the sponsor(s).","01/04/2022 - Introduced in House","01/04/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would allow a registered independent to vote in the primary of one political party and provide that voting equipment be adjusted to allow this to occur. This bill would also define a "registered independent" as a voter who is not registered as a member of a political party, political organization, or political group.

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Flood","Patti Minter","Ruth Palumbo","Josie Raymond","Attica Scott","Pamela Stevenson"]
HISTORY: ["09/15/2021 - Prefiled by the sponsor(s).","01/04/2022 - Introduced in House","01/04/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would extend the deadline for voting from 6 p.m. to 7 p.m. Specifically, this bill would mandate that the last voter already waiting in line at 7 p.m. be permitted to vote, and that the precinct election sheriff wait in line with that final voter to inform anyone who subsequently arrives at the polls after 7 p.m. that they will not be permitted to vote. This bill would also prevent the release of absentee ballot results until 7 p.m. on election day.

HISTORY: ["09/24/2021 - Prefiled by the sponsor(s).","01/04/2022 - Introduced in House","01/04/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would remove straight ticket voting, wherein a voter is given the option to vote for all candidates of a political party as opposed to individually selecting candidates in each office listed on the ballot, as a ballot option in any election.

HISTORY: ["12/10/2021 - Prefiled by the sponsor(s).","01/04/2022 - Introduced in House","01/04/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires any person with a local government contract related to election administration to disclose to the state Attorney General or Secretary of State communications from any entity or person from a foreign country, any federal government agency, or any federal official. This bill prohibits any local government of this state from accepting private monetary funds to assist with election administration unless entered into as a lawful contract for goods or services. This bill would also prohibit voting equipment and voting systems from being capable of connecting to a public network, including the Internet, and require the county clerk to ensure that the voting equipment or voting system used in an election is not connected to a public network, including the Internet. This bill would also prohibit an election official from transmitting any election results to anyone not authorized by law to receive it. Lastly, this bill would make it a Class D felony to knowingly and willfully directly connect, or attempt to directly connect, a voting system or voting equipment to a public network, including the Internet.

HISTORY: ["01/04/2022 - Introduced in House","01/04/2022 - to Committee on Committees (H)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill would extend the deadline to change one's party affiliation on his or her voter registration from December 31 immediately preceding the primary election to 30 days immediately preceding the primary election.

HISTORY: ["03/02/2022 - Prefiled.","03/02/2022 - Under the rules, provisionally referred to the Committee on House and Governmental Affairs.","03/04/2022 - First appeared in the Interim Calendar on 3/4/2022.","03/14/2022 - Read by title, under the rules, referred to the Committee on House and Governmental Affairs.","03/30/2022 - House Committee on  (09:00 3/30/2022 )","04/12/2022 - House Committee on  (09:00 4/12/2022 )","04/18/2022 - House Committee Amendment #2706 H&G Draft","04/19/2022 - House Committee on  (09:00 4/19/2022 )","04/19/2022 - Reported with amendments (9-5).","04/20/2022 - Read by title, amended, ordered engrossed, passed to 3rd reading.","04/20/2022 - House Committee Amendment #2810 H&G Proposed","04/21/2022 - Scheduled for floor debate on 04/27/2022.","04/27/2022 - Read by title, returned to the calendar.","04/27/2022 - Called from the calendar.","04/27/2022 - Read third time by title, roll called on final passage, yeas 66, nays 27. Read first time by title and placed on the Calendar for a second reading.","05/02/2022 - Read second time by title and referred to the Committee on Senate and Governmental Affairs.","05/25/2022 - Senate Committee on Senate and Governmental Affairs (09:30 5/25/2022 Room F)","05/25/2022 - Reported favorably.","05/26/2022 - Read by title and referred to the Legislative Bureau.","05/31/2022 - Reported without Legislative Bureau amendments. Read by title and passed to third reading and final passage.","06/01/2022 - Rules suspended. Read by title, passed by a vote of 35 yeas and 0 nays, and ordered returned to the House. Motion to reconsider tabled.","06/01/2022 - Received from the Senate without amendments.","06/02/2022 - Enrolled and signed by the Speaker of the House.","06/03/2022 - Signed by the President of the Senate on 6/2/2022.","06/03/2022 - Sent to the Governor for executive approval.","06/27/2022 - Vetoed by the Governor."]
BILLSUMMARY:
This bill would mandate that any election official who receives a federal directive or guidance pertaining to elections that is not already published on the Secretary of State's website must notify the governor, the speaker of the Louisiana House of Representatives, and the president of the Louisiana Senate within five business days after receipt. Additionally, this bill would prohibit election officials from implementing any federal directive or guidance pertaining to elections without the explicit state or federal legal requirement to do so, or prior approval of the House Committee on House and Governmental Affairs and the Senate Committee on Senate and Governmental Affairs, and consultation with the Secretary of State. Further, this bill requires that if a state or federal law does not explicitly require the election official to implement the directive or guidance, an official nevertheless wishing to do so must request the approval of such implementation from the House Committee on House and Governmental Affairs and the Senate Committee on Senate and Governmental Affairs. Requests to implement non-mandatory guidance would have to be delivered to the chairman of each committee. 

The election official would then implement or refrain from implementing the directive or guidance as follows: (a) If both committees vote to approve implementation, and after consultation with the Secretary of State, the official must implement the directive or guidance. (b) If neither committee votes to prohibit implementation within thirty days after receipt of the request from the official, the official shall implement the directive or guidance. (c) If either committee votes to prohibit the implementation within thirty days after receipt of the request from the official, and after consulting with the Secretary of State, the official must not implement the directive or guidance. 

This bill also would prohibit election officials from accepting or dispersing new federal elections funds without an explicit state or federal legal requirement to do so, or prior approval of the Joint Legislative Committee on the Budget. Further, if a state or federal law does not explicitly require the election official to accept and disperse the particular federal election funds, an official who wishes to accept and disperse such funds must request the approval of such acceptance and dispersal from the Joint Legislative Committee on the Budget, after consulting with the Secretary of State. Such a request must also be delivered to the chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on the Budget. The official must then accept and disperse the funds or refrain from accepting and dispersing the funds as follows: (a) If the committee votes to authorize acceptance and dispersal of such funds, and after consultation with the Secretary of State, the official must accept and disperse the funds. (b) If the committee does not vote to disapprove the acceptance and dispersal of funds within thirty days after receipt of the request from the official, the official shall accept and disperse the funds. (c) If the committee votes to disapprove the acceptance and dispersal of funds within thirty days after receipt of the request from the official, and after consultation with the Secretary of State, the official must not accept or disperse the funds. Lastly, this bill would mandate the Attorney General pursue any available legal means to enjoin any official who accepts and disperses federal election funds in violation of these guidelines.

BILLSUMMARY:
This bill would deem any absentee mail ballot with an affidavit flap missing any information required to be completed by the voter that is not cured by the voter be deemed as challenged. Further, this bill specifies that if that challenge is because the affidavit flap of the absentee by mail ballot is missing the voter's signature, his mother's maiden name, or, if applicable, the signature of the witness, the challenge must be sustained and the vote not counted. This bill further requires that if a challenge is sustained, the vote shall not be counted, and mandates the board write "rejected" and the reason for the rejection across the ballot envelope, then place the rejected ballot in the special absentee by mail ballot envelope or container. The bill then requires the board of elections notify the voter in writing of the challenge and the reasoning, on a form provided by the Secretary of State, and signed by at least a majority of the members of the board. This notice must be given within four business days, by mail, and addressed to the voter at his place of residence, and the board must retain a copy of the notification. 

Additionally, this bill would require the Secretary of State adopt procedural rules to implement this absentee ballot challenge. These rules, per the bill, would be required to include the following: (1) The preprinting of information on the affidavit flap of an absentee ballot by mail in a form prescribed by the Secretary of State, including but not limited to the date of the election and the ward and precinct of the voter. (2) A uniform, standard challenge process and procedure with regards to the items missing on the affidavit flap of an absentee by mail ballot and determinations made by the board.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill would mandate that before primary elections, the parish board of election supervisors must publish the location of the polling places in the parish at least once on the website of the secretary of state, and may be published on websites maintained by parish election officials, including the registrar of voters and clerk of court. The bill further requires that each website include instructions on how a voter may subscribe to receive electronic notifications of polling place location changes. Additionally, the bill would require any governing authority inform the Secretary of State of all polling place location changes and mandate that the Secretary of State also list polling place location changes on his or her website alongside instructions on how a voter may subscribe to receive electronic notifications of polling place location changes.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Department of State to yearly conduct a supplemental canvas, the purpose of which is to identify other voters who moved and need to update their registration address.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to identify: voters whose address was not updated, voters who have not voted, or engaged in other voter activities in ten years.
  • Requires the Department of State to send identified voters a "supplemental address confirmation card" and place the voter on the inactive voter list.
  • Defines "supplemental address conformation card" and provides for its development.
  • Outlines actions if a voter responds to the card in specific ways.
  • Requires a record of those who were mailed cards and their responses be kept for two years.
  • Requires names and addresses of voters whose registration is inactive by publisehd 90 days before an election.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill would mandate that if an absentee ballot is hand delivered, the voter or a person authorized by the voter, must deliver the ballot to the registrar or to an employee of the registrar at either the registrar's principal office or the registrar's branch office, as long as the ballot is returned during the absentee voting time period. Otherwise, this bill would allow for an absentee ballot to be delivered to an early voting location in the parish in which the voter is registered to vote, as long as the ballot is returned during the applicable period of time established for early voting.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill would empower the Secretary of State to make changes to deadlines, equipment, staffing, and polling locations after the governor declares a state of emergency within forty-five days prior to an election. This bill sets out a process for the Secretary of State to follow in the event of such an emergency, including a requirement that the Secretary of State submit notice of such problems and proposed solutions to both the House and Senate committees on governmental affairs as well as the governor's office. Following such notice, the bill allows the Secretary of State to take "necessary actions" to ensure the successful execution of the election to ensure safe, secure, and accessible elections. This bill then requires that the Secretary of State post a list of all changed polling locations on the Secretary of State's website and that the Department of State provide a report to the legislature of actions taken under this bill within fifteen days following the election.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill would prohibit the use of private funds for election-related expenses. Specifically, it would forbid state and local officials from soliciting, accepting, using, or disposing of any donation in the form of money, grants, property, or personal services from individuals or profit or nonprofit corporations, for the purpose of paying costs related to conducting elections. Conversely, this bill excludes from that prohibition the solicitation, acceptance, use, or disposal of campaign contributions or in-kind contributions by any candidate for public office for the purpose of meeting expenses related to seeking that office as well as the donation or use of equipment for the restoration and maintenance of utilities to a precinct or polling place in the event of an outage.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Adds "disaster" to possible states of emergency.
  • Adds "other impairments that affect participation in or the integrity of the electoral process" as a potential problem in an emergency situation.
  • Requires the Senate Committee on Senate and Governmental Affairs and the House Committee on House and Governmental Affairs to meet within 10 days of receiving a certification of state of emergency.
  • Allows the Secretary of State to present alternative written emergency plans at the meeting.
  • Allows the Secretary of State to determine was is feasible in the emergency situation to conduct early voting in all parishes.
  • Requires emergency plans and alternatives be submitted to the joint committee and governor at the same time as the emergency certification is submitted or as soon as possible.
  • Allows the Secretary of State to incorporate changes into the emergency plan as suggested by the governor or the joint committee.
  • Provides for the legislature to override a governor's veto of an emergency plan.
  • Requires the joint committee to send the governor a notice of each meeting held and allows the governor to attend the meetings and provide recommendations.
  • Provides for the timely distribution and collection of ballots.
  • Provides timelines for delivery and return of ballots in an emergency and outlines requirements for distribution, administration, and record keeping. 
  • Requires the governor to approve or reject an emergency plan by five days after he or she receives the certified tabulation sheet.
  • Outlines procedures for if the plan is approved or denied, including override procedures.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Makes exceptions to regulations regarding the Voter Registration Administrators Certification Program for a state of emergency, allowing those who completed the course within six years to serve in the roll.
  • Extends deadlines for certification renewal requirements of election personnel in a state of emergency.
  • Removes the option of early voting in the office of the registrar for voters who registered by mail and have not previously voted in the parish.
  • Expands the specialists who can submit a certification of disability to include optometrists, physician assistants, and nurse practitioners.
  • Allows the Department of State or registrar of voters to transmit certain information about a registered voter to the Department of Health to amend a voter's birth certificate.
  • Requires the secretary of state to publish a proclamation made by the governor immediately after it is issued.
  • Requires the secretary of state to produce a report on the number of qualified electors for a recall petition and to notify the registrar of voters.
  • Provides that the specifications of the absentee ballot envelope will be determined by the secretary of state.
  • Allows early voting when an elector has out-of-parish work responsibilities.
  • Outlines a system for adding early voting commissioners if within one year of an emergency the registrar of voters determines there is a shortage due to displacement.
  • Revises reporting requirements for counting absentee and early voting ballots, requiring them to be entered by members of the board, and a copy of the final report by posted at the location where tabulation occurred and at the office of the registrar of voters.
  • Requires the registrar to preserve absentee and early voting ballots and not allow their inspection until recounting is complete.
  • Provides for alternate designees to serve on the board of election supervisors.
  • Provides rules for compensation of board members.
  • Changes deadlines for course completion for commissioners-in-charge in the case of a state of emergency.
  • Allows the secretary of state to contract for delivery of voting machines within certain timeframes.
  • Requires the contract be advertised and allow for bids in accordance with current rules.
  • Outlines certain timeline and security requirements for the contractor and election authorities.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Creates a task force to develop "pragmatic and equitable solutions" to increase early voting turnout, with consideration to cost, voting locations, and logistics.
  • Lists required members of the task force and outlines the appointment process.
  • Outlines how the task force should operate.
  • Requires the secretary of state to provide support and staff for the task force. 
  • Provides that the task force will terminate with the submission of the report.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill would mandate that if the unexpired term of an office for which a vacancy has been filled by an appointee is one year or more and the vacancy occurs within one year of the first election at which a redistricting plan adopted following the most recent federal census is to be utilized, no special election will be called and the appointee shall serve the remainder of the term of office.

BILLSUMMARY: This resolution would create a task force to study the voting rights of persons with disabilities and the procedures available to assist voters with disabilities to cast their votes. This task force would be required to report its findings to the Legislature of Louisiana prior to February 1, 2023.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill would prohibit an elected official who has retired or resigned from state or local elective office to be appointed to succeed himself in the office from which he retired or resigned. This bill would also prohibit an elected official who has retired or resigned from state or local elective office from being deemed eligible as a candidate at an election called to fill the vacancy created by his or her retirement or resignation of that office.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill would establish that for the purposes of voter registration and voting, the residence of a person who is incarcerated for the conviction of a felony shall be in this state and in the parish, municipality, if any, and precinct in which he is counted for redistricting purposes by the state. This bill would also repeal existing provisions of law relating to the suspension of registration and voting rights based on a person's conviction of a felony.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill would mandate that only a citizen of the United States is eligible to register to vote in the state. This bill would also establish the method for proving citizenship, including either a legible photocopy of the applicant's birth certificate that verifies citizenship, the applicant's United States passport, a legible photocopy of the pertinent pages of the applicant's United States passport identifying the applicant and the applicant's passport number, the applicant's United States naturalization documents, the number of the certificate of naturalization, any other documents or methods of proof that are established pursuant to the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, or the applicant's Bureau of Indian Affairs card number, tribal treaty card number, or tribal enrollment number. This bill also provides that proof of voter registration from another state is not evidence of citizenship, nor is a driver's license or REAL ID.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the registrar to close registration records 15 days before an election when an emergency is declared.
  • Requires the secretary of state to post a list of all changed polling locations on the secretary of state's website in an emergency.
  • Allows the clerk of court to contact voters via phone or email to inform them of changes in a state of emergency.
  • Allows the secretary of state to take necessary actions to ensure successful execution of an election after the governor issues a state of emergency.
  • Provides that if a state of emergency is declared within 15 days of an election, all ballots received within three days following the election will be counted.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill proposes a referendum for a constitutional amendment to eliminate the gubernatorial appointment of three members of the State Board of Elementary and Secondary Education. If adopted, the amendment would provide for an all-elected membership of the Board and and reduce its membership from eleven to eight.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires affected voters be notified of polling place changes via phone or electronic means in a state of emergency.
  • Requires the parish board of election supervisors to publish polling place locations on websites maintained by parish officials and by the secretary of state, where applicable.
  • Requires the governing authority to inform the secretary of state of all polling place changes.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Replaces the term "reapportionment" with "redistricting" throughout the text.
  • Establishes a redistricting commission for each decennial census year to propose redistricting plans to the Louisiana Legislature.
  • Outlines membership requirements, deadlines, and appointment procedures for the redistricting commission.
  • Provides for filling vacancies, terms of service, per diem, and oath of office for commissioners.
  • Outlines goals and procedures of the commission and requirements for the plan development and reporting.

  • Outlines who may be an early voting watcher and how they may do their job.
  • Requires the registrar of voters or deputy registrar to regulate the number of watchers in the early voting location.
  • Outlines the administration and requirements of early watchers.

HISTORY: ["02/28/2022 - Prefiled.","02/28/2022 - Under the rules, provisionally referred to the Committee on House and Governmental Affairs.","03/03/2022 - Withdrawn prior to introduction.","03/04/2022 - First appeared in the Interim Calendar on 3/4/2022."]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides for "political party super watchers" for recognized parties with affiliation from at least 25% of registered voters.
  • Outlines the number of super watchers a parish qualifies for, based upon population.
  • Outlines notification requirements for political party super watchers.
  • Provides for early voting watchers for recognized parties with affiliation from at least 25% of registered voters.
  • Outlines who may be an early voting watcher and how they may do their job.
  • Requires the registrar of voters or deputy registrar to regulate the number of watchers in the early voting location.
  • Outlines the administration and requirements of early watchers.
  • Allows voting machines to use voter facing optical scanners or other vote capture technology.
  • Defines "voting system."
  • Requires that voting systems include procedures by the secretary of state to verify software and firmware installed on the machine.
  • Requires the voting system to maintain an internal record of ballots.
  • Requires paper ballots to have counterfieit protection.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows political parties to self govern the number of committee members and district requirements for representation on the state party committee, so long as the party's rules are provided to the Secretary of State and voters enrolled in the party are able to approve or dissaprove of the changes directly or indirectly.

HISTORY: ["03/29/2021 - Referred to the Joint Committee on Election Laws","03/29/2021 - House concurred","09/12/2022 - Accompanied a study order, see H5026"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows political party committees to permit voters enrolled in other parties to vote in their primaries.

HISTORY: ["03/29/2021 - Referred to the Joint Committee on Election Laws","03/29/2021 - House concurred","09/12/2022 - Accompanied a study order, see H5026"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows parties to nominate candidates to their own primaries in ways other than nomination papers.

HISTORY: ["03/29/2021 - Referred to the Joint Committee on Election Laws","03/29/2021 - House concurred","09/12/2022 - Accompanied a study order, see H5026"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows state party committees to permit multiple candidates in their state primary to appear on nominating papers so long as the committee alerts the Secretary of State no later than the first day that nomination papers are required to be available.

HISTORY: ["03/29/2021 - Referred to the Joint Committee on Election Laws","03/29/2021 - House concurred","09/12/2022 - Accompanied a study order, see H5026"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows for the acceptance of a $1.00 fee in lieu of any number of signatures required on any nomination papers for any office.

HISTORY: ["03/29/2021 - Referred to the Joint Committee on Election Laws","03/29/2021 - House concurred","09/12/2022 - Accompanied a study order, see H5026"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows political parties chairs to release candidates from party enrollment requirements.

HISTORY: ["03/29/2021 - Referred to the Joint Committee on Election Laws","03/29/2021 - House concurred","09/12/2022 - Accompanied a study order, see H5026"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows electronic and blockchain signatures on candidate nomination papers.

HISTORY: ["03/29/2021 - Referred to the Joint Committee on Election Laws","03/29/2021 - House concurred","09/12/2022 - Accompanied a study order, see H5026"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows state parties to permit candidates to run for more than one office in their own primaries.

HISTORY: ["03/29/2021 - Referred to the Joint Committee on Election Laws","03/29/2021 - House concurred","09/12/2022 - Accompanied a study order, see H5026"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows parties to accept nomination signatures from enrolled members of other parties.

HISTORY: ["03/29/2021 - Referred to the Joint Committee on Election Laws","03/29/2021 - House concurred","09/12/2022 - Accompanied a study order, see H5026"]

COAUTHORS: ["John Barrett","Michael Barrett","Harriette Chandler","Sonia Chang-Diaz","Michelle Ciccolo","Joanne Comerford","Cynthia Creem","Brendan Crighton","John Cronin","Julian Cyr","Sal DiDomenico","Diana Dizoglio","Carol Doherty","James Eldridge","Cindy Friedman","Carmine Gentile","Anne Gobi","Adam Gomez","Adam Hinds","Vanna Howard","Patricia Jehlen","Edward Kennedy","Kay Khan","David LeBoeuf","Eric Lesser","Jack Lewis","Jason Lewis","Joan Lovely","Christina Minicucci","Michael Moore","Susan Moran","Angelo Puppolo","Rebecca Rausch","Maria Robinson","Adam Scanlon","Thomas Stanley","Erika Uyterhoeven"]
HISTORY: ["06/09/2022 - Reported on S2554","06/09/2022 - Rules suspended","06/09/2022 - Committee of conference report accepted -see  Roll Call #188 (yeas 37 to Nays 3)","06/13/2022 - Referred to the committee on House Steering, Policy and Scheduling","06/16/2022 - Committee reported that the matter be placed in the Orders of the Day for the next sitting, the question being on acceptance","06/16/2022 - Rules suspended","06/16/2022 - Committee of conference report accepted, in concurrence -126 YEAS to 29 NAYS (See YEA and NAY No. 197 )","06/16/2022 - Emergency preamble adopted","06/16/2022 - Emergency preamble adopted","06/16/2022 - Enacted - 126 YEAS to 29 NAYS (See YEA and NAY No. 200 )","06/16/2022 - Enacted and laid before the Governor","06/22/2022 - Signed by the Governor, Chapter 92 of the Acts of 2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
This bill makes a number of changes to the state's election laws, including, but not limited to, the following:

  • Allowing all voters to cast absentee/mail-in ballots;  
  • Establishing in-person early voting for two weeks before state general elections and one week before presidential and state primary elections; and
  • Moving the voter registration deadline from 20 days before Election Day to 10 days before Election Day.

COAUTHORS: ["John Barrett","Michael Barrett","Joseph Boncore","Harriette Chandler","Sonia Chang-Diaz","Michelle Ciccolo","Joanne Comerford","Cynthia Creem","Brendan Crighton","John Cronin","Julian Cyr","Sal DiDomenico","Diana Dizoglio","Carol Doherty","Lori Ehrlich","James Eldridge","Cindy Friedman","Carmine Gentile","Anne Gobi","Adam Gomez","Adam Hinds","Vanna Howard","Patricia Jehlen","Edward Kennedy","Kay Khan","David LeBoeuf","Eric Lesser","Jack Lewis","Jason Lewis","Joan Lovely","Christina Minicucci","Michael Moore","Susan Moran","Angelo Puppolo","Rebecca Rausch","Maria Robinson","Adam Scanlon","Thomas Stanley","Erika Uyterhoeven"]
HISTORY: ["10/06/2021 - Text of S2545, printed as amended","10/06/2021 - Passed to be engrossed -see Roll Call #95 (Yeas 36 to Nays 3)","10/14/2021 - Read; and referred to the committee on House Ways and Means","01/26/2022 - Committee recommended ought to pass with an amendment and referred to the committee on House Steering, Policy and Scheduling","01/26/2022 - Committee reported that the matter be placed in the Orders of the Day for the next sitting with the amendment (H4359) pending","01/26/2022 - Rules suspended","01/26/2022 - Read second, amended (as recommended by the committee on House Ways and Means)","01/26/2022 - Ordered to a third reading","01/27/2022 - Read third","01/27/2022 - Passed to be engrossed - 124 YEAS to 34 NAYS (See YEA and NAY No. 140 )","02/03/2022 - Rules suspended","02/03/2022 - Senate NON-concurred in the House amendment","02/03/2022 - Committee of conference (Finegold-Creem-Fattman), appointed","02/03/2022 - House insisted on its amendment","02/03/2022 - Committee of conference appointed, in concurrence - (M. Moran-Ryan-Dooley)","06/09/2022 - Reported by S2924"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows a qualified person to register to vote for national and state elections.
  • Repeals certain time limited provisions related to provisional voters and provisional voting.
  • Revises the closing time for mobile registration units from 8:00pm to 5:00pm.
  • Requires registrars to be open 9am-5pm on the last day of registration, with exceptions for towns with less than 1,500 voters.
  • Requires the registrar to register all people in line by 5pm on the last day of registration and outlines the process for registering those who were in line.
  • Provides a list of possible documents to show proof of residence.
  • Outlines the possible ways a person may register, requires the ballot clerk to permit an applicant to vote in the election, and establishes a process for voters who fail to show proof of residence.
  • Requires the registrar to publish a list of polling locations with dates and hours seven days before the election and outlines where the information should be posted.
  • Directs the Secretary of State to make the statewide list of registered voters available to local election officials and allows local election officials to make certain corrections and add names with certain guidelines.
  • Prohibits anyone from registering on the day of an election for the sole purpose of altering their party affiliation.
  • Establishes rules for violations. 
  • Requires the Secretary of State to adopt rules for registrars to update the annual register of voters during the early voting period.
  • Replaces current automatic voter registration rules with new provisions stating voters who do not decline automatic registration will be registered within certain timetables and provisions related to declining.
  • Replaces provisions concerning vacancies of election officers with new rules stating how replacements should be appointed for certain positions within certain timetables.
  • Outlines the process for a voter to vote by mail or vote early, including administration of the application process and related requirements for voters, who may apply, responsibilities of election officials, deadlines, guidelines for mailing and returning ballots, processing applications and ballots, timelines for early voting, early voting sites, notification requirements, early voting process requirements, party selection requirements, early voting ballot administration and security, and deadlines. 
  • Eliminates a provision related to installation and provision of voting machines to city or town clerks.
  • Applies provisions related to polling station requirements to early voting locations.
  • Replaces guidelines concerning voting lists with new guidelines requiring a voting list be delivered to the ballot clerk and the officer in charge of the ballot box, and outlining how the list is to be used during voting. Also allows for electronic poll books to be used instead of the list.
  • Makes optional the requirement that town or city officials detail police officers to each building that is a polling place.
  • Outlines procedures for operating check-out tables at polling stations where they are used.
  • Requires applications for absentee ballots to be received before 5pm, seven days before the election.
  • Outlines election notification and mail voting procedures for correctional facilities.
  • Outlines reporting and complaint procedures for correctional facilities.
  • Requires correctional facility staff to report quarterly lists of newly incarcerated individuals with certain information.
  • Outlines procedures for processing absentee ballot applications and counting ballots for uniformed and overseas voters, including deadlines.
  • Requires an eligible voter's ballot to be counted if he or she dies after voting.
  • Requires all mail absentee ballots be received before the poll closing time on election day, with certain exceptions.
  • Outlines tabulating procedures and security for absentee ballots.
  • Requires the Secretary of State, by June 10, 2022, to conduct a public awareness campaign regarding: election day registration, expanded mail voting options, accommodations for voters with disability and limited English proficiency, and timelines for processing and counting ballots. 
  • Outlines certain requires for the public information campaign.
  • Makes other non substantive changes to election code.

HISTORY: ["10/21/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","02/08/2022 - Favorable Report by Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","02/08/2022 - Favorable Adopted","02/08/2022 - Second Reading Passed","02/10/2022 - Third Reading Passed (42-3)","02/15/2022 - Referred Ways and Means","04/07/2022 - Favorable Report by Ways and Means","04/08/2022 - Favorable Adopted Second Reading Passed","04/11/2022 - Third Reading Passed (101-22)","04/11/2022 - Returned Passed","05/29/2022 - Enacted under Article II, Section 17(c) of the Maryland Constitution - Chapter 625"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Adds a definition to the terms "contribution" and "expenditure" stating that it is a payment made to a campaign finance entity that may be used to pay expenses associated with an election.
  • Requires there to be less than a 5% difference for a candidate or voter to be able to petition for a recount.
  • Establishes rules for candidates accepting public campaign financing, including the requirement that the candidate establish a contested election committee, meeting all specified requirements.
  • Lists the roles and requirements of a contested election committee.
  • Prohibits certain donations, loans, and actions by the contested election committee.
  • Requires the treasurer of the contested election committee to keep detailed records of specified items, and to retain them for specified periods.
  • Establishes reporting requirements for the treasurer of the contested election committee, including in cases of a recount petition.
  • Requires the State Board to establish reporting periods for the required reports of the contested election committee.
  • Codifies procedures if a treasurer of a contested election committee fails to provide required reports, including notifications, fees, timelines, and prosecution and penalties.
  • Establishes guidelines for receiving an overdue report.
  • Establishes that a candidate with a contested election committee that failed to file required reports cannot be elected, take the oath, or receive salary, and includes related rules.
  • Clarifies related possible civil penalties and with which funds they may be paid.
  • Clarifies what to do when there are insufficient funds to pay civil penalties.
  • Outlines guidelines for repaying public contributions, paying outstanding debts, disposing of remaining assets, and reporting when applicable.
  • Provides that a publicly financed candidate may transfer funds from the candidate's campaign finance entity to the contested election committee.
  • Defines relevant terms. 
  • Makes conforming changes.
