  • Requires the treasurer of the contested election committee to keep detailed records of specified items, and to retain them for specified periods.
  • Establishes reporting requirements for the treasurer of the contested election committee, including in cases of a recount petition.
  • Requires the State Board to establish reporting periods for the required reports of the contested election committee.
  • Codifies procedures if a treasurer of a contested election committee fails to provide required reports, including notifications, fees, timelines, and prosecution and penalties.
  • Establishes guidelines for receiving an overdue report.
  • Establishes that a candidate with a contested election committee that failed to file required reports cannot be elected, take the oath, or receive salary, and includes related rules.
  • Clarifies related possible civil penalties and with which funds they may be paid.
  • Clarifies what to do when there are insufficient funds to pay civil penalties.
  • Outlines guidelines for repaying public contributions, paying outstanding debts, disposing of remaining assets, and reporting when applicable.
  • Provides that a publicly financed candidate may transfer funds from the candidate's campaign finance entity to the contested election committee.
  • Defines relevant terms. 
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["02/07/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","03/14/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Ways and Means","03/15/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 773526/1 Adopted","03/15/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {773526/1 Adopted","03/15/2022 - Motion Special Order until 3/16 (Delegate Kipke) Adopted","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment 583026/1 (Delegate M. Fisher) Rejected (40-95)","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment 673124/1 (Delegate Kipke) Rejected (41-93)","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment 483024/1 (Delegate Morgan) Rejected (41-93)","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment 583423/1 (Delegate Mautz) Rejected (40-93)","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment 993527/1 (Delegate Kipke) Rejected (38-94)","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment {583423/1 (Delegate Mautz) Rejected (40-93)","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment {483024/1 (Delegate Morgan) Rejected (41-93)","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment {673124/1 (Delegate Kipke) Rejected (40-94)","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment {583026/1 (Delegate M. Fisher) Rejected (40-95)","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment {993527/1 (Delegate Kipke) Rejected (38-94)","03/16/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","03/17/2022 - Third Reading Passed (96-40)","03/17/2022 - Referred Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","04/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 463623/1","04/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","04/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {463623/1","04/08/2022 - Motion Laid Over (Senator Ready) Adopted","04/09/2022 - Floor Amendment 793023/1 (Senator Ready) Rejected (14-30)","04/09/2022 - Floor Amendment 453023/1 (Senator Ready) Rejected (14-28)","04/09/2022 - Floor Amendment 303226/1 (Senator Ready) Rejected (17-27)","04/09/2022 - Floor Amendment 783920/1 (Senator Simonaire) Rejected","04/09/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {463623/1 Adopted","04/09/2022 - Floor Amendment {303226/1 (Senator Ready) Rejected (16-28)","04/09/2022 - Floor Amendment {793023/1 (Senator Ready) Rejected (14-30)","04/09/2022 - Floor Amendment {453023/1 (Senator Ready) Rejected (14-28)","04/09/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","04/09/2022 - Floor Amendment {783920/1 (Senator Simonaire) Rejected","04/09/2022 - Third Reading Passed (29-13)","04/11/2022 - House Concurs Senate Amendments","04/11/2022 - Third Reading Passed (92-41)","04/11/2022 - Passed Enrolled","05/27/2022 - Vetoed by the Governor (Policy)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes audits from the definition of what a canvas includes.
  • Changes the definition of "board of canvassers" from canvassing "after" an election to canvas "for" an election.
  • Clarifies that unofficial returns do not include provisional ballot counts, but do include absentee ballot counts.
  • Requires a local board to review an absentee ballot envelope for omission of voters signature on the oath promptly upon receipt.
  • Prohibits a local board from processing a ballot before 8am, eight business days before the first day of early voting.
  • Prohibits a local board from tabulating absentee ballots until the polls close on election day.
  • Requires the local board to reject a ballot if the voter fails to sign the oath on the ballot envelope and fails to correct the omission by 8am, ten days after the election.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt regulations requiring local boards to implement systems to rectify omission of signature on absentee ballot envelopes, with specific timelines, and guidance on counting the ballots. 
  • Allows a signature to be a digital image sent by email or phone beginning June 1, 2023.
  • Allows a voter to choose the method by which they would like to communicate with the local board to correct a signature omission, including text message and an online portal by June 1, 2023.
  • Requires the local board to release a report of unofficial returns of absentee ballots after polls close on election day. 
  • Outlines procedures for if the board receives more than one ballot from the same individual.
  • Requires the board of canvassers to report the early, absentee, and provisional vote separately, but not by precinct.
  • No longer requires the local board to print copies of election results and make them available to the public.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["10/19/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","02/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 453621/1","02/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","02/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {453621/1","02/08/2022 - Motion Special Order until 2/9 (Senator Ready) Adopted","02/09/2022 - Floor Amendment 183823/1 (Senator Simonaire) Rejected","02/09/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {453621/1 Adopted","02/09/2022 - Floor Amendment {183823/1 (Senator Simonaire) Rejected","02/09/2022 - Motion Special Order until 2/10 (Senator Simonaire) Rejected (15-30)","02/09/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","02/14/2022 - Motion Special Order until 2/15 (Senator Ready) Adopted","02/15/2022 - Third Reading Passed (33-14)","02/17/2022 - Referred Ways and Means","04/07/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Ways and Means","04/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 823921/1 Adopted","04/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {823921/1 Adopted","04/08/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","04/08/2022 - Third Reading Passed (94-41)","04/09/2022 - Senate Concurs House Amendments","04/09/2022 - Third Reading Passed (31-14)","04/09/2022 - Passed Enrolled","05/27/2022 - Vetoed by the Governor (Policy)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes the provision that unofficial returns do not include absentee and provisional ballot counts.
  • Requires the local board to review ballot return envelopes for the omission of a voter signature on the oath during the canvas.
  • Requires a local board to wait until 8am, 8 business days before the first day of early voting to accept, reject, open, or process absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Prohibits a local board releasing tabulations of absentee ballot results before the polls close on election day.
  • Allows a voter to correct a ballot return envelope signature before 10am, 10 days after the election.
  • Requires the state board to develop regulations requiring the local board to allow voters to correct signature errors on ballot return envelopes with certain guidelines.
  • Allows a voter to supply a digital signature to fix the envelope signature error with certain requirements and options.
  • Requires the local board to count the first ballot with a properly signed envelope when receiving more than one ballot from an individual.
  • Requires the local board to release a report of unofficial election results each day beginning after the polls close on election day, including early, absentee, and provisional ballots.
  • Outlines guidelines for accepting or rejecting an absentee or provisional ballots received from the same individual.
  • Requires the board of canvassers to prepare a report by precinct including early, absentee, and provisional votes.

HISTORY: ["02/09/2022 - First Reading Senate Rules","03/09/2022 - Rereferred to Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","03/18/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 923924/1 Adopted","03/18/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","03/18/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {923924/1 Adopted","03/18/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","03/21/2022 - Third Reading Passed (46-0)","03/21/2022 - Referred Ways and Means","03/31/2022 - Favorable Report by Ways and Means","04/01/2022 - Favorable Adopted Second Reading Passed","04/04/2022 - Third Reading Passed (124-0)","04/04/2022 - Returned Passed","04/21/2022 - Approved by the Governor - Chapter 192"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board to adopt rules governing the use of a building that holds an alcoholic beverage license as a polling place.
  • Requires the local board to prioritize putting polling places in buildings that do not have an alcoholic beverage license.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["01/19/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","03/14/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Ways and Means","03/15/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 823227/1 Adopted","03/15/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {823227/1 Adopted","03/15/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","03/16/2022 - Third Reading Passed (138-0)","03/16/2022 - Referred Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","04/07/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 373029/1 Adopted","04/07/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","04/07/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {373029/1 Adopted","04/07/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","04/08/2022 - Third Reading Passed (47-0)","04/11/2022 - House Concurs Senate Amendments","04/11/2022 - Third Reading Passed (132-0)","04/11/2022 - Passed Enrolled","04/21/2022 - Approved by the Governor - Chapter 191"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Repeals the rule that an election may not be in a building used by an establishment that holds an alcohol license.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt rules governing the use of buildings with an establishment that holds an alcohol license.
  • Requires local boards to prioritize polling location placement in buildings without an establishment with an alcohol license.

HISTORY: ["09/28/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","03/01/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","03/02/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 983925/1 Adopted","03/02/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {983925/1 Adopted","03/02/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","03/04/2022 - Third Reading Passed (44-0)","03/07/2022 - Referred Ways and Means","03/14/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Ways and Means","03/15/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 443720/1 Adopted","03/15/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {443720/1 Adopted","03/15/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment 913623/1 (Delegate Wilkins) Adopted","03/16/2022 - Floor Amendment {913623/1 (Delegate Wilkins) Adopted","03/16/2022 - Third Reading Passed (139-0)","03/16/2022 - Senate Concurs House Amendments","03/16/2022 - Third Reading Passed (46-0)","03/16/2022 - Passed Enrolled","04/09/2022 - Enacted under Article II, Section 17(b) of the Maryland Constitution - Chapter 35"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that the State Board will review and vote on each contract with more than $50,000 value related to elections.
  • Provides that the State Board must ensure the cost effective use of government resources in administering elections.
  • Requires the state administrator to report each proposed contract or renewal to the Board, including reporting certain information.
  • Requires the state administrator to have Board approval before finalizing a contract.
  • Outlines requirements for a State Board report to the Board of Public Works related to proposed contracts.
  • Provides that counties will reimburse the State Board for 50% of the state's cost of all election related goods and services mandated by the State Board.
  • Allows the State Board to procure other goods that are not mandated, with processing requirements. 
  • Requires each county to pay 50% of the cost for voting systems, absentee voting, and all associated equipment and support costs. 
  • Establishes that county cost will be based on population.

HISTORY: ["03/15/2022 - First Reading Reapportionment and Redistricting","03/28/2022 - Motion Rules Suspend for Late Introduction (Senator King) Adopted (32-12)","03/28/2022 - Motion Rules Suspend to Refer (Senator King) Adopted","03/28/2022 - Referred Reapportionment and Redistricting","03/29/2022 - Favorable Report by Reapportionment and Redistricting","03/29/2022 - Favorable Adopted (29-13)","03/29/2022 - Second Reading Passed","03/29/2022 - Third Reading Passed (30-13)","03/29/2022 - Referred Rules and Executive Nominations","03/30/2022 - Floor Amendment 213922/1 (Delegate Parrott) Rejected (42-92)","03/30/2022 - Favorable Report by House Rules and Executive Nominations","03/30/2022 - Favorable Adopted Second Reading Passed","03/30/2022 - Floor Amendment {213922/1 (Delegate Parrott) Rejected (42-92)","03/30/2022 - Third Reading Passed (94-41)","03/31/2022 - Returned Passed","04/04/2022 - Approved by the Governor - Chapter 16"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill sets forth a redistricting plan for congressional districts in the State of Maryland.

HISTORY: ["01/20/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","03/07/2022 - Favorable Report by Ways and Means","03/08/2022 - Favorable Adopted","03/08/2022 - Motion Special Order until 3/9 (Delegate M. Fisher) Adopted","03/09/2022 - Floor Amendment 693721/1 (Delegate M. Fisher) Rejected (45-86)","03/09/2022 - Floor Amendment {693721/1 (Delegate M. Fisher) Rejected (45-86)","03/09/2022 - Second Reading Passed","03/11/2022 - Third Reading Passed (136-0)","03/14/2022 - Referred Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Forbids the State Board from approving a contract with an election service provider, unless the provider includes a contract clause that requires the provider to report if any manufacturing or change to an election system occurred outside the US.
  • Lists report requirements.
  • Requires the state administrator to forward a copy of the report to appropriate people within five days of receiving it.
  • Allows the state administrator to terminate the contract if he or she determines that there is a possibility of election misconduct.
  • Requires the state administrator to notify appropriate people of the termination within seven days.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["01/31/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","03/17/2022 - Favorable Report by Ways and Means","03/17/2022 - Favorable Adopted Second Reading Passed","03/18/2022 - Third Reading Passed (93-36)","03/21/2022 - Referred Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a candidate for governor to designate a candidate for lieutenant governor by 21 days after the primary election.
  • Requires a candidate for governor not running in a primary election to designate a candidate for lieutenant governor at the time of filing a nomination.
  • Requires governor and lieutenant governor candidates to provide consent in writing at the time of their candidacy filing or declaration of intent.
  • Requires candidates for lieutenant governor and governor be listed jointly on the general election ballot.
  • Requires the name of the gubernatorial candidate to be listed on the primary ballot.
  • Requires the candidate for lieutenant governor to file a certificate of candidacy when he or she is designated by the candidate for governor.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["02/03/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","03/17/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 373928/1 Adopted","03/17/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Ways and Means","03/17/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {373928/1 Adopted","03/17/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","03/18/2022 - Third Reading Passed (132-0)","03/18/2022 - Referred Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines automated software audit and electronic count.
  • Changes the name of manual audit to manual count and makes conforming changes.
  • Defines risk limit and risk limiting audit.
  • Requires the State Board and local boards to audit the accuracy of the voting system's tabulation of votes with a risk limiting audit after each statewide election.
  • Lists which races must be included in the audit.
  • Allows the State Board to choose specific races to conduct the audit, with certain limitations.
  • Includes the requirements of a risk limiting audit.
  • Outlines actions if a risk limiting audit finds certain outcomes.
  • Requires the State Board to publish audit results within certain timelines and with certain requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["02/17/2022 - First Reading House Rules and Executive Nominations","03/03/2022 - Rereferred To Ways and Means"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines curbside voting.
  • Establishes that a voting system must accommodate curbside voting.
  • Lists reasons a voter may be eligible for curbside voting, including qualifying under the Americans with Disabilities Act.
  • Requires local boards to establish a location for curbside voting at each early voting center and on election day at all voting locations, during voting hours.
  • Establishes certain guidelines for implementation of curbside voting.
  • Requires curbside voting to be able to be completed without assistance, unless the voter requests it, and to maintain the secrecy of the ballot.
  • Outlines signage requirements at voting locations for curbside voting.
  • Requires that an area be provided for a voter to obtain information from campaigners.
  • Requires a system by which the voter may announce they have arrived for curbside voting.
  • Requires the voter be promptly acknowledged, and that the same information be provided to curbside voters.
  • Requires two election judges representing different political parties to observe curbside voting, with some exceptions.
  • Outlines the process for requesting a ballot and voting curbside.
  • Requires election judges to maintain a record of each curbside vote at each location.
  • Requires the State Board to designate each curbside voting location at least six months before a primary election and to adopt regulations to carry out the rules outlined for curbside voting.

HISTORY: ["10/21/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","03/07/2022 - Favorable with Amendments Report by Ways and Means","03/08/2022 - Floor Amendment 993423/1 (Delegate Wilkins) Adopted","03/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments 743425/1 Adopted","03/08/2022 - Favorable with Amendments {743425/1 Adopted","03/08/2022 - Floor Amendment {993423/1 (Delegate Wilkins) Adopted","03/08/2022 - Second Reading Passed with Amendments","03/10/2022 - Third Reading Passed (125-11)","03/11/2022 - Referred Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that the State Board is to review and vote on each contract with a value of $50,000 or more.
  • Establishes that the State Board will ensure the cost effective use of government resources in administering elections.
  • Requires the State Administrator to report each proposed contract, renewal, and change to the State Board, with guidance for submitting a report.
  • Requires the State Board to vote on approval before contracts are finalized.
  • Lists requirements for a State Board report to the Board of Public Works.
  • Requires counties to reimburse the State Board for 50% of the state's cost of elections, and electronic voting systems, that are mandated by the State Board, with non-mandated costs being paid out of county funds.
  • Directs that costs should be calculated based on the size of the voting age population in each county.
  • Outlines procurement allowances and contract allowances for the State Board.

COAUTHORS: ["Joseph Boteler","Jason Buckel","Brian Chisholm","Mark Fisher","Robin Grammer","Wayne Hartman","Kevin Hornberger","Seth Howard","Nicholaus Kipke","Trent Kittleman","Nino Mangione","Susan McComas","Michael McKay","Neil Parrott","Jesse Pippy","Teresa Reilly","Sid Saab","Haven Shoemaker","Kathy Szeliga","Brenda Thiam"]
HISTORY: "02/11/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "elected member," "local board," "petition."
  • Establishes that an elected member is subject to recall by voters.
  • Lists reasons an elected member may not be recalled.
  • Describes the process a registered voter must use to initiate a recall.
  • Requires the elected member to respond within 14 days of the Notice of Intention being filed and describes requirements.
  • Requires a recall petition to be signed by at least 30% of registered voters in the county.
  • Lists requirements for the recall petition.
  • Lists required steps for the candidate seeking to succeed the elected member.
  • Outlines what should be on the ballot for a special recall election, the process of administering the election, and provides voting instructions.
  • Forbids an elected member subject to recall to be on the ballot to succeed himself.
  • Outlines procedures if an elected member resigns before a recall election.
  • Establishes that a majority of votes is needed for the recall to succeed, and that they candidate for replacement with the highest number of votes wins the election.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["01/21/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","03/08/2022 - WITHDRAWN BY SPONSOR"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a local board, at the start of the absentee ballot canvas, to review the ballot envelope or ballot return envelope for any omission by the voter.
  • Requires the local board to wait until 8am, eight business days before the first day of early voting to being processing absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Forbids a local board from canvasing absentee ballots during the early voting period.
  • Outlines the process for voters whose ballots do not meet the guidelines.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt rules requiring a local board to adopt a process for rectifying the absentee ballot envelope problems and specifies what must be included.
  • Requires the local board to count only the first legally sufficient ballot it receives from a voter.
  • Requires the local board to release a report of unofficial results beginning after the polls close on election day and at the end of each canvasing day.
  • Outlines a procedure for counting ballots when an absentee ballot and a provisional ballot is received from the same person.

HISTORY: "01/19/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a local board, at the start of the absentee ballot canvas, to review the ballot envelope or ballot return envelope for any omission by the voter.
  • Requires the local board to wait until 8am, eight business days before the first day of early voting to being processing absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Forbids a local board from canvasing absentee ballots during the early voting period.
  • Outlines the process for absentee voters who failed to correct an omission on the absentee ballot envelope by 10am, ten days after the election.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt rules requiring a local board to adopt a process for rectifying the absentee ballot envelope problems and specifies what must be included.
  • Requires the local board to release a report of unofficial results beginning after the polls close on election day and at the end of each canvasing day.
  • Outlines a procedure for counting ballots when an absentee ballot and a provisional ballot is received from the same person.

HISTORY: "02/20/2022 - First Reading Senate Rules"
BILLSUMMARY: • Prohibits absentee ballot envelopes from visibly identifying the party affiliation of the voter.

HISTORY: ["01/19/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs","02/15/2022 - WITHDRAWN BY SPONSOR"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines voter registration drive.
  • Establishes events that may constitute a voter registration drive.
  • Requires that each local board conduct a voter registration drive in each public high school in their county at least once per year.
  • Requires the high school to provide a space for free in an appropriate building.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","02/14/2022 - Unfavorable Report by Ways and Means"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the absentee ballot application include an option for voters to indicate their preferred method to receive communication.
  • Requires the election director to verify the signature of an absentee ballot application.
  • Requires the State Board to provide each local board with machines that electronically verify signatures.
  • Outlines the process for if a signature cannot be verified.
  • Requires the voter to provide the local board a copy of any required forms of identification for the absentee ballot application and the absentee ballot return envelope.
  • Requires an election board to verify the signature on a return identification absentee ballot envelope.
  • Outlines the process for if a voter is unable to provide a signature that matches the record.
  • Outlines the process for the local board to verify the signature and the process if they are unable to verify it, including voter notifications.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt appropriate regulations to carry out these rules.
  • Authorizes the local board to reject an absentee ballot if it is established that the voter voted in person in the same election.
  • Establishes that if a voter's absentee ballot was rejected, the voter's provisional ballot may bot be rejected because the voter cast more than one ballot in the same election.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: "02/11/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines push poll.
  • Lists characteristics of a push poll.
  • Clarifies that a push poll does not include a survey supporting one candidate that fails to reference another candidate other than in a preference question.
  • Clarifies that this section does not apply to a push poll or political phone solicitation where individuals knew each other before the call.
  • Lists legitimate election practices excluded from push poll prohibitions.
  • Lists requirements that must occur during each call of a push poll.
  • Establishes that it is not a violation if the respondent voluntarily ends a call or asks to be called back after all disclosures are made, with certain exceptions.
  • Prohibits a person giving a fictitious name or phone number.
  • Requires disclosures be made in a clear manner and repeated if necessary.
  • Provides certain exclusions.
  • Requires the push poll to have a designated agent to serve the process, notice, and demand before the poll starts and for at least 180 days after the completion of activities in the state.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the designated agent.
  • Requires the State Board to create and maintain forms for the designation of agents and lists information to be included.
  • Includes these provisions in the civil penalties for violation.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","02/14/2022 - WITHDRAWN BY SPONSOR"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that a voter registration drive may include an event on school property where: completed registration applications are accepted by election officials or where election officials visit classrooms in a school and distribute and collect voter registration forms.
  • Requires that each local board conduct a voter registration drive at each public high school at least once per year.
  • Requires that the public high school provide a space free of charge for the voter registration drive.
  • Defines voter registration drive.

HISTORY: "02/11/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires an audit and a manual audit after each primary and general election.
  • Requires 3% of precincts statewide (up from 2%) be manually audited.
  • Requires the manual audit to begin the same day the final ballots are canvassed.
  • Requires official results to be altered if the manual audit finds that the results from the electronic canvas are incorrect.
  • Provides for an automated software audit.
  • Establishes procedures for various election officials to follow before opening the polls during early voting and on election day.
  • Establishes procedures for after all ballots have been canvased.
  • Outlines procedures when auditing the ballot scanner machine.
  • Lists who may observe election officials while they are performing their auditing duties.

HISTORY: "02/11/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes the prohibition on legislative districts with more than two counties that they may not have more than one delegate living in the district. 
  • Removes certain requirements related to the content of ballots for election of candidates to the House of Delegates who are required to live in a certain county.
  • Makes conforming changes.

COAUTHORS: ["Jason Buckel","Dan Cox","Susan Krebs","Michael McKay","Matt Morgan","Charles Otto","Teresa Reilly","Sid Saab","Kathy Szeliga","Brenda Thiam"]
HISTORY: ["10/21/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","02/14/2022 - WITHDRAWN BY SPONSOR"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Administrator to make arrangements with crematories, morticians, and funeral directors to receive reports of Maryland residents, at least 16 years of age who died in the past 30 days.
  • Requires the State Administrator to transmit this information to the appropriate local board. 
  • Requires the election director to remove the name of the deceased voter when receiving this information.

COAUTHORS: ["Christopher Adams","Lauren Arikan","Wendell Beitzel","Joseph Boteler","Jason Buckel","Brian Chisholm","Mark Fisher","Robin Grammer","Michael Griffith","Wayne Hartman","Kevin Hornberger","Seth Howard","Jay Jacobs","Trent Kittleman","Susan Krebs","Nino Mangione","Johnny Mautz","Susan McComas","Michael McKay","Matt Morgan","Charles Otto","Jesse Pippy","Teresa Reilly","April Rose","Sid Saab","Haven Shoemaker","Kathy Szeliga","Brenda Thiam"]
HISTORY: "02/11/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY: • Forbids the absentee ballot form and envelope to include information that identifies a voter's party affiliation.

COAUTHORS: ["Christopher Adams","Steven Arentz","Joseph Boteler","Jason Buckel","Kevin Hornberger","Jay Jacobs","Nicholaus Kipke","Susan Krebs","Susan McComas","Matt Morgan","Charles Otto","April Rose","Haven Shoemaker"]
HISTORY: "02/11/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY: • Forbids people who are not US citizens from voting in an election for any municipal corporation.

HISTORY: ["01/19/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","02/14/2022 - Unfavorable Report by Ways and Means"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Exempts recall elections from requirements for standard election dates.
  • Lists which offices are subject to recall election.
  • Describes the process of filing a petition for recall including timing, signatures, and holding the recall election.
  • Outlines what should be on the ballot for a special recall election.

HISTORY: "02/11/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires the State Board of Elections and each local board of elections post aerial photos on their websites showing the location of the electioneering boundary for polling places and early voting centers.

HISTORY: ["09/10/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means","02/14/2022 - WITHDRAWN BY SPONSOR"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines a fixed bus route and excludes certain routes.
  • Establishes that if an early voting center is located within one-half of a mile from a fixed bus route, buses should allow passengers to embark and disembark at the entrance of the early voting center during its hours of operation.

HISTORY: "02/07/2022 - First Reading Judiciary and Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill prohibits a candidate for judge of the orphans' court from appearing on the ballot in a primary election or being nominated by a political party or by petition. This bill also prohibits judges of the orphans' court from acting as an attorney during their term of office in any matter that is within the jurisdiction of the court and related to the administration of an estate or guardianship of a minor.

COAUTHORS: ["Christopher Adams","Lauren Arikan","Wendell Beitzel","Joseph Boteler","Jason Buckel","Brian Chisholm","Mark Fisher","Michael Griffith","Wayne Hartman","Trent Kittleman","Susan Krebs","Nino Mangione","Johnny Mautz","Susan McComas","Michael McKay","Neil Parrott","April Rose","Sid Saab","Bill Wivell"]
HISTORY: "02/10/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the state board to establish guidelines for verification of signatures on absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Requires absentee ballot envelopes to be signed and signature verified to be counted.
  • Requires a local board to verify the signature by comparing it to the signature with the voter's registration record, which may be done electronically.
  • Requires the state board to provide voter signature verification machines to local boards requesting them.
  • Provides steps if the board is unable to verify a signature.
  • Outlines what should be included in the instructions with the absentee ballot.
  • Allows voters to return a signature verification statement two days after they receive it.
  • Outlines the required contents of a signature verification form.
  • Outlines guidelines for the local board in verifying a signature.
  • Requires each local board to provide certain related information on their website.
  • Requires prepaid postage for the envelope.
  • Requires a voter to return the unsigned ballot statement by the second Sunday after the election to be counted.
  • Outlines the contents of the unsigned ballot statement.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: "02/10/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board to adopt requirements for the secure storage and use of voter data.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt regulations regarding the collection of electronic signatures.
  • Specifies the requirements for accepting an electronic signature.
  • Specifies that an electronic signature must reflect an affirmative action of the signer, or add the signer's name to a petition.
  • Requires the State Board to create forms for electronic signature.
  • Requires the circulator of a petition to witness (in person) and attest to a person signing electronically.

COAUTHORS: ["Christopher Adams","Lauren Arikan","Wendell Beitzel","Joseph Boteler","Jason Buckel","Brian Chisholm","Mark Fisher","Michael Griffith","Trent Kittleman","Susan Krebs","Nino Mangione","Johnny Mautz","Susan McComas","Michael McKay","Matt Morgan","Neil Parrott","Jesse Pippy","Teresa Reilly","April Rose","Sid Saab","Kathy Szeliga","Brenda Thiam","Bill Wivell"]
HISTORY: "02/10/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY: • Prohibits the state and local board, and municipalities, from mailing absentee ballots to voters who did not request them.

HISTORY: "02/10/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines care giving services as direct care, protection, and supervision of a child or individual with a disability or medical condition for whom a candidate has direct caregiving responsibilities.
  • Excludes private school tuition, tutoring, or nursing home care.
  • Establishes that expenditure includes reasonable expenses for caregiving services that the candidate incurs as a direct result of his or her campaign.

HISTORY: "02/07/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines an audit threshold as 0.5% of the audit total.
  • Defines an audit total as 3% of absentee ballots cast in the county in the previous comparable election.
  • Defines previous comparable elections.
  • Requires the State Board to conduct an audit of absentee ballots in each statewide election.
  • Requires each local board to canvas absentee ballots in equal number batches, with the State Board determining the number in each batch.
  • Describes the process of choosing absentee ballots to audit.
  • Requires each voter's signature to be verified in the audit.
  • Outlines which personnel should be included in the audit.
  • Describes the process when a signature cannot be verified.
  • Clarifies the process if the total number of signatures that cannot be verified exceed the audit threshold in the county.
  • Establishes reporting and publication requirements for the audit.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt appropriate policies to carry out the audits.

HISTORY: "02/03/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Directs that the student member on the Board of School Commissioners in certain counties will be an elected position (it was appointed previously). 
  • Requires the student position to be elected by high school students in the jurisdiction.
  • Prohibits the student member from attending executive or special sessions of the board in certain circumstances, unless invited to attend by a majority of the board through a vote.
  • Allows the majority of board members to determine on a case by case basis whether a matter is covered by the exclusionary provision.
  • Establishes that the student member has the same rights and privileges, and voting rights, as other board members with certain exceptions.
  • Provides that the nomination and election process for the student member will be determined by the county board and should include procedures in the case of a vacancy.
  • Establishes certain grade level requirements in certain jurisdictions.

HISTORY: "01/26/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires that the method for electing the county or municipality governing body may not impair the ability of members of a protected class to elect candidates of their choice or influence the outcome of the election.
  • Establishes a list of violations, including listing factors that may establish a violation.
  • Includes a list of items a court should consider to determine whether polarized voting has occurred.
  • Outlines further legal exclusions and requirements when considering voting rights violations.
  • Allows the Attorney General to bring action to enforce voting rights violations and offers means of relief.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: "01/20/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "firearm" and includes examples.
  • Forbids anyone carrying a firearm to a polling site, or within 100 feet of one, during an election, including the parking lot, with certain exceptions.

HISTORY: "02/07/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board in collaboration with local board to audit the accuracy of the voting system tabulation of votes with a risk limiting audit after each statewide election.
  • Lists the races that should be included.
  • Allows the State Board to select specific races to be audited, with certain limitations.
  • Requires the risk limiting audit to examine randomly chosen paper records until a certain quantifiable point in the count.
  • Requires the audit be completed before certification of the election results and be observable to the maximum extent possible.
  • Outlines procedures for an audit outcome determining the electronic count is incorrect.
  • Requires reporting on the state website within 10 days of the conclusion of the audit.
  • Allows the state board to conduct an automated software audit after a statewide election that includes no more than 25% of the ballot styles used in the election.
  • Outlines procedures for pilot risk limiting audits in the November 2022 elections.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: "01/31/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill prohibits anyone from casting a ballot in more than one state in the same year.

COAUTHORS: ["Sarah Elfreth","Guy Guzzone","Cheryl Kagan","Clarence Lam","Will Smith","Jeff Waldstreicher"]
HISTORY: "01/21/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs and Budget and Taxation"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows candidates for state senator or state house to accept certain eligible private contributions under the Public Financing Act.
  • Expands public financing rules to candidates for state senator and state house.
  • Establishes that a candidate for state senator must collect at least 250 eligible private donations worth $15,000 to qualify for Public Financing.
  • Establishes that a candidate for state house must collect at least 150 eligible contributions worth $7,500 to qualify for Public Financing.
  • Establishes that state senate candidates will receive $6 for each dollar of eligible private contributions received for the first $50 of contributions, and $2 for each eligible contribution for the next $100, and no additional funds for other donations.
  • Establishes that state house candidates will receive $6 for each dollar of eligible private contributions received for the first $50 of contributions, and $2 for each eligible contribution for the next $100, and no additional funds for other donations.
  • Establishes maximum limits for public contributions for candidates for governor, state senator, and state house.

HISTORY: "01/19/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill makes it a crime to willfully and maliciously destroy, injure, or deface campaign signs. This bill also criminalizes willfully and knowingly obtaining or exerting unauthorized control over campaign signs under certain circumstances.

COAUTHORS: ["Jack Bailey","Mary Beth Carozza","Bob Cassilly","Paul Corderman","Adelaide Eckardt","George Edwards","Jason Gallion","Stephen Hershey","J.B. Jennings","Johnny Salling","Bryan Simonaire","Chris West"]
HISTORY: "01/28/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires an election judge to establish a voter's identity and verify their address when an individual seeks to vote.
  • Outlines procedures for finding the individual on lists, or establishing the person's identity in another way if they are not on the list.
  • Directs the election judge to authorize a person to vote a regular ballot after establishing their identity.
  • Establishes guidelines for when to refer an individual to a provisional ballot.
  • Forbids anyone from voting or attempting to vote under false identification.

COAUTHORS: ["Dan Cox","Robin Grammer","Kevin Hornberger","Trent Kittleman","Johnny Mautz","Michael McKay","April Rose","Brenda Thiam"]
HISTORY: "02/03/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires, beginning on November 1, 2024, that a congressional House candidate be a resident, by the day of election, of the congressional district in which the candidate is running to represent.

HISTORY: "02/03/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires that a political club be established as a political committee and file a statement of organization. This bill also mandates that political clubs file campaign finance reports and prohibits them from paying a person other than a campaign finance entity to defray the costs of a campaign finance entity.

HISTORY: "01/31/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires petition signatures be in ink.
  • Requires a signature to be validated and counted if the identity of the person can be "reasonably determined" using the required information.
  • Prohibits the election authority from invalidating a signature because someone used a derivative of their given name.
  • Requires the election authority to invalidate a ballot where someone's last name does not match their last name as it appears on the voter registration record.
  • Requires the election authority to validate the first signature of an individual who signed the same petition more than once and makes subsequent signatures invalid.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: "01/31/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines electronic device.
  • Allows authorized individuals and voters to use an electronic device at the polling place for specific actions.
  • Outlines when an individual may not use an electronic device at a polling place.
  • Lists which authorized individuals may use an electronic device.
  • Establishes penalties for violating this section.

COAUTHORS: ["Joseph Boteler","Jason Buckel","Brian Chisholm","Kevin Hornberger","Susan Krebs","Matt Morgan","Teresa Reilly","April Rose","Haven Shoemaker","Kathy Szeliga","Brenda Thiam"]
HISTORY: "01/31/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "continuing care retirement community."
  • Requires a local board to establish a separate precinct in a retirement community to serve at least the residents of the facility, if the facility requests a voting location.
  • Requires the continuing care retirement community to provide a free of charge facility for the polling place, and to provide assistance in recruiting election judges from among the residents.

HISTORY: "01/31/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires training materials created by the State Board to include oral and written instruction on the methods a judge may use to assist an elderly or disabled voter at the polling site, including individualized accommodations.
  • Requires the state to develop a sign that states the various methods an election judge may use to accommodate elderly or disabled voters and specifies the size of the sign, and where the sign should be posted.

HISTORY: "01/27/2022 - First Reading Judicial Proceedings"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill prohibits a candidate for judge of the orphans' court from appearing on the ballot in a primary election or being nominated by a political party or by petition. This bill also prohibits judges of the orphans' court from acting as an attorney during their term of office in any matter that is within the jurisdiction of the court and related to the administration of an estate or guardianship of a minor.

COAUTHORS: ["Lorig Charkoudian","Debra Davis","Eric Ebersole","Terri Hill","Mary Lehman","Robbyn Lewis","Lesley Lopez","Sara Love","Sheila Ruth","Jen Terrasa","Pat Young"]
HISTORY: "01/21/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY: • Allows county governing bodies to establish a public campaign financing system for any of a list of offices, after establishing it for one complete election cycle under current rules.

HISTORY: "01/21/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires each early voting center to be open beginning the second Thursday before an election through the Sunday before the election, 7am-8pm each day.

HISTORY: "01/19/2022 - First Reading Judiciary and Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a candidate for circuit court judge to file a certificate of candidacy by 5pm on the first Monday in August in the year of the election.
  • Requires circuit court judges be elected in nonpartisan elections.
  • Describes the process for circuit court judges to file candidacy.
  • Prohibits circuit court judge candidates to be on the ballot in the primary election.
  • Outlines the process for filling a vacancy of a circuit court judge.
  • Specifies that voters may only vote for the number of candidates as there are vacant positions, and the candidate with the largest number of votes wins the election.
  • Describes the process for if there is a tie.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: "01/19/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires that the superintendent of Hartford County Public Schools will be elected beginning in 2024 to a four year term.
  • Establishes qualification criteria for superintendent candidates.
  • Requires the term to begin December 1 after the election.
  • Prohibits a superintendent from running for more than three consecutive terms.
  • Requires the elected superintendent to choose an assistant superintendent within 60 days of the election, with the approval of the county board.
  • Establishes qualification criteria for candidates for assistant superintendent.
  • Establishes guidelines for filling a vacancy for superintendent or assistant superintendent.
  • Establishes removal and recall guidelines for the two positions.
  • Provides that a registered voter from the county may initiate a recall and outlines the requirements, including petition requirements.
  • Outlines requirements for a candidate seeking to succeed the county superintendent, including ballot placement and wording.
  • Provides for procedures related to the vote for or against recall.
  • Provides procedures for if a superintendent resigns.
  • Requires that the compensation for the superintendent set by the county board be at least equal to the current compensation of the county executive, but not greater by more than 20%.
  • Details what to do in case of a tie in the election.
  • Establishes that in the general election for the superintendent voters may only vote for one candidate and the nominee with the most votes wins the election.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: "01/19/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that compensation for election day and each early voting day may not be less than $200 per day for each election judge.
  • Removes compensation requirements for Allegany County and Calvert County.
  • Allows chief election judges in Washington County to receive a mileage allowance in addition to their pay.

HISTORY: "01/19/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines requirements for candidates seeking to be members of the General Assembly, and members of the General Assembly.
  • Establishes that in determining whether a candidate or member is a resident of a district, the state board or court will consider 13 factors.
  • Establishes that the residency of a candidate or member on active duty may not be considered eligible or ineligible based solely on where the member is stationed.
  • Requires the General Assembly Counsel to annually review the compliance of each member with residency requirements.

HISTORY: "01/19/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines approval voting and ranked choice voting.
  • Allows the Montgomery County Council to adopt ranked choice voting of approval voting for elections for any of a list of offices.
  • Requires the local law to include guidance for ballot format, tabulating procedures, and other provisions.
  • Requires the local law include an education campaign about the method.
  • Allows the Montgomery County Council to choose the format of the ballots for either method.

HISTORY: ["10/06/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a candidate seeking nomination for governor in a primary to designate a candidate for lieutenant governor within 21 days after the primary election.
  • Requires a candidate for governor to identify a candidate for lieutenant governor when filing a declaration of intent to seek nomination.
  • Establishes that the two candidates will be considered for nomination jointly.
  • Requires a candidate to provide consent in writing.
  • Requires the governor and lieutenant governor candidates to be listed together on the ballot in a primary election.
  • Requires a candidate for lieutenant governor to file a certificate of candidacy at the time the candidate is designated by the candidate for governor.

HISTORY: ["09/21/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines requirements for candidates seeking to be members of the General Assembly, and members of the General Assembly.
  • Establishes that in determining whether a candidate or member is a resident of a district, the state board or court will consider 13 factors.
  • Establishes that the residency of a candidate or member on active duty may not be considered eligible or ineligible based solely on where the member is stationed.
  • Requires the General Assembly Counsel to annually review the compliance of each member with residency requirements.

HISTORY: ["10/19/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits anyone from collecting absentee ballots in a container that is not an official ballot drop box, or that is not labeled or designated to be an official or unofficial dropbox.
  • Provides felony level penalties including fines and imprisonment.

HISTORY: ["09/17/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the State Board to establish guidelines for verification of signatures on absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Prohibits a local board from removing an absentee ballot from the envelope or counting the ballot unless the ballot is 1) signed by the voter and witness, with certain exceptions, 2) the signature is verified.
  • Makes exceptions for the witness signature requirement with ballots returned by an active duty service member who is overseas, or his or her spouse or dependent also living overseas.
  • Requires a local board to verify the signature on the return envelope by comparing it to the voter registration signature on record.

HISTORY: ["10/31/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits a person simultaneously holding a party office and an elected public office, excluding those who hold an elected public office and are on the national presidential nominating convention ballot or who hold the office of delegate at a presidential nominating convention.
  • Prohibits an individual from being a candidate for more than one elected office.

HISTORY: ["11/01/2021 - Pre-filed","01/12/2022 - First Reading Ways and Means"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Replaces the term "gun" with "firearm."
  • Defines the term "firearm" and includes examples.
  • Forbids anyone carrying a firearm to a polling site, or within 100 feet of one, during an election, including the parking lot, with certain exceptions.

HISTORY: "12/06/2021 - First Reading Reapportionment and Redistricting"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill sets forth a redistricting plan for congressional districts in the State of Maryland.

HISTORY: "12/06/2021 - First Reading Reapportionment and Redistricting"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill sets forth a redistricting plan for congressional districts in the State of Maryland.

HISTORY: "12/06/2021 - First Reading House Rules and Executive Nominations"
BILLSUMMARY: This bill sets forth a redistricting plan for congressional districts in the State of Maryland.

COAUTHORS: ["Christopher Caiazzo","Patrick Corey","Bradley Farrin","Justin Fecteau","Chloe Maxmin","Sarah Pebworth","Sophia Warren","Lynne Williams"]

ORDERED SENT FORTHWITH.","06/15/2021 - House: H-A to C-A (H-597)","06/15/2021 - House: C-A (H-530)","06/16/2021 - On motion by Senator BREEN of Cumberland PLACED ON THE SPECIAL APPROPRIATIONS TABLE pending PASSAGE TO BE ENACTED, in concurrence.","07/19/2021 - CARRIED OVER, IN THE SAME POSTURE, TO ANY SPECIAL OR REGULAR SESSION OF THE 130th LEGISLATURE, PURSUANT TO JOINT ORDER HP 1302","05/09/2022 - In possession of the Senate when the Legislature adjourned Sine Die and was placed in the Legislative Files. (DEAD)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill requires the Secretary of State to produce and publicly disseminate a guide to election procedures, develop an election complaint process, report to the Legislature on election issues after a general election, and conduct a pilot post-election audit.

COAUTHORS: ["Joseph Baldacci","Christopher Caiazzo","Michelle Dunphy","Bradley Farrin","Louis Luchini","Colleen Madigan","Victoria Morales","Stephen Moriarty","Lois Reckitt"]
HISTORY: ["12/15/2021 - Received by the Clerk of the House on December 15, 2021.","12/15/2021 - The Bill was REFERRED to the Committee on VETERANS AND LEGAL AFFAIRS pursuant to Joint Rule 308.2 and ordered printed pursuant to Joint Rule 401.","01/28/2022 - Work Session Held: TABLED","02/07/2022 - Work Session Held","02/07/2022 - Voted: OTP-AM","03/25/2022 - Reported Out: OTP-AM","03/29/2022 - CONSENT CALENDAR - FIRST DAY","03/29/2022 - Under suspension of the rules CONSENT CALENDAR - SECOND DAY.","03/29/2022 - The Bill was PASSED TO BE ENGROSSED as Amended by Committee Amendment \"A\" (H-840).","03/29/2022 - Sent for concurrence. ORDERED SENT FORTHWITH.","03/31/2022 - Report READ and ACCEPTED","03/31/2022 - Roll Call Ordered Roll Call Number 659 Yeas 33 - Nays 0 - Excused 1 - Absent 0","03/31/2022 - READ ONCE","03/31/2022 - Committee Amendment \"A\" (H-840) READ and ADOPTED","03/31/2022 - Under suspension of the Rules, READ A SECOND TIME and PASSED TO BE ENGROSSED AS AMENDED by Committee Amendment \"A\" (H-840) in concurrence","03/31/2022 - PASSED TO BE ENACTED.","03/31/2022 - Sent for concurrence. ORDERED SENT FORTHWITH.","03/31/2022 - House: C-A (H-840)","04/05/2022 - PASSED TO BE ENACTED, in concurrence."]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill provides that a person commits a Class C felony if they intentionally interfere by force, violence, intimidation, or any other physical act with a public official performing an election function.

ORDERED SENT FORTHWITH.","06/10/2021 - PASSED TO BE ENACTED.","06/10/2021 - Sent for concurrence. ORDERED SENT FORTHWITH.","06/10/2021 - Senate: C-A (S-209)","06/14/2021 - PASSED TO BE ENACTED, in concurrence."]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Clarifies which elections may be included in ranked choice voting.
  • Allows voters who have an alternative registration signature statement on file to authorize any other Maine registered voter to sign direct initiative of legislation petitions and people's veto petitions, along with other items previously listed.
  • Clarifies that this method of signing satisfies existing requirements.
  • Requires that if someone applies for, renews, or updates a drivers license or state issued ID card, the bureau will record the documentation that provides proof of voter eligibility, unless the individual opts out.
  • Updates the number of nomination petition signatures required for statewide and national office seekers.
  • Changes the deadline to October 1 for a state committee to certify whether is a contest among candidates for several offices.
  • Requires that petitions be delivered to the registrar or Secretary of State for certification by certain deadlines.
  • Allows 16 year olds who are conditionally registered to serve as election clerks.
  • Allows the order on the ballot to be modified for ranked choice contests with certain provisions.
  • Clarifies requirements for counting ballots using ranked choice voting.
  • Allows a municipality to obtain and install secured drop boxes for absentee ballots that meet specified criteria related to location, security, quantity, design, accessibility, monitoring, labeling, with certain exceptions.
  • Outlines how absentee ballots in the dropbox must be removed and processed.
  • Requires an electronic absentee ballot application to be accepted if it contains a voter's name, date of birth, and certain address(es).
  • Clarifies that a voter applying for an absentee ballot may be asked for their phone number and email address, which will remain confidential.
  • Requires a clerk to issue absentee ballots when the official ballots become available. 
  • Prohibits a clerk from issuing an absentee ballot to any third person who has been issued five absentee ballots for voters in the municipality until the person has returned one of those ballots.
  • Adds "incapacity or illness" where a voter is unable to leave home as an approved reason for requesting an absentee ballot after the deadline.
  • Prohibits the clerk from issuing a ballot to a candidate other than the candidate's own ballot.
  • Requires the clerk to note whether a cured absentee ballot was accepted or accepted but challenged, including requiring certain specific information. 
  • Requires a clerk verify a voters address and year of birth before issuing a ballot.
  • Outlines procedures for the clerk to examine signatures and affidavits and outlines what to do in specific situations.
  • Provides procedures for curing defects on an absentee ballot envelope.
  • Provides procedures for wardens verifying signatures on absentee ballot return envelopes.
  • Requires the clerk to note on the absentee ballot envelope if the ballot was rejected. 
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain an online service for voters to request and track absentee ballots.
  • Requires that upon determination of electors for President, the Governor must send each elector's name and number of votes each candidate for President received statewide and by Congressional district.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows a municipal budget approved in the previous year to be considered approved if the meeting is delayed because of public health concerns related to COVID-19.
  • Allows assessors to commit property taxes based on the approved budget.
  • Allows the municipal treasurer to disburse funds based on a warrant created for that purpose and signed by a majority of municipal officers during a governor-declared state of emergency related to COVID-19, and for 30 days after the emergency ends.
  • Allows municipal officers to postpone a scheduled election at least two days before the election. 
  • Outlines guidelines for notification and rescheduling the election.
  • Outlines guidelines for notification when the new election is scheduled and ready to be held.
  • Outlines guidelines for absentee ballots and establishes that the same rules apply for municipal ballot referendums.
  • Allows a referendum vote hearing to be carried out remotely following certain guidelines.
  • Outlines guidelines for municipal officers terms of office during a state of emergency due to COVID19 and when to conduct secret ballot elections during the state of emergency.
  • Requires municipal officers file the wording for a referendum question by 30 days before the referendum.
  • Suspends the requirement for a written ballot to change the property tax levy at an open town hall meeting during a state of emergency, and allows instead for a show of hands or voice vote.
  • Retroactivly applies this bill to January 15, 2021 and repeals it as of June 30, 2022.

ORDERED SENT FORTHWITH.","03/30/2021 - Carried over, in the same posture, to a subsequent special or regular session of the 130th Legislature, pursuant to Joint Order SP 435.","05/20/2021 - Work Session Held","05/20/2021 - Voted: ONTP","05/26/2021 - Reported Out: ONTP","06/02/2021 - Pursuant to Joint Rule 310.3 Placed in Legislative Files (DEAD)"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill repeals ranked-choice voting in general elections for President of the United States and proposes to adopt an interstate compact to elect the President of the United States by national popular vote. Under the compact, all of a state's electoral votes would be awarded to the presidential candidate who receives the most popular votes in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. The bill would take effect only if enacted by states possessing a majority of the electoral votes, which is at least 270 of 538.

BILLSUMMARY: This bill provides that a state employee must be granted a paid day off if the employee provides at least six hours of volunteer time assisting election officials on the day of an election.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires training for officials seeking to designate election challengers and establishes required training elements.
  • Requires election inspectors to attend the training.
  • Requires challengers to have a certified completion of training to serve as a challenger, with certain specifications.
  • Requires that training be held before each election, with specified requirements related to audience, content, timelines, and certificates of completion. 
  • Requires the Secretary of State to keep a registry of all those who have been trained, with specific related requirements.
  • Outlines penalties for not following the established rules.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits the use of a polling station in a building belonging to a candidate.
  • Removes conflicting language regarding establishment of polling place locations.
  • Authorizes the use of a privately owned banquet hall or similar facility if another suitable location is not available, but the facility may not belong to a candidate or a sponsor of a political committee.
  • Outlines procedures for using the facility.
  • Authorizes a legislative body to establish a central polling place and outlines related procedures.
  • Defines relevant terms.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires each clerk to make available an identification badge to each challenger in a precinct, with specific information about the content and style of the identification.

  • Requires a challenger to immediately check in when arriving at a precinct and obtain the identification badge, wear it the entire time they are in the precinct, and notify proper authorities when leaving the precinct and return the badge.

  • Requires the election inspector to record arrival and departure times of all challengers, including replacement challengers, in the poll book.

  • Requires the election inspector to record an challenges made by the challenger in the poll book and include how the were resolved.

Jeff Irwin As Conferee 06/30/2022","07/01/2022 - Senate Conference Committee on HB5783 (00:05 7/1/2022 Senate Appropriations, State Capitol Building)","07/01/2022 - House Conference Committee on HB5783 (00:05 7/1/2022 Senate Appropriations, State Capitol Building)","07/01/2022 - Conference Report Received","07/01/2022 - Conference Report Adopted Roll Call # 369 Yeas 97 Nays 9 Excused 0 Not Voting 4","07/01/2022 - Retransmitted","07/01/2022 - Conference Report Received In Senate","07/01/2022 - Senate Adopted Conference Report With Immediate Effect Roll Call # 403 Yeas 37 Nays 0 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","07/01/2022 - Conference Report Adopted By Senate","07/01/2022 - Bill Ordered Enrolled","07/01/2022 - Presented To The Governor 07/14/2022 12:10 Pm","07/20/2022 - Approved By The Governor With Line Item(s) Vetoed 07/20/2022 12:39 Pm","07/20/2022 - Filed With Secretary Of State 07/20/2022 03:20 Pm","07/20/2022 - Assigned Pa 166'22 With Immediate Effect","09/21/2022 - Disapproved Line Item(s) Re-referred To Committee On Appropriations"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Appropriates funds for government agencies for the 2022-23 fiscal year.

HISTORY: ["06/16/2022 - Introduced By Representative Jeff Yaroch","06/16/2022 - Read A First Time","06/16/2022 - Referred To Committee On Local Government And Municipal Finance","06/21/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/21/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes dates for primary elections.
  • Authorizes a board of trustees of a township to adopt a resolution to conduct nonpartisan elections for specific offices and outlines approval procedures and implementation deadlines.
  • Outlines procedures based upon the number of candidates running in the election.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for a candidate to file a nominating petition for a township office, and requirements for the clerk to administer the petitions and nonpartisan ballots.
  • Outline the number of votes requires to win the primary elections and certification procedures.
  • Outlines procedures in the case of death or disqualification.
  • Outlines qualifications and requirements for candidates running for office in the township.
  • Describes the ballot format for these elections.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["06/16/2022 - Introduced By Representative Jeff Yaroch","06/16/2022 - Read A First Time","06/16/2022 - Referred To Committee On Local Government And Municipal Finance","06/21/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/21/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires school board ballot questions be subject to the general property tax act starting January 1, 2023.
  • Establishes required dates for regular and regular primary elections.
  • Codifies requirements for school district ballot questions that were previously optional, including petition signatures, format of the petition, filing deadline, and other deadlines.
  • Establishes that school district ballot questions are subject to the general property tax act starting January 1, 2023.

HISTORY: ["06/16/2022 - Introduced By Representative Jeff Yaroch","06/16/2022 - Read A First Time","06/16/2022 - Referred To Committee On Local Government And Municipal Finance","06/21/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/21/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires that a local taxing unit submit a proposal on a question of imposing new millage, or increasing or renewing it, only at certain regular elections, starting December 31, 2022.
  • Puts a deadline of January 1, 2023 on the requirement that a taxing unit hold no more than two elections in a calendar year.

COAUTHORS: ["Andrew Beeler\u00a0*","Joseph Bellino\u00a0*","Ann Bollin\u00a0*","John Damoose\u00a0*","Andrew Fink\u00a0*","Beth Griffin\u00a0*","Matt Hall\u00a0*","Steven Johnson\u00a0*","Bronna Kahle\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","David Martin\u00a0*","Luke Meerman\u00a0*","Jack O'Malley\u00a0*","Pat Outman\u00a0*","Brad Paquette\u00a0*","Bryan Posthumus\u00a0*","Daire Rendon\u00a0*","John Roth\u00a0*","Jeff Yaroch\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/11/2021 - Introduced By Representative Andrew Fink","03/11/2021 - Read A First Time","03/11/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/16/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/11/2021","04/13/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","04/13/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","04/13/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","04/22/2021 - Read A Second Time","04/22/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","04/22/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","04/27/2021 - Read a third time","04/27/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 145 Yeas 109 Nays 0 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","04/27/2021 - Transmitted","04/28/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","06/15/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 6/15/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","06/16/2022 - Reported Favorably Without Amendment","06/16/2022 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","06/16/2022 - Referred to Committee of the Whole"]

["09/14/2021 - Introduced By Representative David Martin","09/14/2021 - Read A First Time","09/14/2021 - Referred To Committee On Local Government And Municipal Finance","09/14/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 09/14/2021","02/16/2022 - House Local Government and Municipal Finance (12:00 2/16/2022 Room 521, House Office Building)","03/02/2022 - House Local Government and Municipal Finance (12:00 3/2/2022 Room 521, House Office Building)","03/02/2022 - Reported With Recommendation Without Amendment","03/02/2022 - Referred To Second Reading","03/17/2022 - Read A Second Time","03/17/2022 - Placed On Third Reading","03/22/2022 - Read a third time","03/22/2022 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 133 Yeas 102 Nays 3 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","03/22/2022 - Transmitted","03/24/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/04/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/4/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","05/05/2022 - Reported Favorably Without Amendment","05/05/2022 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","05/05/2022 - Referred to Committee of the Whole","05/25/2022 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably Without Amendment(s)","05/25/2022 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading","05/26/2022 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 284 Yeas 37 Nays 0 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","05/26/2022 - Inserted Full Title","06/01/2022 - Returned From Senate Without Amendment With Immediate Effect And Full Title","06/01/2022 - Full Title Agreed To","06/01/2022 - Bill Ordered Enrolled","06/07/2022 - Presented To The Governor 06/07/2022 09:20 Am","06/16/2022 - Approved By The Governor 06/16/2022 11:22 Am","06/16/2022 - Filed With Secretary Of State 06/16/2022 04:58 Pm","06/16/2022 - Assigned Pa 104'22 With Immediate Effect"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines procedures in the case of one or more vacancies in an elective or appointed township office, including what to do if there is no quorum, and temporary appointments.
  • Outlines procedures in the case of a township official submitting a resignation.
  • Specifies when a township board does not fill a vacancy and when instead there is a special election.
  • Specifies procedures for the special election.
  • Clarifies that a vacancy with the township constable requires different procedures, and outlines the procedures.
  • Provides exceptions for political organizations and outlines procedures for political organizations, including timelines and public inspection of the ballot.

HISTORY: ["06/15/2021 - Introduced By Representative Andrea Schroeder","06/15/2021 - Read A First Time","06/15/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/16/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/15/2021","12/07/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 12/7/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","01/18/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/18/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","01/25/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/25/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/01/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 2/1/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/01/2022 - Reported With Recommendation Without Amendment","02/01/2022 - Referred To Second Reading","02/09/2022 - Read A Second Time","02/09/2022 - Placed On Third Reading","02/10/2022 - Read a third time","02/10/2022 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 48 Yeas 80 Nays 25 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","02/10/2022 - Transmitted","02/15/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/25/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/25/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","05/26/2022 - Reported Favorably Without Amendment","05/26/2022 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","05/26/2022 - Referred to Committee of the Whole","06/08/2022 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably Without Amendment(s)","06/08/2022 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading","06/15/2022 - Passed Roll Call # 315 Yeas 23 Nays 14 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","06/15/2022 - Immediate Effect Defeated","06/15/2022 - Inserted Full Title","06/15/2022 - Returned From Senate Without Amendment With Full Title","06/15/2022 - Full Title Agreed To","06/15/2022 - Bill Ordered Enrolled","06/21/2022 - Presented To The Governor 06/21/2022 10:38 Am","07/01/2022 - Vetoed By The Governor 07/01/2022","09/21/2022 - Re-referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the governor to call a special election or direct that the vacancy be filled at the next general election, if a vacancy occurs in the state legislature.
  • Directs the governor to take specific actions based upon the timing of the vacancy, and includes notification and administrative procedure requirements.

HISTORY: ["06/15/2021 - Introduced By Representative Richard Steenland","06/15/2021 - Read A First Time","06/15/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/16/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/15/2021","06/14/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 6/14/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that constitutional amendment petitions must be submitted at least 150 days before an election (from 120 days).
  • Provides that initiative petitions must be submitted at least 190 days before the election (from 160 days).
  • Requires the board of state canvassers complete a canvass at least 90 days (from two months) before the election.
  • Provides that the board of state canvassers make an official declaration of the sufficiency of a petition 90 days (from two months) before the election.
  • Provides that the board of state canvassers make an official declaration of the sufficiency of an initiative petition 130 days (from 100 days) before the election.

HISTORY: ["05/19/2021 - Introduced By Representative Steven Johnson","05/19/2021 - Read A First Time","05/19/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","05/20/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/19/2021","06/14/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 6/14/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Clarifies that anyone elected as a precinct delegate, or delegate to a convention, is not required to pay political party dues to be able to vote at a convention of that party.

HISTORY: ["06/09/2022 - Introduced By Senator Ruth A. Johnson","06/09/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Adds providing money or influence to sway an in-person or absentee voter to a list of felony offenses.

HISTORY: ["06/09/2022 - Introduced By Senator Ruth A. Johnson","06/09/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits anyone from giving money or "other consideration" to an election official in order to influence in person or absentee voters.
  • Establishes felony penalties for such actions.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines timelines and procedures for examining and approving proof copies of ballots.
  • Outlines procedures and a timeline for candidates wishing to correct an error on the ballot.
  • Outlines the contents for an affidavit of the proof ballot, signed by the clerk.
  • Establishes who should get a copy of the proof ballot.

HISTORY: ["05/24/2022 - Introduced By Representative Jeff Yaroch","05/24/2022 - Read A First Time","05/24/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","05/25/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/25/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires election inspectors to attend training school.
  • Allows any city or township, with no population limits, to conduct their own training of election inspectors as long as the clerk meets certain requirements.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Ruth Johnson\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Runestad\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
