BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines who must approve an absent voter dropbox.
  • Establishes that if the design or construction of the absent voter dropbox is not approved, it may not be used to collect ballots.
  • Requires jurisdictions to use video recording to monitor absent voter drop boxes and establishes related requirements, including notifying voters.
  • Codifies who may drop off an absent voter's ballot at a dropbox location, with felony penalties.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Michael MacDonald\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Michael D. Macdonald","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/05/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/5/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)","10/27/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 10/27/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","11/10/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 11/10/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","11/30/2021 - Senate Substitute (S-1)","11/30/2021 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","11/30/2021 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","11/30/2021 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-1)","12/02/2021 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","12/02/2021 - Substitute (s-1) Concurred In","12/02/2021 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading With Substitute (s-1)","12/09/2021 - Passed Roll Call # 472 Yeas 21 Nays 16 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","12/09/2021 - Received On 12/09/2021","12/09/2021 - Read A First Time","12/09/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/01/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 2/1/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","05/10/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (13:00 5/10/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","05/24/2022 - House Substitute (H-2)","05/24/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 5/24/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","05/24/2022 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-2)","05/24/2022 - Referred To Second Reading"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires all absent voter ballot drop boxes to comply with requirements by June 1, 2022.
  • Removes the requirement that a city clerk must use video monitoring of drop boxes.
  • Outlines rules for collecting absent absent voter ballots from drop boxes, including transport and delivery of ballots, ballot security, documentation, preservation of documentation, and information to be collected in the documentation.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["05/19/2022 - Introduced By Senator Ed Mcbroom","05/19/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows a county board of commissioners in a county with less than 75,000 people to adopt a resolution to conduct nonpartisan elections for certain offices within a certain timeline.
  • Outlines when such elections would be held and outlines other related election procedures.
  • Outlines procedures for nonpartisan election candidates to get on the ballot and outlines ballot requirements.
  • Outlines how to declare a winner in primary nonpartisan elections.
  • Clarifies what to do in the case of a candidate vacancy before the election.
  • Establishes dates for nonpartisan primary and general elections and clarifies when a primary needs to be held for the nonpartisan offices.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes edits for clarity.

HISTORY: ["05/19/2022 - Introduced By Senator Ed Mcbroom","05/19/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows nomination at general primary for charter county positions of sheriff, prosecuting attorney, county clerk, county treasurer, and register of deeds.

HISTORY: ["05/19/2022 - Introduced By Senator Ed Mcbroom","05/19/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill allows counties with a population of less than 75,000 to conduct nonpartisan elections for the office of county commissioner, if the county board of commissioners has adopted the provided resolution in the previous calendar year.

HISTORY: ["05/10/2022 - Introduced By Representative Sue Allor","05/10/2022 - Read A First Time","05/10/2022 - Referred to Committee on Transportation","05/11/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/10/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Clarifies that non-US citizens are not eligible to be county road commissioner or member of the county board of commissioners.

  • Requires anyone seeking the office of county road commissioner in a single-member district to be a resident of the district and to submit petitions signed by registered voters living in the district.
  • Clarifies if a county road commissioner moves outside his or her single-member district, he or she will cease being a county road commissioner and the office will become vacant.
  • Specifies that a qualified individual may be appointed to fill a vacancy for a single-member district seat on the county road commission.

HISTORY: ["05/10/2022 - Introduced By Representative Gary Howell","05/10/2022 - Read A First Time","05/10/2022 - Referred to Committee on Transportation","05/11/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/10/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows a county board of commissioners to pass a resolution that county road commissioners be elected in single-member districts starting in January 1, 2024.
  • Requires the county apportionment commission to establish districts, with certain guidelines, within 60 days of the adoption of the resolution to elect county road commissioners, and reapportion them after each decennial census.
  • Allows the county apportionment commission to establish these districts for future use if the county road commission is an appointed office.
  • Establishes rules for filling a vacancy on an elected county road commission.

HISTORY: ["02/17/2022 - Introduced By Senator Ruth A. Johnson","02/17/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections","02/23/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 2/23/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","03/23/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 3/23/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","03/24/2022 - Senate Substitute (S-1)","03/24/2022 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","03/24/2022 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","03/24/2022 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-1)","04/26/2022 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","04/26/2022 - Substitute (s-1) Concurred In","04/26/2022 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading With Substitute (s-1)","05/04/2022 - Passed Roll Call # 200 Yeas 22 Nays 12 Excused 3 Not Voting 1","05/04/2022 - Received On 05/05/2022","05/05/2022 - Read A First Time","05/05/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits certain parties from including any parts in electronic voting systems provided by certain entities.
  • Clarifies language by adding the word "electronic" in front of "voting system" in multiple places.
  • Requires that any equipment bought after July 1, 2022 not include any parts produced by a prohibited entity.
  • Allows for repair of equipment bought before July 1, 2022.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Kimberly A. BILLSUMMARY: • Lists all required items on a voter registration application.

HISTORY: ["02/23/2021 - Introduced By Representative Beau Lafave","02/23/2021 - Read A First Time","02/23/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/24/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/23/2021","04/12/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 4/12/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that one presidential elector will be chosen from each Congressional District and two will be chosen at-large.
  • Requires that for a candidate for presidential elector to be certified, his or her party must have received the highest number of votes in the Congressional district during the presidential election.
  • Requires that for a candidate for presidential elector to be certified, his or her party must have received the highest number of votes in the state during the presidential election.

HISTORY: ["03/08/2022 - Introduced By Representative Ann Bollin","03/08/2022 - Read A First Time","03/08/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/09/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/08/2022","04/12/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 4/12/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that the Secretary of State is to capture digital photographs on government issued ID renewals and update existing qualified voter photo ID files.
  • Defines "veteran."
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["02/23/2021 - Introduced By Representative Jeff Yaroch","02/23/2021 - Read A First Time","02/23/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/24/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/23/2021","04/12/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 4/12/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes language stating that presidential electors are certified by the Secretary of State.

  • Clarifies that a vote for President and Vice President is a vote for presidential electors for that congressional district and for the state.

HISTORY: ["03/08/2022 - Introduced By Representative Ann Bollin","03/08/2022 - Read A First Time","03/08/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/09/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/08/2022","04/12/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 4/12/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]

["03/08/2022 - Introduced By Representative Ann Bollin","03/08/2022 - Read A First Time","03/08/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/09/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/08/2022","04/12/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 4/12/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to capture or reproduce a driver's license or identity card applicant's facial image and upload it to the qualified voter file.
  • Prohibits any part of an applicants social security number to be displayed on an enhanced driver's license or enhanced identity card.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["03/23/2022 - Introduced By Representative Julie Calley","03/23/2022 - Read A First Time","03/23/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/24/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/23/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Clarifies procedures for if an absent voter ballot application signature does not match the signature on file or if the voter did not sign, including timelines, procedures, notification requirements, drop box deposits, notification methods, possible actions by the voter, deadlines, and administrative procedures.
  • Eliminates conflicting legislation.
  • Outlines detailed rules for rejecting a voter's signature, including considerations for the clerk to consider.
  • Clarifies procedures for handling the ballot and envelope when a signature is rejected.

HISTORY: ["03/23/2022 - Introduced By Representative Julie Calley","03/23/2022 - Read A First Time","03/23/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/24/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/23/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that voters may complete an application for an absentee ballot on the Secretary of State's website and have it electronically sent to the appropriate municipality.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to maintain the application website.
  • Outlines requirements for the content and processing of the application for an absentee ballot on the website.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["03/23/2022 - Introduced By Representative Julie Calley","03/23/2022 - Read A First Time","03/23/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/24/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/23/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires an affidavit of identity to include all jurisdictions in which a candidate previously sought office, unless it was an office for which the candidate was not required to file campaign statements.
  • Requires the affidavit of identity to include a compliance statement section.
  • Requires the candidate to be truthful in the affidavit of identity and outlines actions in case of omissions about previous offices sought, including what may lead to disqualification.
  • Requires a candidate who formed a candidate committee to submit a campaign statement for the period, unless the candidate requests a waiver.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["03/23/2022 - Introduced By Senator Wayne A. Schmidt","03/23/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires an affidavit of identity to include all jurisdictions in which a candidate previously sought office, unless it was an office for which the candidate was not required to file campaign statements.
  • Requires the affidavit of identity to include a compliance statement section.
  • Clarifies what counts as a statement.
  • Requires the candidate to be truthful in the affidavit of identity and outlines actions in case of omissions about previous offices sought, including what may lead to disqualification.
  • Requires a candidate who formed a candidate committee to submit a campaign statement for the period, unless the candidate requests a waiver.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["03/22/2022 - Introduced By Representative Laurie Pohutsky","03/22/2022 - Read A First Time","03/22/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/23/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/22/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires polls to be open 7am-8pm on Election Day.
  • Stipulates that polls should be open for at least eight hours during early voting, and includes the timeframe for poll openings.
  • Requires a public notification about days, times, and locations polls are open for early voting.  
  • Directs each jurisdiction to provide at least one early voting polling place and outlines how the clerk may achieve this.
  • Directs the Secretary of State to cooperate with each jurisdiction in providing technical assistance for early voting.
  • Establishes that early voting polling places are subject to the same requirements as Election Day polling places.
  • Requires that the poll book be maintained and ballots be processed and tabulated the same way as they would be on Election Day.
  • Requires that the poll book be divided by date, with separate records maintained for each day during the early voting period.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires jurisdictions with access to the absent voter ballot tracker system to allow voters to use it to track their absent voter ballots.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to expand the system where a voter may be notified updates regarding the status of their ballot.

HISTORY: ["03/23/2022 - Introduced By Senator Wayne A. Schmidt","03/23/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows voters to use the absent voter application on the Secretary of State's website and have it sent electronically to the appropriate jurisdiction.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to maintain the application on the Secretary's website.
  • Outlines specifications and requirements for the absent voter application on the website.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

  • Defines relevant terms.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines what a clerk should do when receiving an absent voter ballot application where the signature does not match up with the signature on file.
  • Makes conforming changes.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the state to reimburse a municipality for the cost of conducting a special election for a vacancy for state senator or representative, with certain requirements.
  • Outlines repayment procedures, source of funding, qualification requirements, and notification requirements if the request is not approved.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines procedures for when a clerk receives an absent voter ballot application missing a signature, including timeline and notification requirements.
  • Specifies when the clerk may reject the absent voter ballot application with no signature.
  • Specifies procedures if the board of election inspectors determines signatures do not match on an absentee ballot envelope.
  • Specifies procedures for the clerk if he or she rejects an absent voter ballot application because signatures do not match.
  • Provides language for a signature verification statement, the unsigned ballot statement, instructions for the absent voter ballot.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that the information of a registered or preregistered voter under 18 is not subject to public disclosure laws.
  • Provides that the registered voter's information becomes subject to public disclosure laws on the voter's 18th birthday.
  • Makes conforming changes.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines misdemeanor penalties for making false statements related to elections.
  • Provides that anyone employing someone for election-related purposes, who committed one of the mentioned crimes, is subject to a civil fine.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits a clerk from canceling a voter registration based solely on a voter not voting.
  • Establishes guidelines and procedures for clerks to confirm a voter should stay on the active voter list if they have not voted since November 2000.
  • Outlines what to do if a related notification sent to a voter comes back as undeliverable.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the county clerk to monthly send a list of all deceased residents to the clerk or each city or township in the county, and requires authorities to cancel the registration of those deceased individuals who were registered to vote.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for verifying qualified voters who were assigned a placeholder date of birth because their date of birth was unknown.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Ruth A. Johnson","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)","12/08/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 12/8/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","12/09/2021 - Senate Substitute (S-1)","12/09/2021 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","12/09/2021 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","12/09/2021 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-1)","03/15/2022 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","03/15/2022 - Substitute (s-1) Concurred In","03/15/2022 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading With Substitute (s-1)","03/17/2022 - Passed Roll Call # 90 Yeas 22 Nays 16 Excused 0 Not Voting 0","03/17/2022 - Received On 03/17/2022","03/17/2022 - Read A First Time","03/17/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Applies existing rules related to the counting board to the absent voter counting board.
  • Establishes that a challenger may be designated to serve at an absent voter counting board.
  • Allows a specific increased number of challengers if a counting board has more than 2,999 absent voter ballots to count.
  • Allows one challenger for every three election inspectors at an absent voter counting board.
  • Allows a challenger to be replaced if an absent voter counting board continues to work after polls close on Election Day.

HISTORY: ["03/17/2022 - Introduced By Senator Lana Theis","03/17/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Adds counties to the list of jurisdictions the Secretary of State must provide information to about a canceled voter registration.
  • Requires the clerk to monthly update the qualified voter file with deaths.
  • Outlines what the clerk should do when receiving information from the Secretary of State about canceled voter registrations, and what the Secretary should do related to electronic notifications.
  • Outlines what a clerk should do in the 16-45 days before the election related to updating qualified voter files.
  • Outlines what the clerk should do in the 1-15 days before the election to update the qualified voter files.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to monthly post the number of voter registrations canceled, including specific information.

HISTORY: ["05/18/2021 - Introduced By Representative Julie Alexander","05/18/2021 - Read A First Time","05/18/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","05/19/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/18/2021","05/25/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 5/25/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","09/14/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","09/14/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","09/14/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","09/15/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 9/15/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","03/09/2022 - Read A Second Time","03/09/2022 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","03/09/2022 - Placed On Third Reading","03/10/2022 - Read a third time","03/10/2022 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 114 Yeas 55 Nays 46 Excused 0 Not Voting 5","03/10/2022 - Transmitted","03/15/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires applicants for precinct election inspector to sign an attestation stating that the information in their application is true, with penalties for perjury if the information is not true.
  • Requires the clerk to maintain a file of applications.
  • Requires the clerk to give each chairperson of a precinct, and each political party chairperson, a list of precinct election inspectors with a certification that the people on the list have a complete application file, including listing party affiliation.
  • Directs that the list of precinct election inspectors be made available to the public.

COAUTHORS: ["Andrew Beeler\u00a0*","Robert Bezotte\u00a0*","Ann Bollin\u00a0*","Kenneth Borton\u00a0*","Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Andrew Fink\u00a0*","Steven Johnson\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Pat Outman\u00a0*","Brad Paquette\u00a0*","Bryan Posthumus\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["09/14/2021 - Introduced By Representative Andrew Beeler","09/14/2021 - Read A First Time","09/14/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","09/14/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 09/14/2021","09/21/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 9/21/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","10/05/2021 - House Substitute (H-2)","10/05/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 10/5/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","10/05/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-2)","10/05/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","03/09/2022 - Read A Second Time","03/09/2022 - Substitute (h-2) Adopted","03/09/2022 - Placed On Third Reading","03/10/2022 - Read a third time","03/10/2022 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 111 Yeas 58 Nays 43 Excused 0 Not Voting 5","03/10/2022 - Transmitted","03/15/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Expands methods to apply for an absent voter ballot.

  • Prohibits absent voter ballot applications to be made available more than 75 days before an election.

  • Requires a voter to physically sign an absent voter ballot application and not use a digital signature.

HISTORY: ["08/17/2021 - Introduced By Representative Julie Calley","08/17/2021 - Read A First Time","08/17/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","08/18/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 08/17/2021","09/21/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 9/21/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","10/05/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 10/5/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","10/19/2021 - House Substitute (H-3)","10/19/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 10/19/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","10/19/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-3)","10/19/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","03/09/2022 - Read A Second Time","03/09/2022 - Substitute (h-3) Adopted","03/09/2022 - Placed On Third Reading","03/10/2022 - Read a third time","03/10/2022 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 112 Yeas 56 Nays 45 Excused 0 Not Voting 5","03/10/2022 - Transmitted","03/15/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that an absent voter may apply for an application through email and fax, along with mail and in-person.
  • Prohibits absent voter ballot applications to be sent out until 75 days before an election.
  • Requires that a voter request an application for an absent ballot before one is sent to him or her, unless the voter is on the permanent absent voter list.
  • Prohibits the Secretary of State from sending absent voter applications to any voter.

HISTORY: ["08/17/2021 - Introduced By Representative Sarah Lightner","08/17/2021 - Read A First Time","08/17/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","08/18/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 08/17/2021","10/26/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 10/26/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/22/2022 - House Substitute (H-1)","02/22/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 2/22/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/22/2022 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","02/22/2022 - Referred To Second Reading","03/09/2022 - Read A Second Time","03/09/2022 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","03/09/2022 - Placed On Third Reading","03/10/2022 - Read a third time","03/10/2022 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 115 Yeas 57 Nays 44 Excused 0 Not Voting 5","03/10/2022 - Transmitted","03/15/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits governmental agencies from accepting private gifts for election related purposes.
  • Makes certain exceptions related to locales for voting related work.
  • Defines terms.

HISTORY: ["05/25/2021 - Introduced By Representative Julie Calley","05/25/2021 - Read A First Time","05/25/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","05/26/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/25/2021","06/03/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (08:15 6/3/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","09/14/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","09/14/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","09/14/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","09/15/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 9/15/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","03/09/2022 - Read A Second Time","03/09/2022 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","03/09/2022 - Placed On Third Reading","03/10/2022 - Read a third time","03/10/2022 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 110 Yeas 54 Nays 47 Excused 0 Not Voting 5","03/10/2022 - Transmitted","03/15/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows organizations to designate additional challengers to an absent voter counting board precinct.
  • Establishes rules for if the counting cannot be properly viewed, limits on the number of challengers, space guidelines, and where the challengers may be.
  • Requires a challenger to be a Michigan registered voter, and not a candidate in the jurisdiction where he or she is serving. 
  • Clarifies other requirements and rules for challengers.
  • Outlines requirements for the statement by an organization appointing challengers, including making several previously optional aspects mandatory for the organization and the clerk.
  • Requires clerks to provide a designated area where challengers may observe voters signing in and voting.
  • Outlines requirements for the designated area and authorized locations for challengers.
  • Lists appropriate actions for challengers.
  • Requires all challenges made to be recorded and delivered to tabulating locations.
  • Adds possible locations for election activities to include a city or township clerk's office, or any satellite office.

HISTORY: ["02/04/2021 - Introduced By Representative Steve Marino","02/04/2021 - Read A First Time","02/04/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/09/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/04/2021","02/23/2021 - Reported With Recommendation Without Amendment","02/23/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","03/03/2021 - Read A Second Time","03/03/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","03/09/2021 - Read a third time","03/09/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 28 Yeas 87 Nays 22 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","03/09/2021 - Transmitted","03/10/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","03/09/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 3/9/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","03/10/2022 - Reported Favorably Without Amendment","03/10/2022 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","03/10/2022 - Referred to Committee of the Whole"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to post the name of each jurisdiction's clerk that is not current in his or her continuing election education training on the department of state website by July 1 in odd numbered years. 
  • Requires the Secretary of State to remove the name when provided with the required proof that the training was completed.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to send notice to clerks who are not current in their continuing election education training by June 1 in odd numbered years, and to not put their names on the website if they complete training by July 1.

HISTORY: ["07/14/2021 - Introduced By Representative Bradley Slagh","07/14/2021 - Read A First Time","07/14/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","07/15/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 07/14/2021","09/21/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 9/21/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","09/28/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","09/28/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 9/28/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","09/28/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","09/28/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","12/14/2021 - Read A Second Time","12/14/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","12/14/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","12/14/2021 - Placed On Immediate Passage","12/14/2021 - Read a third time","12/14/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 613 Yeas 102 Nays 0 Excused 0 Not Voting 5","12/14/2021 - Transmitted","01/12/2022 - Referred to Committee on Elections","02/02/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 2/2/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","02/09/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 2/9/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","02/10/2022 - Senate Substitute (S-3)","02/10/2022 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-3)","02/10/2022 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","02/10/2022 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-3)","03/01/2022 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably With Substitute (s-3)","03/01/2022 - Substitute (s-3) Concurred In","03/01/2022 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading With Substitute (s-3)","03/02/2022 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 50 Yeas 36 Nays 0 Excused 2 Not Voting 0","03/02/2022 - Inserted Full Title","03/02/2022 - Returned From Senate With Substitute (s-3) With Immediate Effect And Full Title","03/02/2022 - Laid Over One Day Under The Rules","03/08/2022 - Senate Substitute (s-3) Concurred In","03/08/2022 - Roll Call Roll Call # 96 Yeas 101 Nays 0 Excused 0 Not Voting 5","03/08/2022 - Full Title Agreed To","03/08/2022 - Bill Ordered Enrolled","03/09/2022 - Presented To The Governor 03/09/2022 02:54 Pm","03/23/2022 - Approved By The Governor 03/23/2022 09:45 Am","03/23/2022 - Filed With Secretary Of State 03/23/2022 10:48 Am","03/23/2022 - Assigned Pa 40'22 With Immediate Effect"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to immediately notify the board of state canvassers about the filing of a petition, specifying timelines and methods of notification.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to post public information on the department's website about the filing of the petition, with specific timelines and instructions.
  • Prohibits the Secretary of State from accepting further filings regarding the same petition after the petition has been filed.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Roger Victory","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","08/31/2021 - Senate Elections (15:00 8/31/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","09/02/2021 - Senate Substitute (S-1)","09/02/2021 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","09/02/2021 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","09/02/2021 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-1)","09/09/2021 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","09/09/2021 - Substitute (s-1) Concurred In","09/09/2021 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading With Substitute (s-1)","09/15/2021 - House Elections (09:00 9/15/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","11/10/2021 - Passed Roll Call # 429 Yeas 34 Nays 0 Excused 1 Not Voting 1","11/10/2021 - Vote Reconsidered","11/10/2021 - Passed Roll Call # 431 Yeas 31 Nays 4 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","11/10/2021 - Received On 11/10/2021","11/10/2021 - Read A First Time","11/10/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/01/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 3/1/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State, within 60 days before a November general election, to prepare a report to the legislature for each municipality outlining the completion of training and requires the report be posted on the Department of State website.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to sent a notice to each municipality not current on its training within 90 days of the November general election, and outlines reporting procedures based on the response from the municipality.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Kevin Daley","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/05/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/5/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)","10/20/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 10/20/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","10/21/2021 - Senate Substitute (S-1)","10/21/2021 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","10/21/2021 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","10/21/2021 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-1)","11/09/2021 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","11/09/2021 - Substitute (s-1) Concurred In","11/09/2021 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading With Substitute (s-1)","11/10/2021 - Passed Roll Call # 440 Yeas 20 Nays 15 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","11/10/2021 - Received On 11/10/2021","11/10/2021 - Read A First Time","11/10/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/01/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 3/1/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to create and require signature verification training for clerks.
  • Outlines requirements for developing the signature verification training.
  • Lists items the training must not include.

HISTORY: ["02/22/2022 - Introduced By Representative Gregory Markkanen","02/22/2022 - Read A First Time","02/22/2022 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/23/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/22/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the board of county canvassers to elect a chair and vice-chair at their first meeting (rather than in the month of January).
  • Provides clarifying language.

HISTORY: ["11/30/2021 - Introduced By Representative Ann Bollin","11/30/2021 - Read A First Time","11/30/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","12/01/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/30/2021","01/18/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/18/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","01/25/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/25/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/22/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 2/22/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/22/2022 - Reported With Recommendation Without Amendment","02/22/2022 - Referred To Second Reading"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Makes conforming changes regarding drivers license and personal identification card rules.
  • Changes the word voter to elector throughout.

HISTORY: ["11/30/2021 - Introduced By Representative Ann Bollin","11/30/2021 - Read A First Time","11/30/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","12/01/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/30/2021","01/18/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/18/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","01/25/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/25/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/22/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 2/22/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/22/2022 - Reported With Recommendation Without Amendment","02/22/2022 - Referred To Second Reading"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Allows an applicants signature on an operator's or chauffeur's license renewal to be uploaded to their qualified voter file.

HISTORY: ["11/30/2021 - Introduced By Representative Ann Bollin","11/30/2021 - Read A First Time","11/30/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","12/01/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/30/2021","01/18/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/18/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","01/25/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/25/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/22/2022 - House Substitute (H-1)","02/22/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 2/22/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/22/2022 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","02/22/2022 - Referred To Second Reading"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to capture an applicant's signature when an applicant is renewing a driver's license or identity card and upload it to the qualified voter file.
  • Clarifies the definition of "veteran."

HISTORY: ["02/04/2021 - Introduced By Representative Pauline Wendzel","02/04/2021 - Read A First Time","02/04/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/09/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/04/2021","02/23/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","02/23/2021 - Referred To Committee On Judiciary, With Substitute (h-1)","03/09/2021 - Judiciary (09:00 3/9/2021 Room 519, House Office Building)","03/09/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","03/09/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","05/25/2021 - Read A Second Time","05/25/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","05/25/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","05/26/2021 - Read a third time","05/26/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 239 Yeas 66 Nays 43 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","05/26/2021 - Title Amended","05/26/2021 - Transmitted","05/27/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","01/19/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 1/19/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","02/16/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 2/16/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","02/17/2022 - Reported Favorably Without Amendment","02/17/2022 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","02/17/2022 - Referred to Committee of the Whole"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Codifies that a person submitting an absent voter ballot application with false information or forged signature is committing a felony.
  • Codifies that a person submitting another voter's absent ballot application without consent is guilty of a felony.
  • Codifies that a person who submits an absent voter application with the intent to obtain multiple ballots for a person is guilty of a felony.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["02/04/2021 - Introduced By Representative Ann Bollin","02/04/2021 - Read A First Time","02/04/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/09/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/04/2021","02/23/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","02/23/2021 - Referred To Committee On Judiciary, With Substitute (h-1)","03/09/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","03/09/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","05/25/2021 - Read A Second Time","05/25/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","05/25/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","05/26/2021 - Read a third time","05/26/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 240 Yeas 65 Nays 44 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","05/26/2021 - Transmitted","05/27/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","01/19/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 1/19/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","02/16/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 2/16/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","02/17/2022 - Reported Favorably Without Amendment","02/17/2022 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","02/17/2022 - Referred to Committee of the Whole"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes "forged signature on absentee ballot" from the list of criminal election offenses.
  • Adds to the list knowingly submitting an absent voter application with false information or a forged signature.

HISTORY: ["03/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Phil Green","03/03/2021 - Read A First Time","03/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/04/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/04/2021","06/15/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 6/15/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","06/22/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","06/22/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (11:30 6/22/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","06/22/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","06/22/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","06/23/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","07/21/2021 - Read A Second Time","07/21/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","07/21/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","07/21/2021 - Placed On Immediate Passage","07/21/2021 - Read a third time","07/21/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 423 Yeas 107 Nays 1 Excused 0 Not Voting 2","07/21/2021 - Transmitted","07/27/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","02/16/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 2/16/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)"]
["02/09/2022 - Introduced By Senator Ken Horn","02/09/2022 - Referred to Committee on Judiciary and Public Safety"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows a judge to submit a written form to prevent disclosure of their personal information, or their family's personal information, and outlines what must be on the form.
  • Prohibits those receiving the request from publishing it, making it public, or selling it, or if it was already made public, requires the information be removed within five business days. 
  • Creates an exception allowing the judge and his or her family to choose to make their information public.
  • Exempts from disclosure personal information covered in the written request form.
  • Allows a judge to provide a PO Box instead of a residential address in public documents.
  • Establishes that a judge may start a civil action to compel compliance with this act and outlines the procedure and punishments.
  • Calls this act the "Judicial Protection Act."
  • Defines relevant terms.

COAUTHORS: ["Andrew Beeler\u00a0*","Robert Bezotte\u00a0*","Kenneth Borton\u00a0*","Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Gary Eisen\u00a0*","Steven Johnson\u00a0*","Beau LaFave\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Gregory Markkanen\u00a0*","David Martin\u00a0*","Luke Meerman\u00a0*","Pat Outman\u00a0*","John Reilly\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["02/01/2022 - Introduced By Representative Luke Meerman","02/01/2022 - Read A First Time","02/01/2022 - Referred To Committee On Local Government And Municipal Finance","02/02/2022 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/01/2022"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows county board of commissioners to remove the appointed local health officer for any reason by a majority vote.

  • Defines local health officer.

COAUTHORS: ["Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Rick Outman","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)","01/19/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 1/19/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","01/20/2022 - Senate Substitute (S-2)","01/20/2022 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-2)","01/20/2022 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","01/20/2022 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-2)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to create a comprehensive training curriculum for political parties seeking to designate election challengers.
  • Removes incorporated organizations and organized committees of citizens as groups who may designate a challenger.
  • Requires those seeking to be appointed election challengers to have completed the challenger training within three days to three years before the election.
  • Outlines verification procedures and timelines for those attending the training.

COAUTHORS: ["Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Rick Outman","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)","01/19/2022 - Senate Elections (14:00 1/19/2022 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Eliminates filing certain false statements from the list of election code felonies.

HISTORY: ["02/23/2021 - Introduced By Representative Terry Sabo","02/23/2021 - Read A First Time","02/23/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/24/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/23/2021","03/10/2021 - Reported With Recommendation Without Amendment","03/10/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","04/13/2021 - Read A Second Time","04/13/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","04/14/2021 - Read a third time","04/14/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 106 Yeas 90 Nays 20 Excused 0 Not Voting 0","04/14/2021 - Transmitted","04/15/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","09/29/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 9/29/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","10/13/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 10/13/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","10/14/2021 - Reported Favorably Without Amendment","10/14/2021 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","10/14/2021 - Referred to Committee of the Whole","12/09/2021 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably Without Amendment(s)","12/09/2021 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading","12/14/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 486 Yeas 35 Nays 1 Excused 2 Not Voting 0","12/14/2021 - Returned From Senate Without Amendment With Immediate Effect","12/14/2021 - Bill Ordered Enrolled","12/15/2021 - Presented To The Governor 12/17/2021 11:04 Am","12/15/2021 - Approved By The Governor 12/23/2021 10:12 Am","12/15/2021 - Filed With Secretary Of State 12/27/2021 12:24 Pm","12/15/2021 - Assigned Pa 145'21 With Immediate Effect"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires a candidate for county commissioner to be a resident and registered voter of the district and remain so.

  • Clarifies that county commission elections are partisan and clarifies nomination and qualification procedures.

  • Requires a nonrefundable filing fee be paid and the funds be deposited in the county general fund for specific purposes.

COAUTHORS: ["Felicia Brabec\u00a0*","Darrin Camilleri\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Jewell Jones\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","H. Helena Scott\u00a0*","Shri Thanedar\u00a0*","Regina Weiss\u00a0*","Stephanie Young\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["12/14/2021 - Introduced By Representative Abraham Aiyash","12/14/2021 - Read A First Time","12/14/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","12/15/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 12/14/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that candidates considered to have received votes are those candidates where the oval or box next to their names is completely darkened.
  • Removes the requirement that the oval or box be to the left of the name.
  • Requires ranked choice voting ballots allow a voter to rank candidates for each office, with certain stipulations and procedures.
  • Outlines the counting process for ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines what to do in case of a tie, what to do if a voter skips a rank, or uses the same rank twice. 
  • Requires a municipality to conduct a voter education campaign for ranked choice voting.
  • Establishes that a city is responsible for costs associated with the certification and testing of the voting system used for ranked choice voting and outlines tallying requirements for equipment.
  • Makes conforming changes.

COAUTHORS: ["Felicia Brabec\u00a0*","Darrin Camilleri\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Jewell Jones\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","H. Helena Scott\u00a0*","Shri Thanedar\u00a0*","Regina Weiss\u00a0*","Stephanie Young\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["12/14/2021 - Introduced By Representative Shri Thanedar","12/14/2021 - Read A First Time","12/14/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","12/15/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 12/14/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Creates exceptions for instructions related to the ballot secrecy sleeve for ranked choice voting.
  • Requires the city clerk to issue ballot marking instructions for elections involving ranked choice voting, and requires that these instructions be used in local elections with specific related requirements.
  • Requires ballot marking instructions to be included for absent voters, including instructions for ranked choice voting, where relevant.
  • Makes exceptions for ranked choice voting tabulation in electronic tabulation requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.

COAUTHORS: ["Winnie Brinks\u00a0*","Adam Hollier\u00a0*","Sean McCann\u00a0*","Jeremy Moss\u00a0*","Dayna Polehanki\u00a0*","Sylvia Santana\u00a0*","Paul Wojno\u00a0*","Douglas Wozniak\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["12/14/2021 - Introduced By Senator Paul Wojno","12/14/2021 - Referred to Committee on Judiciary and Public Safety"]

COAUTHORS: ["Winnie Brinks\u00a0*","Adam Hollier\u00a0*","Sean McCann\u00a0*","Jeremy Moss\u00a0*","Dayna Polehanki\u00a0*","Sylvia Santana\u00a0*","Paul Wojno\u00a0*","Douglas Wozniak\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["12/14/2021 - Introduced By Senator Paul Wojno","12/14/2021 - Referred to Committee on Judiciary and Public Safety"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that threatening to physically harm an election official is a misdemeanor with possible prison time and fines.
  • Establishes that assaulting an election official and causing injury is a felony with possible prison time and fines.
  • Establishes that assaulting an election official and causes serious injury is a felony with possible prison time and fines.
  • Defines relevant terms.

COAUTHORS: ["Kyra Bolden\u00a0*","Felicia Brabec\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Kevin Coleman\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Matt Koleszar\u00a0*","Donna Lasinski\u00a0*","Mari Manoogian\u00a0*","Laurie Pohutsky\u00a0*","Regina Weiss\u00a0*","Karen Whitsett\u00a0*","Stephanie Young\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["11/30/2021 - Introduced By Representative Mari Manoogian","11/30/2021 - Read A First Time","11/30/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","12/01/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/30/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows those ages 16-17 years of age to preregister to vote.
  • Outlines requirements for preregistering.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create a preregistration application and lists what must be included.
  • Establishes that an individual who preregisters becomes registered at 17 1/2 years old, and may vote after turning 18.
  • Outlines preregistration procedures for the Secretary of State, or other voter registration agency.
  • Prohibits preregistered voters from being included in the precinct voter list for an election.
  • Outlines change of address procedures, notification procedures for when the person becomes 17 1/2 years old, and procedures for when the person turns 18.

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Breen\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Alex Garza\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Matt Koleszar\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Donna Lasinski\u00a0*","Mari Manoogian\u00a0*","Christine Morse\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","H. Helena Scott\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*","Joseph Tate\u00a0*","Tenisha Yancey\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["11/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Padma Kuppa","11/03/2021 - Read A First Time","11/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","11/04/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that a qualified overseas or military voter may return a ballot electronically.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create rules, with certain stipulations, regarding electronic return of an absentee ballot for overseas and military voters, including a secure web portal.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Lists all qualified uniformed services.

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Breen\u00a0*","Tyrone Carter\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Alex Garza\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Matt Koleszar\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Donna Lasinski\u00a0*","Mari Manoogian\u00a0*","Christine Morse\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","H. Helena Scott\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*","Joseph Tate\u00a0*","Tenisha Yancey\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["11/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Tyrone Carter","11/03/2021 - Read A First Time","11/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","11/04/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires each clerk to send each voter an absent ballot application, and supporting documents, with certain guidelines. 
  • Requires the clerk to provide a postage paid envelope for absent voting and absent voting applications.
  • Establishes reimbursement procedures for the postage paid envelopes, including qualification guidelines and notification requirements.

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Breen\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Alex Garza\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Matt Koleszar\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Donna Lasinski\u00a0*","Mari Manoogian\u00a0*","Christine Morse\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","H. Helena Scott\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*","Joseph Tate\u00a0*","Tenisha Yancey\u00a0*","Stephanie Young\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["11/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Kara Hope","11/03/2021 - Read A First Time","11/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","11/04/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires each absent voter drop box to be checked an emptied daily.
  • Requires each municipality to provide at least one secure absent voter ballot drop box for every 20,000 registered voters in an accessible outdoor location.
  • Establishes that the state will reimburse each municipality for the cost of providing absent voter ballot drop boxes.
  • Outlines the reimbursement approval process, source of funding, submission requirements, and what to do in case the request is not approved.

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Breen\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Matt Koleszar\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Donna Lasinski\u00a0*","Christine Morse\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","Yousef Rabhi\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","H. Helena Scott\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*","Joseph Tate\u00a0*","Tenisha Yancey\u00a0*","Stephanie Young\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["11/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Matt Koleszar","11/03/2021 - Read A First Time","11/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","11/04/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the clerk to deliver absent voter ballot return envelopes to approved absent voter counting boards each day the board meets before election day.
  • Allows the counting boards to be meet up to seven days before the election, 8am-5pm, and requires the municipality to provide notification at least five days before they meet, including certain information.
  • Makes complying changes.
  • Allows absent voter counting boards to meet starting at 7am on election day.
  • Prohibits absent voter counting boards from tabulating vote counts before election day, and specifies what the board may do, and how to secure ballots, before election day.
  • Prohibits an absentee voter from spoiling his or her absentee ballot after the date the absent voter counting board begins meeting and processing ballots.

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Breen\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Alex Garza\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Matt Koleszar\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Donna Lasinski\u00a0*","Tullio Liberati\u00a0*","Mari Manoogian\u00a0*","Christine Morse\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","H. Helena Scott\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*","Joseph Tate\u00a0*","Tenisha Yancey\u00a0*","Stephanie Young\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["11/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Tullio Liberati","11/03/2021 - Read A First Time","11/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","11/04/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the state to reimburse each jurisdiction for the cost of election mail postage.

  • Outlines eligibility requirements for the reimbursement.

  • Appropriates general funds for the reimbursement.

  • Outlines a timeline and procedures for accepting, denying, and/or paying the reimbursement.

  • Defines "election mail."

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Breen\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Alex Garza\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Matt Koleszar\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Donna Lasinski\u00a0*","Mari Manoogian\u00a0*","Christine Morse\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","H. Helena Scott\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*","Joseph Tate\u00a0*","Karen Whitsett\u00a0*","Tenisha Yancey\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["11/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Karen Whitsett","11/03/2021 - Read A First Time","11/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","11/04/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Eliminates the provision that prohibits anyone from hiring transportation for conveying voters to an election.

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Breen\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Matt Koleszar\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Donna Lasinski\u00a0*","Christine Morse\u00a0*","Amos O'Neal\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","H. Helena Scott\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*","Joseph Tate\u00a0*","Tenisha Yancey\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["11/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Amos O'neal","11/03/2021 - Read A First Time","11/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","11/04/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 11/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires jurisdictions to count absent voter ballots postmarked by election day and received within 72 hours of the close of polls.

  • Requires the clerk to transmit the results of absent voter ballots counted after the election by the fourth day after the election.
  • Outlines handling and recording requirements for the clerk for absent voter ballots received more than 72 hours after the close of polls.
  • Redefines "uniformed services."
  • Makes clarifying changes.
  • Makes conforming changes.

COAUTHORS: ["Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Dan Lauwers\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Tom Barrett","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/26/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/26/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)","06/02/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 6/2/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","06/03/2021 - Reported Favorably Without Amendment","06/03/2021 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","06/03/2021 - Referred to Committee of the Whole","06/16/2021 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably Without Amendment(s)","06/16/2021 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading","06/16/2021 - Rules suspended","06/16/2021 - Placed On Immediate Passage","06/16/2021 - Passed Roll Call # 275 Yeas 19 Nays 16 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","06/16/2021 - Received On 06/16/2021","06/16/2021 - Read A First Time","06/16/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/23/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","06/23/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","06/23/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","06/23/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","06/23/2021 - Read A Second Time","06/23/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","06/23/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","06/23/2021 - Placed On Immediate Passage","06/23/2021 - Read a third time","06/23/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 368 Yeas 58 Nays 52 Excused 0 Not Voting 0","06/23/2021 - Title Amended","06/23/2021 - Returned To Senate","06/24/2021 - Laid Over One Day Under The Rules","10/06/2021 - Substitute (s-3) Adopted","10/06/2021 - House Substitute (h-1) Concurred In As Substituted (s-3)","10/06/2021 - Roll Call: Roll Call # 369 Yeas 20 Nays 15 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","10/06/2021 - Re-returned From Senate With Substitute (s-3) To House Substitute (h-1) With Title Amendment","10/06/2021 - Laid Over One Day Under The Rules","10/14/2021 - Senate Substitute (s-3) To House Substitute (h-1) Concurred In","10/14/2021 - Roll Call Roll Call # 469 Yeas 56 Nays 51 Excused 0 Not Voting 2","10/14/2021 - Title Amendment Agreed To","10/14/2021 - Returned To Senate","10/19/2021 - Immediate Effect Defeated","10/19/2021 - Title Amendment Agreed To","10/19/2021 - Ordered enrolled","10/21/2021 - Presented To Governor 10/20/2021 12:02 Pm","11/02/2021 - Senate Vetoed By Governor 10/29/2021","11/02/2021 - Vetoed By Governor 10/29/2021","11/02/2021 - Postponed For The Day"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Lists required information and items for a voter registration application.
  • Requires the election official to first ask a potential voter for their full name and address and for the individual to sign an affirmation, with certain required elements, before being provided a ballot.
  • Requires an election official to compare signatures for each potential voter, if the technology is available, or ensure the voter's name appears on the voter registration list, and provides instructions on what to do in specific circumstances.
  • Requires the election official to ask for identification of a potential voter, and requires that if the individual does not have identification, the be issued a provisional ballot.
  • Outlines administrative procedures required for when an individual is given a ballot, and what should be done with these records after the polls close. 
  • Furnishes guidelines for applying for an absentee ballot, including timetables, mailings, and deadlines.
  • Provides that an individual may submit a voter registration application and absent voter application at the same time and outlines when and where that voter may complete the absent ballot.
  • Lists ways an application for an absentee ballot may be made.
  • Lists required information and items for an absent voter application.
  • Outlines required procedures for administering an absent voter application.
  • Lists who may be in possession of an absent voter application.
  • Requires jurisdictions to have absent voter applications available and specifies the contents of the applications.
  • Provides required instructions for the absent voter ballot.
  • Specifies what is allowed in different scenarios related to returning the absentee ballot and penalties for those who do not follow the code.
  • Specifies that the absent voter application is confidential and not subject to Freedom of Information Act requests.
  • Specifies procedures for absent uniformed service voters and absent overseas voters to register and to cast an absent voter ballot, including timelines, deadlines, voting in primaries, approval process, email confidentiality, and eligibility. 
  • Clarifies reporting requirements and timelines for absent uniformed services and overseas voter ballots and applications.
  • Outlines deadlines and procedures for applying for an absent voter ballot in the case of illness or other emergencies, and outlines penalties for false statements.
  • Requires each jurisdiction to have access to the department of state data system to verify absent voter application information.
  • Outlines procedures for signature verification on the absent voter application.
  • Specifies how absent voter applications and ballots must be issued.
  • Specifies written instructions and other items for the envelope of the absentee ballot application.
  • Provides deadlines and administrative procedures for return of absentee voter ballots.
  • Specifies conditions for collecting an absent voter ballot and public notification requirements.
  • Outlines procedures, reporting requirements, counting requirements, and timelines for provisional ballots received before the election.
  • Specifies voter registration reporting requirements.
  • Specifies funding sources for election related activities.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["10/21/2021 - Introduced By Representative Luke Meerman","10/21/2021 - Read A First Time","10/21/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","10/26/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 10/21/2021","11/02/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 11/2/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","01/18/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/18/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)","01/25/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 1/25/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Prohibits a clerk from posting on the internet unofficial election results until counting of all ballot returns in the jurisdiction is complete.

HISTORY: ["10/21/2021 - Introduced By Senator Betty Jean Alexander","10/21/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits anyone except authorized individuals from tampering with or moving an absent voter ballot drop box.
  • Prohibits anyone from blocking or impeding a voter attempting to return their ballot to the absent voter drop box.
  • Specifies felony penalties.

COAUTHORS: ["Sarah Anthony\u00a0*","Kyra Bolden\u00a0*","Brenda Carter\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Cynthia Neeley\u00a0*","Karen Whitsett\u00a0*","Tenisha Yancey\u00a0*","Stephanie Young\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["09/23/2021 - Introduced By Representative Sarah Anthony","09/23/2021 - Read A First Time","09/23/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","09/28/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 09/23/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides that anyone in jail or prison who is qualified may register to vote.
  • Eliminates a statement that anyone who is imprisoned after being convicted and sentenced is not eligible to vote.

COAUTHORS: ["Andrew Beeler\u00a0*","Joseph Bellino\u00a0*","Timothy Beson\u00a0*","Kenneth Borton\u00a0*","Stephen Carra\u00a0*","John Damoose\u00a0*","Andrew Fink\u00a0*","Michele Hoitenga\u00a0*","Mark Huizenga\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Gregory Markkanen\u00a0*","Pat Outman\u00a0*","Bryan Posthumus\u00a0*","John Reilly\u00a0*","John Roth\u00a0*","Mark Tisdel\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["05/13/2021 - Introduced By Representative Ken Borton","05/13/2021 - Read A First Time","05/13/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","05/18/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 5/18/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","05/18/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/13/2021","05/25/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 5/25/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","06/22/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","06/22/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (11:30 6/22/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","06/22/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","06/22/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","06/23/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","08/17/2021 - Read A Second Time","08/17/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","08/17/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","08/17/2021 - Placed On Immediate Passage","08/17/2021 - Read a third time","08/17/2021 - Amended","08/17/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 436 Yeas 80 Nays 28 Excused 0 Not Voting 2","08/17/2021 - Transmitted","08/25/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Changes the timeframe for being able to destroy all election returns and ballots from two years to 22 months.
  • Provides that flash drives and electronic poll book flash drives used in an election must be destroyed 30 days after the election except in specific circumstances.

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Breen\u00a0*","Julie Brixie\u00a0*","Darrin Camilleri\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Tullio Liberati\u00a0*","Christine Morse\u00a0*","Ranjeev Puri\u00a0*","Julie Rogers\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Karen Whitsett\u00a0*","Tenisha Yancey\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["08/18/2021 - Introduced By Representative Kara Hope","08/18/2021 - Read A First Time","08/18/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","08/19/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 08/18/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits anyone from intimidating an election official, or prevent the official from performing his or her duties, punishable as a misdemeanor with possible imprisonment or a fine.

  • Defines relevant terms.

COAUTHORS: ["Rosemary Bayer\u00a0*","Winnie Brinks\u00a0*","Stephanie Chang\u00a0*","Erika Geiss\u00a0*","Curtis Hertel\u00a0*","Mallory McMorrow\u00a0*","Jeremy Moss\u00a0*","Dayna Polehanki\u00a0*","Paul Wojno\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["07/27/2021 - Introduced By Senator Curtis Hertel, Jr.","07/27/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Forbids someone employed to collect signatures for constitutional amendments ballot petitions or recall petitions from making intentionally false statements designed to impact the decisions of specific individuals and groups who may signs the petition.
  • If the person breaks this law, all signatures will be deemed invalid and not counted.

COAUTHORS: ["Rosemary Bayer\u00a0*","Winnie Brinks\u00a0*","Stephanie Chang\u00a0*","Erika Geiss\u00a0*","Curtis Hertel\u00a0*","Mallory McMorrow\u00a0*","Jeremy Moss\u00a0*","Dayna Polehanki\u00a0*","Paul Wojno\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["07/27/2021 - Introduced By Senator Mallory Mcmorrow","07/27/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows a voter who signed a ballot question petition to submit a written request to the Secretary of State asking that their name be removed from the petition, before the petition is filed.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to immediately remove the person's name and signature when receiving a proper request and forbids that person's name to be counted in the number of petition signatures.

COAUTHORS: ["Rosemary Bayer\u00a0*","Winnie Brinks\u00a0*","Stephanie Chang\u00a0*","Erika Geiss\u00a0*","Curtis Hertel\u00a0*","Jeff Irwin\u00a0*","Mallory McMorrow\u00a0*","Jeremy Moss\u00a0*","Dayna Polehanki\u00a0*","Paul Wojno\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["07/27/2021 - Introduced By Senator Jeff Irwin","07/27/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes knowingly signing a petition more than once as a violation of Michigan election law.
  • Provides that only the first signature of a voter who signs a petition more than once will be counted.

COAUTHORS: ["Rosemary Bayer\u00a0*","Winnie Brinks\u00a0*","Stephanie Chang\u00a0*","Erika Geiss\u00a0*","Curtis Hertel\u00a0*","Mallory McMorrow\u00a0*","Jeremy Moss\u00a0*","Dayna Polehanki\u00a0*","Paul Wojno\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["07/27/2021 - Introduced By Senator Jeremy Moss","07/27/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Prohibits an organization from employing anyone to obtain signatures for ballot question petitions, or recall petitions, who has been convicted of an election crime.

COAUTHORS: ["Rosemary Bayer\u00a0*","Winnie Brinks\u00a0*","Stephanie Chang\u00a0*","Erika Geiss\u00a0*","Curtis Hertel\u00a0*","Adam Hollier\u00a0*","Mallory McMorrow\u00a0*","Jeremy Moss\u00a0*","Dayna Polehanki\u00a0*","Paul Wojno\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["07/27/2021 - Introduced By Senator Adam J. Hollier","07/27/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Prohibits an individual employed to circulate a petition from being paid per signature or for completed signature sheets, requiring instead the person be paid an hourly rate.

HISTORY: ["07/01/2021 - Introduced By Representative Richard Steenland","07/01/2021 - Read A First Time","07/01/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","07/14/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 07/01/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Provides that a clerk is not required to keep a master voter registration file, however if the clerk does keep one, requires the file to be maintained and updated.

HISTORY: ["07/01/2021 - Introduced By Representative Michele Hoitenga","07/01/2021 - Read A First Time","07/01/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","07/14/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 07/01/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits any governmental entity from accepting donations for elections or election related purposes.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: ["06/29/2021 - Introduced By Representative Bronna Kahle","06/29/2021 - Read A First Time","06/29/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/30/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/29/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits an election official from accepting or using donated funds for conducting an election, and requires the official to only accept public funding.

  • Defines "conducting an election" and "election official."

COAUTHORS: ["Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Ruth Johnson\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Wayne Schmidt\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Ruth A. Johnson","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/05/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/5/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)","06/16/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 6/16/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","06/17/2021 - Senate Substitute (S-1)","06/17/2021 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","06/17/2021 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","06/17/2021 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-1)","06/23/2021 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","06/23/2021 - Substitute (s-1) Concurred In","06/23/2021 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading With Substitute (s-1)","06/24/2021 - Substitute (s-2) Defeated","06/24/2021 - Passed Roll Call # 302 Yeas 34 Nays 1 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","06/24/2021 - Received On 06/24/2021","06/24/2021 - Read A First Time","06/24/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","09/28/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 9/28/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)"]

["05/13/2021 - Introduced By Representative Brad Paquette","05/13/2021 - Read A First Time","05/13/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","05/18/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 5/18/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","05/18/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/13/2021","05/25/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 5/25/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","06/08/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","06/08/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 6/8/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","06/08/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","06/08/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","06/22/2021 - Read A Second Time","06/22/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","06/22/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","06/23/2021 - Read a third time","06/23/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 361 Yeas 106 Nays 4 Excused 0 Not Voting 0","06/23/2021 - Transmitted","06/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Applies current absent voter ballot mailing procedures to primaries and special primaries.

  • Allows the clerk to provide an annual absent voter application allowing voters to select any elections held that year.

  • Specifies timelines and procedures for this application.

  • Makes conforming changes.

  • Makes clarifying edits.

HISTORY: ["05/18/2021 - Introduced By Representative Diana Farrington","05/18/2021 - Read A First Time","05/18/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","05/19/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/18/2021","05/25/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 5/25/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","06/08/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 6/8/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","06/08/2021 - Reported With Recommendation Without Amendment","06/08/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","06/22/2021 - Read A Second Time","06/22/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","06/23/2021 - Read a third time","06/23/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 362 Yeas 107 Nays 3 Excused 0 Not Voting 0","06/23/2021 - Transmitted","06/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to conduct signature verification training for clerks before each even numbered primary election year and other elections as determined by the Secretary of State.

  • Specifies what must be included in the training.

  • Requires the Secretary of State to implement these requirements.

HISTORY: ["01/13/2021 - Introduced By Senator Paul Wojno","01/13/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/05/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/5/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)","06/16/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 6/16/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","06/17/2021 - Senate Substitute (S-1)","06/17/2021 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","06/17/2021 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","06/17/2021 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-1)","06/23/2021 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","06/23/2021 - Substitute (s-1) Concurred In","06/23/2021 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading With Substitute (s-1)","06/24/2021 - Passed Roll Call # 298 Yeas 34 Nays 1 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","06/24/2021 - Received On 06/24/2021","06/24/2021 - Read A First Time","06/24/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","09/28/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 9/28/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Defines "United States Department of Defense verified electronic signature."

HISTORY: ["02/11/2021 - Introduced By Senator Aric Nesbitt","02/11/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/28/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/28/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)","06/23/2021 - Senate Elections (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","06/23/2021 - House Elections (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Changes the date of primary elections to the first Tuesday after the first Monday in June rather than August.

  • Changes the date for a nomination by caucus from May to the first Tuesday after the first Monday in March.

  • Removes a provision about nomination of candidates that was designated to be in place only in 2012.
