  • Requires a chairperson of a county committee of a congressional district to submit a certificate with the number of delegates to the county convention by February 1, rather than April 1, and requires the state chairperson to notify the local chairperson of this requirement by January 1.
  • Removes provisions allowing a city council to change its May regular election.
  • Provides that after December 31, 2020 a city council adopting a resolution for a May regular election will instead hold the election on the March regular election date.
  • Provides that after December 31, 2020 a city council adopting a resolution for an August regular primary election will instead hold the election on the June regular election date.
  • Removes the requirement that the board of county canvassers meet to canvass and certify a ballot question in the May election.  
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

HISTORY: ["06/22/2021 - Introduced By Representative Steve Carra","06/22/2021 - Read A First Time","06/22/2021 - Referred To Committee On Government Operations","06/23/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/22/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Creates a state election audit board and specifies who should be in the seven-person membership.
  • Requires appointments to the board to be made within 28 days of the effective date of the act.
  • Requires the board to contract an independent third party entity to conduct an audit of the November 2020 elections within 40 days of the effective date of this act.
  • Requires the audit board to contract with an independent third party entity to conduct an audit of the voter file, with specific listed tasks, within 45 days of the effective date of this act.
  • Requires the third party entity to conduct an audit of certain items in at least 10% of election precincts in each county (20% for counties larger than 500,000) from the November 2020 elections, with specific instructions on what is to be audited.
  • Outlines requirements for how the third party entity should conduct the audit, and what specific items they need to look into.
  • Excludes individuals cooperating with the audit from criminal penalties.   
  • Outlines reporting requirements for the third party entity regarding the audit, as well as where the report is to be submitted.
  • Dissolves the state election audit board 30 days after it issues its final report.
  • Appropriates funds for the audit activities.
  • Defines relevant terms.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Dan Lauwers\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Lana Theis","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/26/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/26/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)","06/02/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 6/2/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","06/03/2021 - Senate Substitute (S-1)","06/03/2021 - Reported Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","06/03/2021 - Committee Recommended Immediate Effect","06/03/2021 - Referred To Committee Of The Whole With Substitute (s-1)","06/16/2021 - Reported By Committee Of The Whole Favorably With Substitute (s-1)","06/16/2021 - Substitute (s-1) Concurred In","06/16/2021 - Placed On Order Of Third Reading With Substitute (s-1)","06/16/2021 - Rules suspended","06/16/2021 - Placed On Immediate Passage","06/16/2021 - Passed Roll Call # 274 Yeas 19 Nays 16 Excused 1 Not Voting 0","06/16/2021 - Received On 06/16/2021","06/16/2021 - Read A First Time","06/16/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines ID requirements for absent voter ballot applications.
  • Lists qualified uniformed services.
  • Lists ID requirements for an emergency absent voter ballot application.
  • Requires each jurisdiction to have access to the current Department of State data system with updated voter information.
  • Removes conflicting legislation.

COAUTHORS: ["Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Gary Eisen\u00a0*","Beth Griffin\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Gregory Markkanen\u00a0*","Brad Paquette\u00a0*","John Reilly\u00a0*","Daire Rendon\u00a0*","Douglas Wozniak\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["06/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Steve Carra","06/03/2021 - Read A First Time","06/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/08/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes requirements for the curriculum and training of election officials, including multiple penalties and violations, and signature validation requirements.

  • Requires all appointed election inspectors to wear a badge while acting as election inspector, with certain requirements regarding the content of the badge and its distribution.
  • Establishes that failing to comply is punishable as a misdemeanor offense with possible imprisonment and/or a fine.
  • Allows a challenger to be located behind the processing table.
  • Allows a challenger to observe the election process at a "reasonable distance" and defines the term.
  • Allows a challenger to challenge the manner the duties of an election inspector are being performed.
  • Establishes that a challenger may observe but not interfere with voters.
  • Defines "good reason to believe."
  • Establishes that a challenger may obtain the voting results generated after polls close.
  • Establishes that a challenger may use an electronic device as long as it does not impede with a voter's right to vote a secret ballot.
  • Clarifies that an expelled challenger may demand and be provided a written explanation for the expulsion, and the entity that appointed the challenger may appoint a replacement.
  • Outlines reporting requirements if someone infringes on the rights of a challenger.
  • Makes clarifying changes.

COAUTHORS: ["Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Beth Griffin\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Gregory Markkanen\u00a0*","Pat Outman\u00a0*","John Reilly\u00a0*","Daire Rendon\u00a0*","Douglas Wozniak\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["06/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative John Reilly","06/03/2021 - Read A First Time","06/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/08/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Gives those qualified individuals on a list submitted by a major political party first priority to be an election inspector.

  • Gives those qualified individuals who individually filed an application to be an election inspector second priority.
  • Provides that the board of election commissioners will appoint election inspectors from the pool of eligible individuals by random selection.
  • Prohibits the board of election commissioners from appointing more than two election inspectors from the same major political party for every one inspector from the other major political party in a precinct.
  • Requires a board of election commissioners who are unable to appoint an equal number of election inspectors from each major political party to submit a report containing certain information to the Secretary of State within ten days after the election.
  • Requires each clerk to post a notice 40-90 days before an election about the application process to be a precinct election inspector, and includes detailed information about the notice, the application process, and its administration.
  • Makes clarifying changes.

COAUTHORS: ["Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Beth Griffin\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Gregory Markkanen\u00a0*","Brad Paquette\u00a0*","John Reilly\u00a0*","Daire Rendon\u00a0*","Douglas Wozniak\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["06/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Brad Paquette","06/03/2021 - Read A First Time","06/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/08/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/03/2021","10/26/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 10/26/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","02/08/2022 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 2/8/2022 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires each ballot used in an election to include specific security features to prevent duplication.

COAUTHORS: ["Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Gary Eisen\u00a0*","Beth Griffin\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Gregory Markkanen\u00a0*","Pat Outman\u00a0*","John Reilly\u00a0*","Daire Rendon\u00a0*","Douglas Wozniak\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["06/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Gary Eisen","06/03/2021 - Read A First Time","06/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/08/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides clarifying edits.
  • Changes the timeframe for the board of county canvassers to deliver a certificate of returns from 14 days to 21 days after the election to the county clerk.
  • Changes the timeframe for each county clerk to deliver to the Secretary of State a certified statement of how many votes each candidate received from 14 days to 21 days after the election.
  • Changes the timeframe for the Secretary of State to call a meeting of the board of state canvassers from 20 days after the election to 22 days.
  • Changes when primary election ballots may be destroyed from 30 days after the election to 180 days after the election.
  • Changes the timeframe for the board of county canvassers to complete a canvass and certify election results from 14 days to 21 days after an election.
  • Provides procedures for if a member of the county board of county canvassers signs an affidavit saying that their vote on certification was made under duress.
  • Changes the deadline for the board of state canvassers to meet with the Secretary of State for determining the results of an election from 20 days to 22 days after the election.
  • Changes the deadline by which the Secretary of State may ask for certification of returns for electors for President and Vice President, during an expedited canvass, from 14 days after the election to 21 days after the election.
  • Changes the deadline for the Secretary of State to require the receipt of returns after an expedited canvass from 20 days to 22 days after an election.

COAUTHORS: ["Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Gary Eisen\u00a0*","Beth Griffin\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Brad Paquette\u00a0*","John Reilly\u00a0*","Daire Rendon\u00a0*","Douglas Wozniak\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["06/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Beth Griffin","06/03/2021 - Read A First Time","06/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/08/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides for a county chairperson of a major political party to petition for a recount on behalf of one candidate in one precinct in the county and specifies requirements for submitting the request.

  • Establishes that a refund of a deposit will be issued to a petitioner if it is an informational recount and not done to change the result of the election.

  • Removes references to a precinct that is "not recountable."

  • Removes reasons a precinct may not have a recount.

  • Provides procedures for specific situations where a recount indicates discrepancies that could lead to changing election results.

  • Provides that in an informational recount the board of canvassers will accept all previous returns and describes procedures for recording results of an informational recount.

  • Eliminates procedures for if the number of ballots issued and the numbers shown on the poll list do not match.

  • Makes clarifying edits.

COAUTHORS: ["Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Gary Eisen\u00a0*","Beth Griffin\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Gregory Markkanen\u00a0*","Brad Paquette\u00a0*","John Reilly\u00a0*","Daire Rendon\u00a0*","Douglas Wozniak\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["06/03/2021 - Introduced By Representative Daire Rendon","06/03/2021 - Read A First Time","06/03/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/08/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/03/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Specifies that an electronic voting system must be incapable of being connected to the internet.

  • Makes clarifying edits.

COAUTHORS: ["Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Matt Hall\u00a0*","Beau LaFave\u00a0*","Matt Maddock\u00a0*","Luke Meerman\u00a0*","Brad Paquette\u00a0*","Daire Rendon\u00a0*","Douglas Wozniak\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["06/01/2021 - Introduced By Representative Matt Maddock","06/01/2021 - Read A First Time","06/01/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","06/02/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 06/01/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Authorizes certain individuals to use cameras or video cameras at an absent voter counting board proceeding.
  • Requires a clerk to post public notice at least 14 days before an election about where and when the absent voter counting board will meet to verify signatures.
  • Requires the signature verification process be open at all times to election challengers and poll watchers.
  • Authorizes the use of camera or video camera at the absent voter counting board only when votes are being tabulated, and specifies what may not be recorded, as well as penalties.
  • Provides that officials may provide live video coverage of the custody of all ballots in the tabulation room of certain elections, specifying requirements, timelines, procedures,  publication, what to do in case of video disruption, and storage of the footage.

  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["05/26/2021 - Introduced By Representative Steven Johnson","05/26/2021 - Read A First Time","05/26/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","05/27/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/26/2021","11/02/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 11/2/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Allows a current concealed pistol license to be an identification for election purposes.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Wayne A. Schmidt","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/05/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/5/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Adds the following enumerated election code felonies: tampering with a ballot container in early voting, and disclosing an election result or characterizing how a ballot was voted before the polls close on election day.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Wayne A. Schmidt","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/05/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/5/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes poll opening and closing times and days for early voting.
  • Establishes notification requirements for early voting.
  • Requires each city and township to provide early voting in at least one polling place and requires the Secretary of State to work with the locale to provide technical assistance.
  • Provides that certain election day provisions also apply to early voting and provides a list of the provisions.
  • Requires early voting ballots to be processed the same way as ballots cast on election day.
  • Codifies that it is a felony to tamper with a ballot container containing ballots voted on the second Saturday before election day.
  • Codifies that it is a felony to disclose election results before the close of polls on election day.
  • Requires the poll book be divided by date and that seperate records be maintained for early voting on the second Satruday before election day.

HISTORY: ["05/11/2021 - Introduced By Representative Pauline Wendzel","05/11/2021 - Read A First Time","05/11/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","05/12/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 05/11/2021","10/05/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 10/5/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","10/19/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 10/19/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)"]

["03/17/2021 - Introduced By Representative Ranjeev Puri","03/17/2021 - Read A First Time","03/17/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/18/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/17/2021","04/13/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","04/13/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","04/13/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","04/22/2021 - Read A Second Time","04/22/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","04/22/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","04/27/2021 - Read a third time","04/27/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 151 Yeas 65 Nays 44 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","04/27/2021 - Transmitted","04/28/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","06/23/2021 - Senate Elections (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","06/23/2021 - House Elections (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Makes conforming changes for moving the primary from August to June, including filing deadline, resolutions related to circuit court judges, new judicial circuits, permitting additional judges of probate, additional district judgeships, and new districts for judgeships.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

HISTORY: ["03/17/2021 - Introduced By Representative Julie Calley","03/17/2021 - Read A First Time","03/17/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/18/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/17/2021","03/23/2021 - Elections and Ethics (12:00 3/23/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","04/13/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","04/13/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","04/13/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","04/22/2021 - Read A Second Time","04/22/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","04/22/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","04/27/2021 - Read a third time","04/27/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 148 Yeas 63 Nays 46 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","04/27/2021 - Transmitted","04/28/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","06/23/2021 - Senate Elections (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","06/23/2021 - House Elections (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines "odd year primary election" to be the election held on the June regular election date in odd years.
  • Clarifies that a general primary election must be held on the third Tuesday in June, before the general election in November, and lists offices to which this applies.
  • Removes deadlines for nominating petitions and requires they be received by 4pm on the 15th Tuesday before the June primary.
  • Makes conforming changes and clarifies other language in the legislation.
  • Provides that if a city provides for nomination by caucus or by filing a petition directly for the June election, the candidate filing deadline is 4pm on the 15th Tuesday before the June election.

COAUTHORS: ["Robert Bezotte\u00a0*","Tommy Brann\u00a0*","Stephen Carra\u00a0*","Andrew Fink\u00a0*","Phil Green\u00a0*","Steven Johnson\u00a0*","Pat Outman\u00a0*","Bradley Slagh\u00a0*","Jeff Yaroch\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - Introduced By Representative Bradley Slagh","02/10/2021 - Read A First Time","02/10/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/11/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/10/2021","04/13/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","04/13/2021 - Elections and Ethics (12:00 4/13/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)","04/13/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","04/13/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","04/22/2021 - Read A Second Time","04/22/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","04/22/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","04/27/2021 - Read a third time","04/27/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 144 Yeas 60 Nays 49 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","04/27/2021 - Transmitted","04/28/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Bureau of Elections to review initiative petition signatures and the Board of Canvassers to complete the canvas within 90 days of the petition filing.
  • Creates a different timeline for if a petition is filed 45 days or fewer before a November general election.

HISTORY: ["04/15/2021 - Introduced By Representative Rachel Hood","04/15/2021 - Read A First Time","04/15/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","04/20/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 04/15/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Specifies that the deadline for filing nominating petitions or fees for county commissioner is the same as for state representative.
  • Specifies deadlines for filing nominating petitions and fees for the November 2022 general election.

HISTORY: ["04/15/2021 - Introduced By Representative Steve Marino","04/15/2021 - Read A First Time","04/15/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","04/20/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 04/15/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Sets up the number of signatures required and deadlines for nominating petitions for the offices of Governor, US Representative, and state Senator in the November 2022 election cycle.
  • Allows the Secretary of State and clerks to accept nominating petitions and filing fees by a specified deadline for the November 2022 general election.
  • Furnishes a deadline for complaints about signatures on a petition for the November 2022 general election.
  • Allows the county clerk or the board of state canvassers, in 2022, to make public its staff report about the disposition of challenges filed against a petition at least three days before a decision is made.
  • Furnishes a deadline for complaints about signatures on a nominating petition in the November 2022 general elections.

HISTORY: ["03/25/2021 - Introduced By Senator Ruth A. Johnson","03/25/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/05/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/5/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes timelines for examination of absent voter ballot secrecy envelope containers for August primary elections.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Extends the requirement that the Secretary of State provide a written report to the House and Senate committees dealing with elections to include a March 1 deadline every two years.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Kimberly A. Lasata","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes timelines for examination of absent voter ballot secrecy envelope containers for August primary elections or November general elections.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Extends the requirement that the Secretary of State provide a written report to the House and Senate committees dealing with elections to include a March 1 deadline every two years.

COAUTHORS: ["Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Tom Barrett","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Provides that only the Secretary of State, a designated voter registration agency, or a municipal clerk will have access to the qualified voter file.

COAUTHORS: ["Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Ed McBroom\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Ed Mcbroom","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/19/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/19/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides clarifying edits.
  • Changes the timeframe for the board of county canvassers to deliver a certificate of returns from 14 days to 21 days after the election to the county clerk.
  • Changes the timeframe for each county clerk to deliver to the Secretary of State a certified statement of how many votes each candidate received from 14 days to 21 days after the election.
  • Changes the timeframe for the Secretary of State to call a meeting of the board of state canvassers from 20 days after the election to 22 days.
  • Changes the timeframe for the board of county canvassers to complete a canvass and certify election results from 14 days to 21 days after an election.
  • Changes the deadline for the board of state canvassers to meet with the Secretary of State for determining the results of an election from 20 days to 22 days after the election.
  • Changes the deadline by which the Secretary of State may ask for certification of returns for electors for President and Vice President, during an expedited canvass, from 14 days after the election to 21 days after the election.
  • Changes the deadline for the Secretary of State to require the receipt of returns after an expedited canvass from 20 days to 22 days after an election.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Rick Outman","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits the board of election commissioners from appointing more than two election inspectors from a major political party for every one inspector appointed from the other major political party for any precinct.
  • Requires that a city or township submit a report within ten days after an election if they are not able to appoint an equal number of election inspectors from each major political party in each precinct.

COAUTHORS: ["Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Ruth Johnson\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Ruth A. Johnson","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/26/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/26/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits the Secretary of State from providing an absent voter ballot application (or website link to the application) to an elector who did not request it.
  • Makes conforming changes.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Dan Lauwers\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Dan Lauwers","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/26/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/26/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Directs the Secretary of State to provide a report to the state legislature yearly about contracts entered into related to voting.
  • Prohibits any governmental entity from accepting donations for elections or election related purposes.
  • Defines relevant terms.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Runestad\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Jim Runestad","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/19/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/19/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows an election challenger or poll watcher to video tape with an electronic device when votes are being tabulated at a precinct.
  • Lists actions the election challenger or poll watcher may not videotape at the precinct.
  • Forbids anyone from threatening or impeding an election inspector, challenger, or poll watcher while he or she is conducting authorized videotaping.
  • Outlines penalties.

COAUTHORS: ["Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Ed McBroom\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Ed Mcbroom","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/05/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/5/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits voters from using an absent voter ballot drop box starting after 5pm the day before election day.
  • Requires that each drop box automatically lock at 5pm the day before election day.
  • Makes conforming changes.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Jon C. Bumstead","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/19/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/19/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires two qualified inspectors, one from each major political party, to be appointed in each jurisdiction at least five days before an election audit.

  • Requires each political party to designate two observers to monitor the proceedings on an election audit at each precinct where the audit will occur.

  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide live video streaming of the election audit in each precinct on the Secretary of State's website.

COAUTHORS: ["Ruth Johnson\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Wayne Schmidt\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Ruth A. Johnson","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines requirements and procedures for allowing individuals 16-17.5 years of age to preregister to vote.
  • Outlines what is required of the voter to preregister.
  • Outlines procedures for authorities processing the registration, including what to do when the person turns 17.5 years old.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Dale W. Zorn","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits a candidates name or likeness appearing on any communication paid for with public money related to elections.
  • Establishes misdemeanor sanctions for violations.
  • Defines relevant terms.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Kimberly A. Lasata","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the Secretary of State to request information from each multi-state program or service to verify current residence and voter registration of voters by March 1 each year and outlines timelines for updating procedures for a minimum of 95% of participants.
  • Outlines guidelines and a timeline for reporting this information to the relevant House and Senate committees.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to request information from each multi-state program or service to update data identifying voters who cast improper votes in the preceding November election and to commence related investigations.
  • Outlines related public reporting requirements and deadlines for the Secretary of State to post on the website.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Jim Stamas","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Prohibits cities or townships from providing prepaid postage on absent voter ballot return envelopes and prohibits the Secretary of State from providing funding for the prepaid postage.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Runestad\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Jim Runestad","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/19/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/19/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows members of each political party to attend and observe an election audit and to record the proceedings with video recording devices.
  • Outlines additional rules prohibiting interference or disruption of the audit.
  • Provides that beginning at 8:00pm on election day, the tabulation of absent voter ballots is subject to the same rules as other tabulation of ballots.
  • Provides that a clerk may provide live, recorded video coverage of the custody of ballots in the tabulation room for certain elections.
  • Requires the recording be available for 40 days on the website and outlines further requirements for the recorded video.

HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Paul Wojno","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires each city or township clerk to maintain a permanent absent voter list.
  • Requires election officials to mail a notification to each registered voter that they may request to be added to the permanent absent voter list, and requires the option to be added to voter registration applications, including information on what must be included.
  • Clarifies information for carrying out the above requirements.
  • Allows voters to request to be removed from the permanent absent voter list, and includes information on how to administer this, including if a voter changes address.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Jon C. Bumstead","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that each challenger has the right to stand or sit behind the processing table at the polling place while people are applying to vote and the processing table while counting ballots, but not hinder electors.
  • Establishes that a challenger may observe the election process at a reasonable distance from the election inspectors, and defines "reasonable distance."
  • Establishes that a challenger may challenge the manner in which the duties of election inspectors are performed.
  • Defines "good reason to believe."
  • Allows challengers to get vote results in the precinct after polls close.
  • Allows challengers to use an electronic device in a polling place or counting board, as long as it does not hinder an elector's right to vote a secret ballot.
  • Allows challenger expelled from a polling place to ask for and be provided with a written explanation, and allows the entity appointing the challenger to appoint a new one.
  • Outlines procedures actions for if someone infringes on the rights of a challenger.
  • Defines poll watcher.
  • Outlines what a poll watcher may do at the polls and during a canvas.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Rick Outman","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Removes "Filing Certain False Statements" from the list of felonies enumerated in Michigan Election Law.

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Rick Outman","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)"]

COAUTHORS: ["John Bizon\u00a0*","Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Ed McBroom\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Ed Mcbroom","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/19/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/19/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Clarifies that the board of county canvassers will meet to canvas votes.
  • Requires at least one member from each political party to be present during the entire canvas.
  • Requires the board of county canvassers, and one member from each represented political party, to approve the hiring of each assistant to the clerk before their hiring.

COAUTHORS: ["Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Lana Theis","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/26/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/26/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires the full text of a ballot proposal to appear on all impacted ballots.

COAUTHORS: ["Jon Bumstead\u00a0*","Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Ed McBroom\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Ed Mcbroom","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/19/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/19/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires that starting January 1, 2022 existing boards of county canvassers in certain counties will be abolished and replaced, with varying membership depending on county size.
  • Requires one member from each political party represented on the board of county canvassers to be appointed for a two year term.
  • Outlines membership terms and notification requirements for appointments to the board of county canvassers.
  • Prohibits more than 50% of members from one political party on a board of canvassers.
  • Establishes quorum for each county board of canvassers.

COAUTHORS: ["Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Rick Outman\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Roger Victory\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Roger Victory","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/12/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/12/2021 Room 403, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires that training of precinct inspectors include training on conducting regular balancing checks to confirm the total number of ballots issued matches the total number of ballots counted.

COAUTHORS: ["Kevin Daley\u00a0*","Kenneth Horn\u00a0*","Kim LaSata\u00a0*","Jim Stamas\u00a0*","Lana Theis\u00a0*","Curt VanderWall\u00a0*","Dale Zorn\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["03/24/2021 - Introduced By Senator Dale W. Zorn","03/24/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/19/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/19/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes a deadline for submitting sealed election returns and tally sheets to the city clerk and establishes a deadline for the city clerk to transmit the information to appropriate authorities.
  • Changes the deadline for the local clerk to deliver returns from 11am to noon on the day following the election.

HISTORY: ["03/16/2021 - Introduced By Representative Pamela Hornberger","03/16/2021 - Read A First Time","03/16/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/17/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/16/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits contact information for an elected or appointed official from appearing on ballot related materials provided to a voter.
  • Defines ballot related material.

HISTORY: ["03/11/2021 - Introduced By Representative Steven Johnson","03/11/2021 - Read A First Time","03/11/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/16/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 03/11/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits a voter from exposing their ballot or absent voter ballot revealing who they voted for in a primary, and outlining procedures if this occurs.
  • Allows voters to display a photograph of their voted ballot more than 100 feet from a polling station.
  • Allows voters to use electronic devices in a voting booth.

COAUTHORS: ["Ann Bollin\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Sarah Lightner\u00a0*","Brad Paquette\u00a0*","Richard Steenland\u00a0*","Pauline Wendzel\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["02/04/2021 - Introduced By Representative Ann Bollin","02/04/2021 - Read A First Time","02/04/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/09/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/04/2021","02/23/2021 - House Substitute (H-1)","02/23/2021 - Reported With Recommendation With Substitute (h-1)","02/23/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","03/03/2021 - Read A Second Time","03/03/2021 - Substitute (h-1) Adopted","03/03/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","03/09/2021 - Read a third time","03/09/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 31 Yeas 79 Nays 30 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","03/09/2021 - Transmitted","03/10/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","08/31/2021 - Senate Elections (15:00 8/31/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","09/15/2021 - House Elections (09:00 9/15/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)"]

COAUTHORS: ["Ann Bollin\u00a0*","Kevin Hertel\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Sarah Lightner\u00a0*","Brad Paquette\u00a0*","Richard Steenland\u00a0*","Pauline Wendzel\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["02/04/2021 - Introduced By Representative Ann Bollin","02/04/2021 - Read A First Time","02/04/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/09/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/04/2021","02/23/2021 - Reported With Recommendation Without Amendment","02/23/2021 - Referred To Second Reading","03/03/2021 - Read A Second Time","03/03/2021 - Placed On Third Reading","03/09/2021 - Read a third time","03/09/2021 - Passed; Given Immediate Effect Roll Call # 32 Yeas 104 Nays 5 Excused 0 Not Voting 1","03/09/2021 - Transmitted","03/10/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines the number of absent voter counting boards required based on the number of election precincts in a district. 
  • Establishes that in a city or township with fewer than 6,000 registered voters and two precincts, an absent voter counting board is not required for both precincts.

COAUTHORS: ["Kyra Bolden\u00a0*","Felicia Brabec\u00a0*","Julie Brixie\u00a0*","Brenda Carter\u00a0*","Tyrone Carter\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Alex Garza\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Amos O'Neal\u00a0*","Laurie Pohutsky\u00a0*","Yousef Rabhi\u00a0*","Julie Rogers\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*","Regina Weiss\u00a0*","Stephanie Young\u00a0*"]

COAUTHORS: ["Kelly Breen\u00a0*","Brenda Carter\u00a0*","Tyrone Carter\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Alex Garza\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Yousef Rabhi\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["02/25/2021 - Introduced By Representative Jim Haadsma","02/25/2021 - Read A First Time","02/25/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/02/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/25/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires each clerk to maintain a permanent absent voter list.

  • Allows each clerk to mail a notice to each registered voter indicating a qualified voter may request to be placed in the permanent absent voter list.

  • Requires each voter registration application to include a space for a voter to indicate they wish to be placed on the permanent absent voter list.

  • Describes ways a voter must be able to indicate they want to be added to the permanent absent voter list.

  • Outlines procedures for election staff related to adding voters to the permanent absent voter list.

  • Outlines procedures for a voter to request to be removed from the permanent absent voter list.

  • Outlines reasons a clerk may remove a voter from the permanent absent voter list.

  • Outlines procedures for a change of address for a voter on the permanent absent voter list.

COAUTHORS: ["Felicia Brabec\u00a0*","Julie Brixie\u00a0*","Brenda Carter\u00a0*","Tyrone Carter\u00a0*","Mary Cavanagh\u00a0*","Alex Garza\u00a0*","Jim Haadsma\u00a0*","Rachel Hood\u00a0*","Kara Hope\u00a0*","Cynthia Johnson\u00a0*","Padma Kuppa\u00a0*","Amos O'Neal\u00a0*","Laurie Pohutsky\u00a0*","Julie Rogers\u00a0*","Terry Sabo\u00a0*","William Sowerby\u00a0*","Samantha Steckloff\u00a0*","Lori Stone\u00a0*","Regina Weiss\u00a0*","Stephanie Young\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["02/25/2021 - Introduced By Representative Kara Hope","02/25/2021 - Read A First Time","02/25/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","03/02/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/25/2021"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits anyone circulating a certain type of ballot question petition, or a recall petition, from making false statement or misrepresenting aspects of the petition to a certain listed group of individuals or with the purpose of obtaining or influencing their signature decision.

  •  Provides that a violation is subject to a civil fine and a misdemeanor offense.

HISTORY: ["02/11/2021 - Introduced By Senator Paul Wojno","02/11/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","06/23/2021 - Senate Elections (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)","06/23/2021 - House Elections (12:00 6/23/2021 Room 1300, Binsfeld Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Changes the month or primary elections to June from August.

  • Changes the deadline for filing a resolution to temporarily reduce the number of judgeships in a primary election to the 16th Tuesday before the June primary.

  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - Introduced By Representative Pamela Hornberger","02/10/2021 - Read A First Time","02/10/2021 - Referred To Committee On Elections And Ethics","02/11/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/10/2021","06/15/2021 - House Elections and Ethics (12:00 6/15/2021 Room 326, House Office Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits a candidate from running for more than one office when the person is temporarily filling a vacancy and running for that office.
  • Outlines rules in the case of the death of a candidate for city office or village office.

HISTORY: ["02/10/2021 - Introduced By Representative Pamela Hornberger","02/10/2021 - Read A First Time","02/10/2021 - Referred to Committee on Education","02/11/2021 - Bill Electronically Reproduced 02/10/2021"]

COAUTHORS: ["Marshall Bullock\u00a0*","Stephanie Chang\u00a0*","Erika Geiss\u00a0*","Adam Hollier\u00a0*","Jeff Irwin\u00a0*","Jeremy Moss\u00a0*","Dayna Polehanki\u00a0*","Sylvia Santana\u00a0*","Paul Wojno\u00a0*"]
HISTORY: ["01/27/2021 - Introduced By Senator Stephanie Chang","01/27/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Removes reasons for an exemption in recounting ballots.
  • Removes procedures for if ballot counts do not match.
  • Removes reference to precincts considered "not recountable."

HISTORY: ["01/13/2021 - Introduced By Senator Paul Wojno","01/13/2021 - Referred to Committee on Elections","05/05/2021 - Senate Elections (14:00 5/5/2021 Harry T. Gast Appropriations Room, 3rd Floor, Capitol Building)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Allows an eligible uniformed or overseas voter to electronically return an absent ballot to the appropriate clerk to be counted using the procedures outlines by the Secretary of State.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to develop policies and procedures for electronic return of ballots and includes a list of what must be included in the policies and procedures.
  • Establishes that the Secretary of State may develop a secure web portal to facilitate electronic return.
  • Defines "eligible member" and "uniformed services."

COAUTHORS: ["Esther Agbaje","Andrew Carlson","Shelly Christensen","Rob Ecklund","Carlos Mariani","Mohamud Noor","Dan Wolgamott"]
HISTORY: ["02/22/2021 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections","02/25/2021 - Author added Ecklund","03/01/2021 - Authors added Mariani and Wolgamott","03/18/2021 - Author added Christensen","01/31/2022 - Author stricken Ecklund","03/10/2022 - Author added Carlson","05/16/2022 - Author added Ecklund"]

["03/31/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to Redistricting","05/04/2022 - Author added Murphy (as chief author)","05/04/2022 - Author added Klevorn","05/05/2022 - House Redistricting (09:00 5/5/2022 )"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill alters the district boundaries for Senate District 58.

HISTORY: ["02/15/2021 - Introduction and first reading, referred to Transportation Finance and Policy","02/18/2021 - Motion to recall and re-refer, motion prevailed State Government Finance and Elections","02/21/2021 - Referred by Chair to Local Government Division","04/28/2022 - House Local Government Division (08:30 4/28/2022 )"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Adds Metropolitan Council member to the definition of "candidate."
  • Requires Metropolitan Council candidates to complete a filing statement with the board.
  • Sets spending and contribution limits for Metropolitan Council candidates.
  • Outlines a program for public subsidy in elections for Metropolitan Council candidates.
  • Adds Metropolitan Council to the affidavit requirements for other local candidates and makes complying changes.
  • Adds Metropolitan Council candidates to the list of candidates for rules regarding absent candidates.
  • Sets a filing fee of $100 for Metropolitan Council candidates, or a nominating petition with 500 valid signatures.
  • Adds Metropolitan Council elections to existing election code for other elections.
  • Stipulates that Metropolitan Council candidate elections will be nonpartisan.
  • Outlines procedures for a vacancy and a special election in the Metropolitan Council office.
  • Outlines the membership requirements for a Metropolitan Council and how the membership will be appointed until after completion of implementation of the 2020 US Census results, and then elected by district.
  • Outlines terms and jurisdiction requirements for Metropolitan Council members, as well as redistricting rules.
  • Stipulates compensation requirements for Metropolitan Council members.
  • Outlines transition requirements for the Metropolitan Council members.
  • Applies the Act to certain counties.
  • Provides for salaries of Metropolitan Council members.
  • Makes complying changes.
  • Defines relevant terms.

HISTORY: "04/26/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines the requirements and timeline for a forensic audit.
  • Provides for payment for a forensic audit.
  • Outlines the expenses for which the requesting party is responsible.

HISTORY: "04/26/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Puts forth the "Strengthening Attorney General Oversight of Voting and Elections Act."
  • Provides the Attorney General statewide jurisdiction in criminal proceedings related to voting, campaigning, and elections.
  • Clarifies that the jurisdiction is concurrent with the local prosecuting authority.
  • Requires an investigating Attorney General to notify appropriate local authorities.

COAUTHORS: ["Greg Boe","Brian Daniels","Lisa Demuth","John Heinrich","Jerry Hertaus","Ron Kresha","Nathan Nelson","John Petersburg","Duane Quam","Kristin Robbins","Joe Schomacker","Peggy Scott","Paul Torkelson","Dean Urdahl","Nolan West"]
HISTORY: ["04/08/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections","04/19/2022 - Authors added West, Heinrich, Boe, Quam, Urdahl, Schomacker, Kresha, Hertaus, Scott and Nelson, N.","04/21/2022 - Author added Daniels"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits a fee to be charged when someone certifies they need a certain document to register to vote, or a voter identification card, and outlines related reporting requirements.
  • Provides for appropriations related to this service, including specifying certain amounts.
  • Adds a voter identification card to the list of identifications whose format must be approved by the department.
  • Provides that no fee may be charged for a voter identification card.
  • Stipulates what must be included on the application for a voter identification card.
  • Outlines criteria and requirements for issuing a voter identification card.
  • Outlines required content of a voter identification card.
  • Establishes rules governing voter identification cards for military voters and their spouses.
  • Stipulates that voter identification cards must have the voter's current address and procedures to update a card and issue a duplicate card.
  • Specifies procedures for canceling a voter identification card.
  • Lists what is considered sufficient proof of identity and residence for Election Day voter registration.
  • Establishes a voter identification card account for reimbursement in for multiple specified expenses.
  • Specifies that the polling place roster address must be the voter's most current address, and includes certain exceptions, and outlines verification procedures when a voter is checking in to vote.
  • Outlines certain provisions for absentee ballot signature envelopes, particularly for the witness.
  • Includes the voter identification number as an acceptable identification for an application for absentee ballot.
  • Requires the appropriate official to verify identification numbers provided for absentee ballot applications.
  • Allows the voter identification card as an acceptable ID for the absentee ballot signature envelope. 
  • Provides that a judge must require a voter to sign the polling place roster and outlines procedures for voters who do not have proper identification.
  • Prohibits a government entity from accepting contributions in any form from an outside entity to pay for election related expenses.
  • Outlines procedures for distributing, casting, and counting provisional ballots.
  • Provides that the canvas board, or other canvas group, will meet on the 8th day (rather than the second or third day) after the election and complete the canvas. 
  • Provides timelines for the canvas board, or other canvas group, to meet at the auditor's office, and the state capitol, to canvas the vote.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to receive the canvas report 10 days following a primary and 15 days following a general election.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to contract with a vendor regarding a voter information campaign about voter identification requirements, with specific requirements.
  • Requires the Secretary of State by January 15, 2023 to report on proposed changes to administrative rules governing elections, with certain requirements.
  • Requires training for drivers license agents on issuing voter identification cards.
  • Requires any other designated polling place be open for in person absentee voting during the entire absentee voting period during the same days and hours as the office of the county auditor. 
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Provides effective dates.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["04/19/2022 - Introduction and first reading","04/19/2022 - Referred to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections","04/21/2022 - Authors added Utke; Koran"]

BILLSUMMARY:
• Prohibits a fee to be charged when someone certifies they need a certain document to register to vote, or a voter identification card, and outlines related reporting requirements.
  • Provides for appropriations related to this service, including specifying certain amounts.
  • Adds a voter identification card to the list of identifications whose format must be approved by the department.
  • Provides that no fee may be charged for a voter identification card.
  • Stipulates what must be included on the application for a voter identification card.
  • Outlines criteria and requirements for issuing a voter identification card.
  • Outlines required content of a voter identification card.
  • Establishes rules governing voter identification cards for military voters and their spouses.
  • Stipulates that voter identification cards must have the voter's current address and procedures to update a card and provide a duplicate.
  • Specifies procedures for canceling a voter identification card.
  • Lists what is considered sufficient proof of identity and residence for voting and registering.
  • Establishes a voter identification card account for reimbursement in for multiple specified expenses.
  • Specifies that the polling place roster address must be the voter's most current address, and includes certain exceptions.
  • Includes the voter identification number as an acceptable identification for an application for absentee ballot.
  • Requires the appropriate official to verify identification numbers provided for absentee ballot applications.
  • Allows the voter identification card as an acceptable ID for the absentee ballot signature envelope. 
  • Outlines certain additional provisions for absentee ballot signature envelopes, particularly for the witness.
  • Provides that a judge must require a voter to sign the polling place roster and outlines procedures for voters who do not have proper identification.
  • Outlines procedures for casting and counting provisional ballots.
  • Provides that the canvas board, or other canvas group, will meet on the 8th day (rather than the second or third day) after the election and complete the canvas. 
  • Provides timelines for the canvas board, or other canvas group, to meet at the auditor's office, and the state capitol, to canvas the vote.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to receive the canvas report 10 days following a primary and 15 days following a general election.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to contract with a vendor regarding a voter information campaign about voter identification requirements, with specific requirements.
  • Requires the Secretary of State by January 15, 2023 to report on proposed changes to administrative rules governing elections, with certain requirements.
  • Requires training for drivers license agents on issuing voter identification cards.
  • Provides appropriations.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Provides effective dates.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

• Defines "electioneer."
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Provides clarifying language.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires officials to make a list of active and inactive voters available without cost.
  • Requires the county auditor to post the voting history of every person who voted in the election within three days after the election (the deadline was six weeks after the election).
  • Requires abstracts filed by the canvassing board be sent to the state Historical Society for public access and viewing after they are no longer required.
  • Changes the content of what needs to be recorded by the county canvassing board.
  • Changes the deadline for the notice of contest to 14 days after the event.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to notify all affected candidates that contest has been served.  
  • Makes clarifying changes.

COAUTHORS: ["Matt Bliss","Greg Boe","Greg Davids","Joshua Heintzeman","Jerry Hertaus","Brian Pfarr","Kristin Robbins","Peggy Scott"]

["03/21/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections","04/07/2022 - Authors added Scott and Boe"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Changes the deadline for same day voter registrations to be added to the statewide registration system from 42 days after the election to two days after the election.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to transmit information about received voter registration applications to appropriate county auditors.
  • Provides that absentee ballots may not be "left with" the county auditor, but must be personally delivered.
  • Prohibits an agent dropping off another person's absentee ballot envelope in a drop box.
  • Requires video recordings from dropbox locations to be live-streamed.
  • Outlines specifications for dropbox locations.
  • Adds requirements to what must be printed on the outside of a drop box.
  • Outlines requirements for maintaining a ballot collection log of each drop box, and reporting on it.
  • Provides provisions for who may serve on a ballot board.
  • Outlines requirements for video recording ballot board activity, and requirements for retaining the recording.
  • Lists all those who are forbidden from disclosing the results of an election prematurely.
  • Stipulates the the state voting equipment grant is a one time appropriation.
  • Outlines when the election security and integrity grant report is due, and who should receive it.
  • Lists a September 1, 2022 effective date.   
  • Provides complying changes.

["03/08/2021 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections","05/06/2021 - Author added Pfarr","02/17/2022 - Author added Davids","04/07/2022 - Authors added Scott and Bliss"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Provides clarifying language for procedures related to incomplete voter registration forms.
  • Provides procedures for completing a voter registration and provisional ballot on the same day, or by mail.
  • Adds content required in notifications about registered voters before an election and adds an effective date.
  • Requires that voter registrations be entered by three days after the election (a change from 42 days).
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide daily reports for six days following an election of voters whose information cannot be verified.
  • Outlines procedures for county staff upon receipt of a voter registration and absentee ballot by mail.
  • Clarifies a person who is not preregistered may not use alternative procedures to cast an absentee ballot.
  • Changes the name of return envelopes to signature envelopes.
  • Outlines requirements for challengers to establish residency.
  • Outlines procedures for casting a provisional ballot, including counting, verification, judges, reconciliation, and notification procedures.
  • Changes deadlines for the canvass of primary, county, municipal, and school district elections.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to contract a vendor to conduct a public information campaign about registering to vote with certain requirements.  
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Sets an effective date.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires members of the ballot board to confirm a ballot has the appropriate watermark indicating its authenticity.
  • Requires ballots be printed using certain paper and watermarks, with certain exceptions.
  • Establishes who may create the watermark for each type of election.

HISTORY: ["02/11/2021 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections","02/18/2021 - Author added Hertaus","04/07/2022 - Author added Boe"]
BILLSUMMARY: • Requires that additional polling places designated by the county auditor must be open for in-person absentee voting the entire absentee voting period with the same hours as other designated locations.

COAUTHORS: ["Esther Agbaje","Steve Elkins","Sandra Feist","Pat Garofalo","Aisha Gomez","Emma Greenman","Hodan Hassan","Frank Hornstein","Michael Howard","Sydney Jordan","Heather Keeler","Jamie Long","Dave Pinto","Zack Stephenson","Samantha Vang","Dan Wolgamott","Jay Xiong","Cheryl Youakim"]
HISTORY: ["02/08/2021 - Introduction and first reading, referred to Public Safety and Criminal Justice Reform Finance and Policy","02/10/2021 - Authors added Stephenson, Jordan, Youakim, Long, Howard, Garofalo, and Vang","02/22/2021 - Author added Pinto","03/01/2021 - Author added Wolgamott","03/04/2021 - Committee report, to adopt","03/04/2021 - Second Reading","04/06/2021 - Author added Hornstein","03/28/2022 - Author added Elkins","04/04/2022 - Author added Feist"]
BILLSUMMARY: This bill mandates that an individual convicted of a felony has his or her civil right to vote restored when the individual is no longer incarcerated for the offense, or upon sentencing if no incarceration is imposed. If the individual is later incarcerated for the same offense, the individual's civil right to vote is lost only during the period of incarceration. This bill requires a notice of restoration of the civil right to vote and a voter registration application be provided to formerly incarcerated individuals and those leaving incarceration.

HISTORY: ["03/28/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections","03/30/2022 - Author added Youakim","03/31/2022 - House State Government Finance and Elections (08:30 3/31/2022 )"]
["03/24/2022 - Introduction and first reading","03/24/2022 - Referred to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections","03/29/2022 - Author added Pappas","03/30/2022 - Author added Carlson"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines terms relevant to ranked choice voting.
  • Provides that the ranked choice voting method must be used for federal, state, and legislative offices at every primary and regular election.
  • Authorizes local adoption of ranked choice voting for all general elections and primaries.
  • Clarifies that a primary election must not be held for nonpartisan races. 
  • Outlines timelines for adopting ranked choice voting.
  • Specifies ballot format for ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines requirements for tabulation of ranked choice voting including location and procedures.
  • Codifies procedures for reporting results.
  • Outlines procedures for a recount.
  • Gives the Secretary of State implementation authority.
  • Requires outreach, notification, and training before use of ranked choice voting in an election.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create ballot format rules for ranked choice voting, with certain requirements.
  • Specifies procedures for use of an approved electronic voting system with an unapproved tabulating system.
  • Outlines procedures for purchasing a new electronic voting system.
  • Specifies requirements related to ranked choice voting in the post election review.
  • Appropriates funds for implementation.

HISTORY: ["02/24/2022 - Introduction and first reading","02/24/2022 - Referred to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections","03/02/2022 - Author added Dornink","03/22/2022 - Senate Committee on State Government Finance and Policy and Elections (10:30 3/22/2022 Room 1100 Minnesota Senate Bldg.)","03/23/2022 - Comm report: To pass as amended and re-refer to Civil Law and Data Practices Policy","03/29/2022 - Senate Committee on Civil Law and Data Practices Policy (13:00 3/29/2022 Room G-15 Capitol)","03/30/2022 - Comm report: To pass as amended and re-refer to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires Election Day voter registration applications to be entered into the system before the election canvas begins (a change from 42 days after the election).
  • Allows absentee ballots to be personally delivered to the appropriate official.
  • Forbids an agent depositing someone else's absentee ballot in a dropbox.
  • Outlines guidelines for dropbox locations and notifications on the dropbox.
  • Requires a ballot collection log for each dropbox and clarifies reporting requirements.
  • Outlines who must not be on a ballot board.
  • Stipulates that the counting of ballots must be made public. 
  • Clarifies guidelines for appointing ballot board observers and outlines their duties, including what they may and may not do. 
  • Requires live-streaming of certain ballot board activity, and outlines live-streaming requirements.
  • Prohibits anyone disclosing precinct election results until all precinct ballots have been processed, with exceptions for absentee ballot processing.
  • Requires public notice for testing voting machines be given two weeks (up from two days) in advance, with specific requirements.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to report about grants awarded for ballot dropbox security.
  • Sets appropriations for related items.
  • Provides effective dates.
  • Makes clarifying changes.

HISTORY: ["03/02/2022 - Introduction and first reading","03/02/2022 - Referred to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections","03/16/2022 - Senate Committee on State Government Finance and Policy and Elections (10:30 3/16/2022 Room 1100 Minnesota Senate Bldg.)","03/16/2022 - Author added Draheim","03/17/2022 - Comm report: To pass as amended and re-refer to Civil Law and Data Practices Policy","03/29/2022 - Senate Committee on Civil Law and Data Practices Policy (13:00 3/29/2022 Room G-15 Capitol)","03/30/2022 - Comm report: To pass as amended","03/30/2022 - Joint rule 2.03, referred to Rules and Administration"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that all data in the statewide voter registration system is public data.
  • Lists what is considered private data on individuals.
  • Establishes that the presidential primary political party list is private data, except that it is provided to the chair of each major political party.
  • Establishes procedures for when a voter fills out a request to keep their information private.
  • Makes conforming changes.

HISTORY: ["03/21/2022 - Introduction and first reading","03/21/2022 - Referred to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections","03/29/2022 - Senate Committee on State Government Finance and Policy and Elections (10:30 3/29/2022 Room 1100 Minnesota Senate Bldg.)"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines provisions for creating an absentee ballot for a precinct.
  • Adds assisted living facilities, residential treatment programs, and adult day cares to the definition of residential facilities.
  • Adds reasons a voter registration may not be deficient and outlines related procedures.
  • Replaces "resides" with "maintains residence" in related election code.
  • Specifies that emergency response providers and utility workers are eligible for absentee voting with certain conditions.
  • Outlines timelines for setting polling place locations and absentee voting for town elections.
  • Specifies how ballots may be delivered to women's shelters and veteran's homes.
  • Specifies a timeline for changing a polling place.
  • Makes exceptions for mail ballots having both school and municipal candidates when they overlap.
  • Specifies procedures for declaring a winner for the canvass board at the completion of the canvass.
  • Directs the clerk to provide notification 14 days before a special primary and 21 days before a special election.
  • Provides that candidate affidavits in a special election are due 21 days in advance of the election.
  • Clarifies that rules regarding soliciting near polling places apply only during poll opening hours.
  • Provides clarifying language.

HISTORY: ["03/23/2022 - Introduction and first reading","03/23/2022 - Referred to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections","03/28/2022 - Author added Isaacson"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Establishes that the Attorney General must assist in the enforcement of code, including intimidation of election officials.
  • Outlines penalties for intimidation of election officials.
  • Allows for civil actions by the Attorney General or other authorized officials.
  • Provides for civil remedies.
  • Defines relevant terms.

  • Provides for payment for a forensic audit.
  • Outlines the expenses for which the requesting party is responsible.

HISTORY: ["02/21/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections","02/24/2022 - Author added Bahner","03/03/2022 - Author added Kotyza-Witthuhn","03/04/2022 - House State Government Finance and Elections (08:30 3/4/2022 )","03/08/2022 - House State Government Finance and Elections (08:30 3/8/2022 )","03/10/2022 - Committee report, to adopt as amended and re-refer to Judiciary Finance and Civil Law","03/10/2022 - Author added Frederick","03/15/2022 - House Judiciary Finance and Civil Law (08:30 3/15/2022 )","03/17/2022 - Committee report, to adopt and re-refer to Ways and Means","03/23/2022 - Author added Her"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Requires the attorney general to assist in enforcement of a series of laws related to business, commerce, and trade, as well as laws related to voter intimidation, interference, and deceptive practices in elections.
  • Lists specific potential infractions in voting related practices and elections and their penalties.
  • Provides for and defines vicarious liability related to elections.
  • Establishes the extent and limits of remedies.
  • Lists specific voter intimidation and deceptive practices included in the code, and establishes penalties. 
  • Defines related terms. 
  • Makes conforming changes.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Outlines the required notification statement to be included by organizations or committees sending a sample ballot or an absentee ballot application.
  • Sets guidelines for the format of the notification.

HISTORY: ["03/23/2022 - Introduction and first reading","03/23/2022 - Referred to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Appropriates one-time funds for election security.
  • Lists the purposes for which the funds may be used.
  • Establishes that the Secretary of State will administer the funds and allows jurisdictions to apply for grants.
  • Lists required elements of the application.
  • Outlines what may occur if a jurisdiction declines to apply for funds.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to establish the funding application process and reporting process.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to submit a related report to the appropriate legislative committee by January 31, 2023.

HISTORY: ["02/14/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections","02/15/2022 - Referred by Chair to Local Government Division","03/23/2022 - Author added Bliss"]
"03/21/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections"
BILLSUMMARY:
• Defines terms relevant to ranked choice voting.
  • Provides that the ranked choice voting method must be used for federal, state, and legislative offices at every primary and regular election.
  • Authorizes local adoption of ranked choice voting for all general elections and primaries.
  • Clarifies that a primary election must not be held for nonpartisan races. 
  • Outlines timelines for adopting ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines guidelines for how to repeal ranked choice voting.
  • Specifies ballot format for ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines requirements for tabulation of ranked choice voting including location and procedures.
  • Codifies procedures for reporting results.
  • Outlines procedures for a recount.
  • Gives the Secretary of State implementation authority.
  • Requires outreach, notification, and training before use of ranked choice voting in an election.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create ballot format rules for ranked choice voting, with certain requirements.
  • Specifies procedures for use of an approved electronic voting system with an unapproved tabulating system.
  • Outlines procedures for purchasing a new electronic voting system.
  • Specifies requirements related to ranked choice voting in the post election review.
  • Appropriates funds for implementation.

["02/03/2022 - Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections","02/07/2022 - Authors added Bahner and Long","02/11/2022 - House State Government Finance and Elections (08:30 2/11/2022 )","02/14/2022 - House State Government Finance and Elections (10:30 2/14/2022 )","02/17/2022 - Committee report, to adopt as amended and re-refer to Ways and Means","03/10/2022 - Author added Frederick"]
BILLSUMMARY:
• Adds early voting into existing election code related to absentee voting.
  • Defines early voting.
  • Exempts jurisdictions conducting voting exclusively by mail from early voting rules.
  • Sets timelines for mailing ballots to voters on the permanent vote by mail list.
  • Adds the voter record as a place where a voter's signature may be compared for validation.
  • Describes the administrative duties of the ballot board in early voting.
  • Clarifies that a voter who voted early may not be permitted to vote again.
  • Outlines recording requirements for the when an early vote is cast.
  • Changes the starting date for opening envelopes for cast early votes.
  • Outlines how a municipality may implement early voting.
  • Establishes that early voting must be available to eligible voters.
  • Sets a timeline and hours for early voting.
  • Outlines location information for early voting.
  • Sets notification requirements to voters about early voting.
  • Clarifies early voting procedures and roles of election officials.
  • Requires the election computer program and its backup to each jurisdiction 40 days before the election.
  • Changes the deadline for testing voting equipment from 14 days before Election Day to 37 days before Election Day.
  • Sets an effective date.
  • Makes complying changes.

BILLSUMMARY:
• Appropriates $5 million in 2023 for enhanced election security.
  • Lists the purposes for which the funds may be used.
  • Outlines county eligibility for grants.
  • Requires specific reporting by the Secretary of State.
